00038 // when it's fused.

00106 // Utilities for testing Google Test itself and code that uses Google Test
00107 // (e.g. frameworks built on top of Google Test).

00109 #ifndef GTEST_INCLUDE_GTEST_GTEST_SPI_H_
00110 #define GTEST_INCLUDE_GTEST_GTEST_SPI_H_

00112 
00113 namespace testing {
00114 
00115 // This helper class can be used to mock out Google Test failure reporting
00116 // so that we can test Google Test or code that builds on Google Test.
00117 //
00118 // An object of this class appends a TestPartResult object to the
00119 // TestPartResultArray object given in the constructor whenever a Google Test
00120 // failure is reported. It can either intercept only failures that are
00121 // generated in the same thread that created this object or it can intercept
00122 // all generated failures. The scope of this mock object can be controlled with
00123 // the second argument to the two arguments constructor.
00124 class GTEST_API_ ScopedFakeTestPartResultReporter
00125     : public TestPartResultReporterInterface {
00126  public:
00127   // The two possible mocking modes of this object.
00128   enum InterceptMode {
00129     INTERCEPT_ONLY_CURRENT_THREAD,  // Intercepts only thread local failures.
00130     INTERCEPT_ALL_THREADS           // Intercepts all failures.
00131   };
00132 
00133   // The c'tor sets this object as the test part result reporter used
00134   // by Google Test.  The 'result' parameter specifies where to report the
00135   // results. This reporter will only catch failures generated in the current
00136   // thread. DEPRECATED
00137   explicit ScopedFakeTestPartResultReporter(TestPartResultArray* result);
00138 
00139   // Same as above, but you can choose the interception scope of this object.
00140   ScopedFakeTestPartResultReporter(InterceptMode intercept_mode,
00141                                    TestPartResultArray* result);
00142 
00143   // The d'tor restores the previous test part result reporter.
00144   virtual ~ScopedFakeTestPartResultReporter();
00145 
00146   // Appends the TestPartResult object to the TestPartResultArray
00147   // received in the constructor.
00148   //
00149   // This method is from the TestPartResultReporterInterface
00150   // interface.
00151   virtual void ReportTestPartResult(const TestPartResult& result);
00152  private:
00153   void Init();
00154 
00155   const InterceptMode intercept_mode_;
00156   TestPartResultReporterInterface* old_reporter_;
00157   TestPartResultArray* const result_;
00158 
00159   GTEST_DISALLOW_COPY_AND_ASSIGN_(ScopedFakeTestPartResultReporter);
00160 };
00161 
00162 namespace internal {
00163 
00164 // A helper class for implementing EXPECT_FATAL_FAILURE() and
00165 // EXPECT_NONFATAL_FAILURE().  Its destructor verifies that the given
00166 // TestPartResultArray contains exactly one failure that has the given
00167 // type and contains the given substring.  If that's not the case, a
00168 // non-fatal failure will be generated.
00169 class GTEST_API_ SingleFailureChecker {
00170  public:
00171   // The constructor remembers the arguments.
00172   SingleFailureChecker(const TestPartResultArray* results,
00173                        TestPartResult::Type type,
00174                        const string& substr);
00175   ~SingleFailureChecker();
00176  private:
00177   const TestPartResultArray* const results_;
00178   const TestPartResult::Type type_;
00179   const string substr_;
00180 
00181   GTEST_DISALLOW_COPY_AND_ASSIGN_(SingleFailureChecker);
00182 };
00183 
00184 }  // namespace internal
00185 
00186 }  // namespace testing
00187 
00188 // A set of macros for testing Google Test assertions or code that's expected
00189 // to generate Google Test fatal failures.  It verifies that the given
00190 // statement will cause exactly one fatal Google Test failure with 'substr'
00191 // being part of the failure message.
00192 //
00193 // There are two different versions of this macro. EXPECT_FATAL_FAILURE only
00194 // affects and considers failures generated in the current thread and
00195 // EXPECT_FATAL_FAILURE_ON_ALL_THREADS does the same but for all threads.
00196 //
00197 // The verification of the assertion is done correctly even when the statement
00198 // throws an exception or aborts the current function.
00199 //
00200 // Known restrictions:
00201 //   - 'statement' cannot reference local non-static variables or
00202 //     non-static members of the current object.
00203 //   - 'statement' cannot return a value.
00204 //   - You cannot stream a failure message to this macro.
00205 //
00206 // Note that even though the implementations of the following two
00207 // macros are much alike, we cannot refactor them to use a common
00208 // helper macro, due to some peculiarity in how the preprocessor
00209 // works.  The AcceptsMacroThatExpandsToUnprotectedComma test in
00210 // gtest_unittest.cc will fail to compile if we do that.
00211 #define EXPECT_FATAL_FAILURE(statement, substr) \
00212   do { \
00213     class GTestExpectFatalFailureHelper {\
00214      public:\
00215       static void Execute() { statement; }\
00216     };\
00217     ::testing::TestPartResultArray gtest_failures;\
00218     ::testing::internal::SingleFailureChecker gtest_checker(\
00219         &gtest_failures, ::testing::TestPartResult::kFatalFailure, (substr));\
00220     {\
00221       ::testing::ScopedFakeTestPartResultReporter gtest_reporter(\
00222           ::testing::ScopedFakeTestPartResultReporter:: \
00223           INTERCEPT_ONLY_CURRENT_THREAD, &gtest_failures);\
00224       GTestExpectFatalFailureHelper::Execute();\
00225     }\
00226   } while (::testing::internal::AlwaysFalse())
00227 
00228 #define EXPECT_FATAL_FAILURE_ON_ALL_THREADS(statement, substr) \
00229   do { \
00230     class GTestExpectFatalFailureHelper {\
00231      public:\
00232       static void Execute() { statement; }\
00233     };\
00234     ::testing::TestPartResultArray gtest_failures;\
00235     ::testing::internal::SingleFailureChecker gtest_checker(\
00236         &gtest_failures, ::testing::TestPartResult::kFatalFailure, (substr));\
00237     {\
00238       ::testing::ScopedFakeTestPartResultReporter gtest_reporter(\
00239           ::testing::ScopedFakeTestPartResultReporter:: \
00240           INTERCEPT_ALL_THREADS, &gtest_failures);\
00241       GTestExpectFatalFailureHelper::Execute();\
00242     }\
00243   } while (::testing::internal::AlwaysFalse())
00244 
00245 // A macro for testing Google Test assertions or code that's expected to
00246 // generate Google Test non-fatal failures.  It asserts that the given
00247 // statement will cause exactly one non-fatal Google Test failure with 'substr'
00248 // being part of the failure message.
00249 //
00250 // There are two different versions of this macro. EXPECT_NONFATAL_FAILURE only
00251 // affects and considers failures generated in the current thread and
00252 // EXPECT_NONFATAL_FAILURE_ON_ALL_THREADS does the same but for all threads.
00253 //
00254 // 'statement' is allowed to reference local variables and members of
00255 // the current object.
00256 //
00257 // The verification of the assertion is done correctly even when the statement
00258 // throws an exception or aborts the current function.
00259 //
00260 // Known restrictions:
00261 //   - You cannot stream a failure message to this macro.
00262 //
00263 // Note that even though the implementations of the following two
00264 // macros are much alike, we cannot refactor them to use a common
00265 // helper macro, due to some peculiarity in how the preprocessor
00266 // works.  If we do that, the code won't compile when the user gives
00267 // EXPECT_NONFATAL_FAILURE() a statement that contains a macro that
00268 // expands to code containing an unprotected comma.  The
00269 // AcceptsMacroThatExpandsToUnprotectedComma test in gtest_unittest.cc
00270 // catches that.
00271 //
00272 // For the same reason, we have to write
00273 //   if (::testing::internal::AlwaysTrue()) { statement; }
00274 // instead of
00275 //   GTEST_SUPPRESS_UNREACHABLE_CODE_WARNING_BELOW_(statement)
00276 // to avoid an MSVC warning on unreachable code.
00277 #define EXPECT_NONFATAL_FAILURE(statement, substr) \
00278   do {\
00279     ::testing::TestPartResultArray gtest_failures;\
00280     ::testing::internal::SingleFailureChecker gtest_checker(\
00281         &gtest_failures, ::testing::TestPartResult::kNonFatalFailure, \
00282         (substr));\
00283     {\
00284       ::testing::ScopedFakeTestPartResultReporter gtest_reporter(\
00285           ::testing::ScopedFakeTestPartResultReporter:: \
00286           INTERCEPT_ONLY_CURRENT_THREAD, &gtest_failures);\
00287       if (::testing::internal::AlwaysTrue()) { statement; }\
00288     }\
00289   } while (::testing::internal::AlwaysFalse())
00290 
00291 #define EXPECT_NONFATAL_FAILURE_ON_ALL_THREADS(statement, substr) \
00292   do {\
00293     ::testing::TestPartResultArray gtest_failures;\
00294     ::testing::internal::SingleFailureChecker gtest_checker(\
00295         &gtest_failures, ::testing::TestPartResult::kNonFatalFailure, \
00296         (substr));\
00297     {\
00298       ::testing::ScopedFakeTestPartResultReporter gtest_reporter(\
00299           ::testing::ScopedFakeTestPartResultReporter::INTERCEPT_ALL_THREADS,\
00300           &gtest_failures);\
00301       if (::testing::internal::AlwaysTrue()) { statement; }\
00302     }\
00303   } while (::testing::internal::AlwaysFalse())
00304 
00305 #endif  // GTEST_INCLUDE_GTEST_GTEST_SPI_H_
00306

00320 #if GTEST_OS_LINUX
00321 
00322 // TODO(kenton@google.com): Use autoconf to detect availability of
00323 // gettimeofday().
00324 # define GTEST_HAS_GETTIMEOFDAY_ 1
00325 
00326 # include <fcntl.h>  // NOLINT
00327 # include <limits.h>  // NOLINT
00328 # include <sched.h>  // NOLINT
00329 // Declares vsnprintf().  This header is not available on Windows.
00330 # include <strings.h>  // NOLINT
00331 # include <sys/mman.h>  // NOLINT
00332 # include <sys/time.h>  // NOLINT
00333 # include <unistd.h>  // NOLINT
00334 # include <string>
00335 
00336 #elif GTEST_OS_SYMBIAN
00337 # define GTEST_HAS_GETTIMEOFDAY_ 1
00338 # include <sys/time.h>  // NOLINT
00339 
00340 #elif GTEST_OS_ZOS
00341 # define GTEST_HAS_GETTIMEOFDAY_ 1
00342 # include <sys/time.h>  // NOLINT
00343 
00344 // On z/OS we additionally need strings.h for strcasecmp.
00345 # include <strings.h>  // NOLINT
00346 
00347 #elif GTEST_OS_WINDOWS_MOBILE  // We are on Windows CE.
00348 
00349 # include <windows.h>  // NOLINT
00350 
00351 #elif GTEST_OS_WINDOWS  // We are on Windows proper.
00352 
00353 # include <io.h>  // NOLINT
00354 # include <sys/timeb.h>  // NOLINT
00355 # include <sys/types.h>  // NOLINT
00356 # include <sys/stat.h>  // NOLINT
00357 
00358 # if GTEST_OS_WINDOWS_MINGW
00359 // MinGW has gettimeofday() but not _ftime64().
00360 // TODO(kenton@google.com): Use autoconf to detect availability of
00361 //   gettimeofday().
00362 // TODO(kenton@google.com): There are other ways to get the time on
00363 //   Windows, like GetTickCount() or GetSystemTimeAsFileTime().  MinGW
00364 //   supports these.  consider using them instead.
00365 #  define GTEST_HAS_GETTIMEOFDAY_ 1
00366 #  include <sys/time.h>  // NOLINT
00367 # endif  // GTEST_OS_WINDOWS_MINGW
00368 
00369 // cpplint thinks that the header is already included, so we want to
00370 // silence it.
00371 # include <windows.h>  // NOLINT
00372 
00373 #else
00374 
00375 // Assume other platforms have gettimeofday().
00376 // TODO(kenton@google.com): Use autoconf to detect availability of
00377 //   gettimeofday().
00378 # define GTEST_HAS_GETTIMEOFDAY_ 1
00379 
00380 // cpplint thinks that the header is already included, so we want to
00381 // silence it.
00382 # include <sys/time.h>  // NOLINT
00383 # include <unistd.h>  // NOLINT
00384 
00385 #endif  // GTEST_OS_LINUX
00386 
00387 #if GTEST_HAS_EXCEPTIONS
00388 # include <stdexcept>
00389 #endif
00390 
00391 #if GTEST_CAN_STREAM_RESULTS_
00392 # include <arpa/inet.h>  // NOLINT
00393 # include <netdb.h>  // NOLINT
00394 #endif

00396 // Indicates that this translation unit is part of Google Test's
00397 // implementation.  It must come before gtest-internal-inl.h is
00398 // included, or there will be a compiler error.  This trick is to
00399 // prevent a user from accidentally including gtest-internal-inl.h in
00400 // his code.
00401 #define GTEST_IMPLEMENTATION_ 1

00406 // modification, are permitted provided that the following conditions are

00411 //     * Redistributions in binary form must reproduce the above
00412 // copyright notice, this list of conditions and the following disclaimer

00414 // distribution.

00416 // contributors may be used to endorse or promote products derived from
00417 // this software without specific prior written permission.

00419 // THIS SOFTWARE IS PROVIDED BY THE COPYRIGHT HOLDERS AND CONTRIBUTORS
00420 // "AS IS" AND ANY EXPRESS OR IMPLIED WARRANTIES, INCLUDING, BUT NOT
00421 // LIMITED TO, THE IMPLIED WARRANTIES OF MERCHANTABILITY AND FITNESS FOR
00422 // A PARTICULAR PURPOSE ARE DISCLAIMED. IN NO EVENT SHALL THE COPYRIGHT
00423 // OWNER OR CONTRIBUTORS BE LIABLE FOR ANY DIRECT, INDIRECT, INCIDENTAL,
00424 // SPECIAL, EXEMPLARY, OR CONSEQUENTIAL DAMAGES (INCLUDING, BUT NOT
00425 // LIMITED TO, PROCUREMENT OF SUBSTITUTE GOODS OR SERVICES; LOSS OF USE,
00426 // DATA, OR PROFITS; OR BUSINESS INTERRUPTION) HOWEVER CAUSED AND ON ANY

00428 // (INCLUDING NEGLIGENCE OR OTHERWISE) ARISING IN ANY WAY OUT OF THE USE
00429 // OF THIS SOFTWARE, EVEN IF ADVISED OF THE POSSIBILITY OF SUCH DAMAGE.

00431 // Utility functions and classes used by the Google C++ testing framework.
00432 //
00433 // Author: wan@google.com (Zhanyong Wan)
00434 //
00435 // This file contains purely Google Test's internal implementation.  Please
00436 // DO NOT #INCLUDE IT IN A USER PROGRAM.
00437 
00438 #ifndef GTEST_SRC_GTEST_INTERNAL_INL_H_
00439 #define GTEST_SRC_GTEST_INTERNAL_INL_H_
00440 
00441 // GTEST_IMPLEMENTATION_ is defined to 1 iff the current translation unit is
00442 // part of Google Test's implementation; otherwise it's undefined.
00443 #if !GTEST_IMPLEMENTATION_
00444 // A user is trying to include this from his code - just say no.
00445 # error "gtest-internal-inl.h is part of Google Test's internal implementation."
00446 # error "It must not be included except by Google Test itself."
00447 #endif  // GTEST_IMPLEMENTATION_
00448

00466 namespace testing {

00468 // Declares the flags.
00469 //
00470 // We don't want the users to modify this flag in the code, but want
00471 // Google Test's own unit tests to be able to access it. Therefore we
00472 // declare it here as opposed to in gtest.h.
00473 GTEST_DECLARE_bool_(death_test_use_fork);
00474 
00475 namespace internal {
00476 
00477 // The value of GetTestTypeId() as seen from within the Google Test
00478 // library.  This is solely for testing GetTestTypeId().
00479 GTEST_API_ extern const TypeId kTestTypeIdInGoogleTest;
00480 
00481 // Names of the flags (needed for parsing Google Test flags).
00482 const char kAlsoRunDisabledTestsFlag[] = "also_run_disabled_tests";
00483 const char kBreakOnFailureFlag[] = "break_on_failure";
00484 const char kCatchExceptionsFlag[] = "catch_exceptions";
00485 const char kColorFlag[] = "color";
00486 const char kFilterFlag[] = "filter";
00487 const char kListTestsFlag[] = "list_tests";
00488 const char kOutputFlag[] = "output";
00489 const char kPrintTimeFlag[] = "print_time";
00490 const char kRandomSeedFlag[] = "random_seed";
00491 const char kRepeatFlag[] = "repeat";
00492 const char kShuffleFlag[] = "shuffle";
00493 const char kStackTraceDepthFlag[] = "stack_trace_depth";
00494 const char kStreamResultToFlag[] = "stream_result_to";
00495 const char kThrowOnFailureFlag[] = "throw_on_failure";
00496 
00497 // A valid random seed must be in [1, kMaxRandomSeed].
00498 const int kMaxRandomSeed = 99999;
00499 
00500 // g_help_flag is true iff the --help flag or an equivalent form is
00501 // specified on the command line.
00502 GTEST_API_ extern bool g_help_flag;
00503 
00504 // Returns the current time in milliseconds.
00505 GTEST_API_ TimeInMillis GetTimeInMillis();
00506 
00507 // Returns true iff Google Test should use colors in the output.
00508 GTEST_API_ bool ShouldUseColor(bool stdout_is_tty);
00509 
00510 // Formats the given time in milliseconds as seconds.
00511 GTEST_API_ std::string FormatTimeInMillisAsSeconds(TimeInMillis ms);
00512 
00513 // Parses a string for an Int32 flag, in the form of "--flag=value".
00514 //
00515 // On success, stores the value of the flag in *value, and returns
00516 // true.  On failure, returns false without changing *value.
00517 GTEST_API_ bool ParseInt32Flag(
00518     const char* str, const char* flag, Int32* value);
00519 
00520 // Returns a random seed in range [1, kMaxRandomSeed] based on the
00521 // given --gtest_random_seed flag value.
00522 inline int GetRandomSeedFromFlag(Int32 random_seed_flag) {
00523   const unsigned int raw_seed = (random_seed_flag == 0) ?
00524       static_cast<unsigned int>(GetTimeInMillis()) :
00525       static_cast<unsigned int>(random_seed_flag);
00526 
00527   // Normalizes the actual seed to range [1, kMaxRandomSeed] such that
00528   // it's easy to type.
00529   const int normalized_seed =
00530       static_cast<int>((raw_seed - 1U) %
00531                        static_cast<unsigned int>(kMaxRandomSeed)) + 1;
00532   return normalized_seed;
00533 }
00534 
00535 // Returns the first valid random seed after 'seed'.  The behavior is
00536 // undefined if 'seed' is invalid.  The seed after kMaxRandomSeed is
00537 // considered to be 1.
00538 inline int GetNextRandomSeed(int seed) {
00539   GTEST_CHECK_(1 <= seed && seed <= kMaxRandomSeed)
00540       << "Invalid random seed " << seed << " - must be in [1, "
00541       << kMaxRandomSeed << "].";
00542   const int next_seed = seed + 1;
00543   return (next_seed > kMaxRandomSeed) ? 1 : next_seed;
00544 }
00545 
00546 // This class saves the values of all Google Test flags in its c'tor, and
00547 // restores them in its d'tor.
00548 class GTestFlagSaver {
00549  public:
00550   // The c'tor.
00551   GTestFlagSaver() {
00552     also_run_disabled_tests_ = GTEST_FLAG(also_run_disabled_tests);
00553     break_on_failure_ = GTEST_FLAG(break_on_failure);
00554     catch_exceptions_ = GTEST_FLAG(catch_exceptions);
00555     color_ = GTEST_FLAG(color);
00556     death_test_style_ = GTEST_FLAG(death_test_style);
00557     death_test_use_fork_ = GTEST_FLAG(death_test_use_fork);
00558     filter_ = GTEST_FLAG(filter);
00559     internal_run_death_test_ = GTEST_FLAG(internal_run_death_test);
00560     list_tests_ = GTEST_FLAG(list_tests);
00561     output_ = GTEST_FLAG(output);
00562     print_time_ = GTEST_FLAG(print_time);
00563     random_seed_ = GTEST_FLAG(random_seed);
00564     repeat_ = GTEST_FLAG(repeat);
00565     shuffle_ = GTEST_FLAG(shuffle);
00566     stack_trace_depth_ = GTEST_FLAG(stack_trace_depth);
00567     stream_result_to_ = GTEST_FLAG(stream_result_to);
00568     throw_on_failure_ = GTEST_FLAG(throw_on_failure);
00569   }
00570 
00571   // The d'tor is not virtual.  DO NOT INHERIT FROM THIS CLASS.
00572   ~GTestFlagSaver() {
00573     GTEST_FLAG(also_run_disabled_tests) = also_run_disabled_tests_;
00574     GTEST_FLAG(break_on_failure) = break_on_failure_;
00575     GTEST_FLAG(catch_exceptions) = catch_exceptions_;
00576     GTEST_FLAG(color) = color_;
00577     GTEST_FLAG(death_test_style) = death_test_style_;
00578     GTEST_FLAG(death_test_use_fork) = death_test_use_fork_;
00579     GTEST_FLAG(filter) = filter_;
00580     GTEST_FLAG(internal_run_death_test) = internal_run_death_test_;
00581     GTEST_FLAG(list_tests) = list_tests_;
00582     GTEST_FLAG(output) = output_;
00583     GTEST_FLAG(print_time) = print_time_;
00584     GTEST_FLAG(random_seed) = random_seed_;
00585     GTEST_FLAG(repeat) = repeat_;
00586     GTEST_FLAG(shuffle) = shuffle_;
00587     GTEST_FLAG(stack_trace_depth) = stack_trace_depth_;
00588     GTEST_FLAG(stream_result_to) = stream_result_to_;
00589     GTEST_FLAG(throw_on_failure) = throw_on_failure_;
00590   }
00591  private:
00592   // Fields for saving the original values of flags.
00593   bool also_run_disabled_tests_;
00594   bool break_on_failure_;
00595   bool catch_exceptions_;
00596   String color_;
00597   String death_test_style_;
00598   bool death_test_use_fork_;
00599   String filter_;
00600   String internal_run_death_test_;
00601   bool list_tests_;
00602   String output_;
00603   bool print_time_;
00604   bool pretty_;
00605   internal::Int32 random_seed_;
00606   internal::Int32 repeat_;
00607   bool shuffle_;
00608   internal::Int32 stack_trace_depth_;
00609   String stream_result_to_;
00610   bool throw_on_failure_;
00611 } GTEST_ATTRIBUTE_UNUSED_;
00612 
00613 // Converts a Unicode code point to a narrow string in UTF-8 encoding.
00614 // code_point parameter is of type UInt32 because wchar_t may not be
00615 // wide enough to contain a code point.
00616 // The output buffer str must containt at least 32 characters.
00617 // The function returns the address of the output buffer.
00618 // If the code_point is not a valid Unicode code point
00619 // (i.e. outside of Unicode range U+0 to U+10FFFF) it will be output
00620 // as '(Invalid Unicode 0xXXXXXXXX)'.
00621 GTEST_API_ char* CodePointToUtf8(UInt32 code_point, char* str);
00622 
00623 // Converts a wide string to a narrow string in UTF-8 encoding.
00624 // The wide string is assumed to have the following encoding:
00625 //   UTF-16 if sizeof(wchar_t) == 2 (on Windows, Cygwin, Symbian OS)
00626 //   UTF-32 if sizeof(wchar_t) == 4 (on Linux)
00627 // Parameter str points to a null-terminated wide string.
00628 // Parameter num_chars may additionally limit the number
00629 // of wchar_t characters processed. -1 is used when the entire string
00630 // should be processed.
00631 // If the string contains code points that are not valid Unicode code points
00632 // (i.e. outside of Unicode range U+0 to U+10FFFF) they will be output
00633 // as '(Invalid Unicode 0xXXXXXXXX)'. If the string is in UTF16 encoding
00634 // and contains invalid UTF-16 surrogate pairs, values in those pairs
00635 // will be encoded as individual Unicode characters from Basic Normal Plane.
00636 GTEST_API_ String WideStringToUtf8(const wchar_t* str, int num_chars);
00637 
00638 // Reads the GTEST_SHARD_STATUS_FILE environment variable, and creates the file
00639 // if the variable is present. If a file already exists at this location, this
00640 // function will write over it. If the variable is present, but the file cannot
00641 // be created, prints an error and exits.
00642 void WriteToShardStatusFileIfNeeded();
00643 
00644 // Checks whether sharding is enabled by examining the relevant
00645 // environment variable values. If the variables are present,
00646 // but inconsistent (e.g., shard_index >= total_shards), prints
00647 // an error and exits. If in_subprocess_for_death_test, sharding is
00648 // disabled because it must only be applied to the original test
00649 // process. Otherwise, we could filter out death tests we intended to execute.
00650 GTEST_API_ bool ShouldShard(const char* total_shards_str,
00651                             const char* shard_index_str,
00652                             bool in_subprocess_for_death_test);
00653 
00654 // Parses the environment variable var as an Int32. If it is unset,
00655 // returns default_val. If it is not an Int32, prints an error and
00656 // and aborts.
00657 GTEST_API_ Int32 Int32FromEnvOrDie(const char* env_var, Int32 default_val);
00658 
00659 // Given the total number of shards, the shard index, and the test id,
00660 // returns true iff the test should be run on this shard. The test id is
00661 // some arbitrary but unique non-negative integer assigned to each test
00662 // method. Assumes that 0 <= shard_index < total_shards.
00663 GTEST_API_ bool ShouldRunTestOnShard(
00664     int total_shards, int shard_index, int test_id);
00665 
00666 // STL container utilities.
00667 
00668 // Returns the number of elements in the given container that satisfy
00669 // the given predicate.
00670 template <class Container, typename Predicate>
00671 inline int CountIf(const Container& c, Predicate predicate) {
00672   // Implemented as an explicit loop since std::count_if() in libCstd on
00673   // Solaris has a non-standard signature.
00674   int count = 0;
00675   for (typename Container::const_iterator it = c.begin(); it != c.end(); ++it) {
00676     if (predicate(*it))
00677       ++count;
00678   }
00679   return count;
00680 }
00681 
00682 // Applies a function/functor to each element in the container.
00683 template <class Container, typename Functor>
00684 void ForEach(const Container& c, Functor functor) {
00685   std::for_each(c.begin(), c.end(), functor);
00686 }
00687 
00688 // Returns the i-th element of the vector, or default_value if i is not
00689 // in range [0, v.size()).
00690 template <typename E>
00691 inline E GetElementOr(const std::vector<E>& v, int i, E default_value) {
00692   return (i < 0 || i >= static_cast<int>(v.size())) ? default_value : v[i];
00693 }
00694 
00695 // Performs an in-place shuffle of a range of the vector's elements.
00696 // 'begin' and 'end' are element indices as an STL-style range;
00697 // i.e. [begin, end) are shuffled, where 'end' == size() means to
00698 // shuffle to the end of the vector.
00699 template <typename E>
00700 void ShuffleRange(internal::Random* random, int begin, int end,
00701                   std::vector<E>* v) {
00702   const int size = static_cast<int>(v->size());
00703   GTEST_CHECK_(0 <= begin && begin <= size)
00704       << "Invalid shuffle range start " << begin << ": must be in range [0, "
00705       << size << "].";
00706   GTEST_CHECK_(begin <= end && end <= size)
00707       << "Invalid shuffle range finish " << end << ": must be in range ["
00708       << begin << ", " << size << "].";
00709 
00710   // Fisher-Yates shuffle, from
00711   // http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fisher-Yates_shuffle
00712   for (int range_width = end - begin; range_width >= 2; range_width--) {
00713     const int last_in_range = begin + range_width - 1;
00714     const int selected = begin + random->Generate(range_width);
00715     std::swap((*v)[selected], (*v)[last_in_range]);
00716   }
00717 }
00718 
00719 // Performs an in-place shuffle of the vector's elements.
00720 template <typename E>
00721 inline void Shuffle(internal::Random* random, std::vector<E>* v) {
00722   ShuffleRange(random, 0, static_cast<int>(v->size()), v);
00723 }
00724 
00725 // A function for deleting an object.  Handy for being used as a
00726 // functor.
00727 template <typename T>
00728 static void Delete(T* x) {
00729   delete x;
00730 }
00731 
00732 // A predicate that checks the key of a TestProperty against a known key.
00733 //
00734 // TestPropertyKeyIs is copyable.
00735 class TestPropertyKeyIs {
00736  public:
00737   // Constructor.
00738   //
00739   // TestPropertyKeyIs has NO default constructor.
00740   explicit TestPropertyKeyIs(const char* key)
00741       : key_(key) {}
00742 
00743   // Returns true iff the test name of test property matches on key_.
00744   bool operator()(const TestProperty& test_property) const {
00745     return String(test_property.key()).Compare(key_) == 0;
00746   }
00747 
00748  private:
00749   String key_;
00750 };
00751 
00752 // Class UnitTestOptions.
00753 //
00754 // This class contains functions for processing options the user
00755 // specifies when running the tests.  It has only static members.
00756 //
00757 // In most cases, the user can specify an option using either an
00758 // environment variable or a command line flag.  E.g. you can set the
00759 // test filter using either GTEST_FILTER or --gtest_filter.  If both
00760 // the variable and the flag are present, the latter overrides the
00761 // former.
00762 class GTEST_API_ UnitTestOptions {
00763  public:
00764   // Functions for processing the gtest_output flag.
00765 
00766   // Returns the output format, or "" for normal printed output.
00767   static String GetOutputFormat();
00768 
00769   // Returns the absolute path of the requested output file, or the
00770   // default (test_detail.xml in the original working directory) if
00771   // none was explicitly specified.
00772   static String GetAbsolutePathToOutputFile();
00773 
00774   // Functions for processing the gtest_filter flag.
00775 
00776   // Returns true iff the wildcard pattern matches the string.  The
00777   // first ':' or '\0' character in pattern marks the end of it.
00778   //
00779   // This recursive algorithm isn't very efficient, but is clear and
00780   // works well enough for matching test names, which are short.
00781   static bool PatternMatchesString(const char *pattern, const char *str);
00782 
00783   // Returns true iff the user-specified filter matches the test case
00784   // name and the test name.
00785   static bool FilterMatchesTest(const String &test_case_name,
00786                                 const String &test_name);
00787 
00788 #if GTEST_OS_WINDOWS
00789   // Function for supporting the gtest_catch_exception flag.
00790 
00791   // Returns EXCEPTION_EXECUTE_HANDLER if Google Test should handle the
00792   // given SEH exception, or EXCEPTION_CONTINUE_SEARCH otherwise.
00793   // This function is useful as an __except condition.
00794   static int GTestShouldProcessSEH(DWORD exception_code);
00795 #endif  // GTEST_OS_WINDOWS
00796 
00797   // Returns true if "name" matches the ':' separated list of glob-style
00798   // filters in "filter".
00799   static bool MatchesFilter(const String& name, const char* filter);
00800 };
00801 
00802 // Returns the current application's name, removing directory path if that
00803 // is present.  Used by UnitTestOptions::GetOutputFile.
00804 GTEST_API_ FilePath GetCurrentExecutableName();
00805 
00806 // The role interface for getting the OS stack trace as a string.
00807 class OsStackTraceGetterInterface {
00808  public:
00809   OsStackTraceGetterInterface() {}
00810   virtual ~OsStackTraceGetterInterface() {}
00811 
00812   // Returns the current OS stack trace as a String.  Parameters:
00813   //
00814   //   max_depth  - the maximum number of stack frames to be included
00815   //                in the trace.
00816   //   skip_count - the number of top frames to be skipped; doesn't count
00817   //                against max_depth.
00818   virtual String CurrentStackTrace(int max_depth, int skip_count) = 0;
00819 
00820   // UponLeavingGTest() should be called immediately before Google Test calls
00821   // user code. It saves some information about the current stack that
00822   // CurrentStackTrace() will use to find and hide Google Test stack frames.
00823   virtual void UponLeavingGTest() = 0;
00824 
00825  private:
00826   GTEST_DISALLOW_COPY_AND_ASSIGN_(OsStackTraceGetterInterface);
00827 };
00828 
00829 // A working implementation of the OsStackTraceGetterInterface interface.
00830 class OsStackTraceGetter : public OsStackTraceGetterInterface {
00831  public:
00832   OsStackTraceGetter() : caller_frame_(NULL) {}
00833   virtual String CurrentStackTrace(int max_depth, int skip_count);
00834   virtual void UponLeavingGTest();
00835 
00836   // This string is inserted in place of stack frames that are part of
00837   // Google Test's implementation.
00838   static const char* const kElidedFramesMarker;
00839 
00840  private:
00841   Mutex mutex_;  // protects all internal state
00842 
00843   // We save the stack frame below the frame that calls user code.
00844   // We do this because the address of the frame immediately below
00845   // the user code changes between the call to UponLeavingGTest()
00846   // and any calls to CurrentStackTrace() from within the user code.
00847   void* caller_frame_;
00848 
00849   GTEST_DISALLOW_COPY_AND_ASSIGN_(OsStackTraceGetter);
00850 };
00851 
00852 // Information about a Google Test trace point.
00853 struct TraceInfo {
00854   const char* file;
00855   int line;
00856   String message;
00857 };
00858 
00859 // This is the default global test part result reporter used in UnitTestImpl.
00860 // This class should only be used by UnitTestImpl.
00861 class DefaultGlobalTestPartResultReporter
00862   : public TestPartResultReporterInterface {
00863  public:
00864   explicit DefaultGlobalTestPartResultReporter(UnitTestImpl* unit_test);
00865   // Implements the TestPartResultReporterInterface. Reports the test part
00866   // result in the current test.
00867   virtual void ReportTestPartResult(const TestPartResult& result);
00868 
00869  private:
00870   UnitTestImpl* const unit_test_;
00871 
00872   GTEST_DISALLOW_COPY_AND_ASSIGN_(DefaultGlobalTestPartResultReporter);
00873 };
00874 
00875 // This is the default per thread test part result reporter used in
00876 // UnitTestImpl. This class should only be used by UnitTestImpl.
00877 class DefaultPerThreadTestPartResultReporter
00878     : public TestPartResultReporterInterface {
00879  public:
00880   explicit DefaultPerThreadTestPartResultReporter(UnitTestImpl* unit_test);
00881   // Implements the TestPartResultReporterInterface. The implementation just
00882   // delegates to the current global test part result reporter of *unit_test_.
00883   virtual void ReportTestPartResult(const TestPartResult& result);
00884 
00885  private:
00886   UnitTestImpl* const unit_test_;
00887 
00888   GTEST_DISALLOW_COPY_AND_ASSIGN_(DefaultPerThreadTestPartResultReporter);
00889 };
00890 
00891 // The private implementation of the UnitTest class.  We don't protect
00892 // the methods under a mutex, as this class is not accessible by a
00893 // user and the UnitTest class that delegates work to this class does
00894 // proper locking.
00895 class GTEST_API_ UnitTestImpl {
00896  public:
00897   explicit UnitTestImpl(UnitTest* parent);
00898   virtual ~UnitTestImpl();
00899 
00900   // There are two different ways to register your own TestPartResultReporter.
00901   // You can register your own repoter to listen either only for test results
00902   // from the current thread or for results from all threads.
00903   // By default, each per-thread test result repoter just passes a new
00904   // TestPartResult to the global test result reporter, which registers the
00905   // test part result for the currently running test.
00906 
00907   // Returns the global test part result reporter.
00908   TestPartResultReporterInterface* GetGlobalTestPartResultReporter();
00909 
00910   // Sets the global test part result reporter.
00911   void SetGlobalTestPartResultReporter(
00912       TestPartResultReporterInterface* reporter);
00913 
00914   // Returns the test part result reporter for the current thread.
00915   TestPartResultReporterInterface* GetTestPartResultReporterForCurrentThread();
00916 
00917   // Sets the test part result reporter for the current thread.
00918   void SetTestPartResultReporterForCurrentThread(
00919       TestPartResultReporterInterface* reporter);
00920 
00921   // Gets the number of successful test cases.
00922   int successful_test_case_count() const;
00923 
00924   // Gets the number of failed test cases.
00925   int failed_test_case_count() const;
00926 
00927   // Gets the number of all test cases.
00928   int total_test_case_count() const;
00929 
00930   // Gets the number of all test cases that contain at least one test
00931   // that should run.
00932   int test_case_to_run_count() const;
00933 
00934   // Gets the number of successful tests.
00935   int successful_test_count() const;
00936 
00937   // Gets the number of failed tests.
00938   int failed_test_count() const;
00939 
00940   // Gets the number of disabled tests.
00941   int disabled_test_count() const;
00942 
00943   // Gets the number of all tests.
00944   int total_test_count() const;
00945 
00946   // Gets the number of tests that should run.
00947   int test_to_run_count() const;
00948 
00949   // Gets the elapsed time, in milliseconds.
00950   TimeInMillis elapsed_time() const { return elapsed_time_; }
00951 
00952   // Returns true iff the unit test passed (i.e. all test cases passed).
00953   bool Passed() const { return !Failed(); }
00954 
00955   // Returns true iff the unit test failed (i.e. some test case failed
00956   // or something outside of all tests failed).
00957   bool Failed() const {
00958     return failed_test_case_count() > 0 || ad_hoc_test_result()->Failed();
00959   }
00960 
00961   // Gets the i-th test case among all the test cases. i can range from 0 to
00962   // total_test_case_count() - 1. If i is not in that range, returns NULL.
00963   const TestCase* GetTestCase(int i) const {
00964     const int index = GetElementOr(test_case_indices_, i, -1);
00965     return index < 0 ? NULL : test_cases_[i];
00966   }
00967 
00968   // Gets the i-th test case among all the test cases. i can range from 0 to
00969   // total_test_case_count() - 1. If i is not in that range, returns NULL.
00970   TestCase* GetMutableTestCase(int i) {
00971     const int index = GetElementOr(test_case_indices_, i, -1);
00972     return index < 0 ? NULL : test_cases_[index];
00973   }
00974 
00975   // Provides access to the event listener list.
00976   TestEventListeners* listeners() { return &listeners_; }
00977 
00978   // Returns the TestResult for the test that's currently running, or
00979   // the TestResult for the ad hoc test if no test is running.
00980   TestResult* current_test_result();
00981 
00982   // Returns the TestResult for the ad hoc test.
00983   const TestResult* ad_hoc_test_result() const { return &ad_hoc_test_result_; }
00984 
00985   // Sets the OS stack trace getter.
00986   //
00987   // Does nothing if the input and the current OS stack trace getter
00988   // are the same; otherwise, deletes the old getter and makes the
00989   // input the current getter.
00990   void set_os_stack_trace_getter(OsStackTraceGetterInterface* getter);
00991 
00992   // Returns the current OS stack trace getter if it is not NULL;
00993   // otherwise, creates an OsStackTraceGetter, makes it the current
00994   // getter, and returns it.
00995   OsStackTraceGetterInterface* os_stack_trace_getter();
00996 
00997   // Returns the current OS stack trace as a String.
00998   //
00999   // The maximum number of stack frames to be included is specified by
01000   // the gtest_stack_trace_depth flag.  The skip_count parameter
01001   // specifies the number of top frames to be skipped, which doesn't
01002   // count against the number of frames to be included.
01003   //
01004   // For example, if Foo() calls Bar(), which in turn calls
01005   // CurrentOsStackTraceExceptTop(1), Foo() will be included in the
01006   // trace but Bar() and CurrentOsStackTraceExceptTop() won't.
01007   String CurrentOsStackTraceExceptTop(int skip_count);
01008 
01009   // Finds and returns a TestCase with the given name.  If one doesn't
01010   // exist, creates one and returns it.
01011   //
01012   // Arguments:
01013   //
01014   //   test_case_name: name of the test case
01015   //   type_param:     the name of the test's type parameter, or NULL if
01016   //                   this is not a typed or a type-parameterized test.
01017   //   set_up_tc:      pointer to the function that sets up the test case
01018   //   tear_down_tc:   pointer to the function that tears down the test case
01019   TestCase* GetTestCase(const char* test_case_name,
01020                         const char* type_param,
01021                         Test::SetUpTestCaseFunc set_up_tc,
01022                         Test::TearDownTestCaseFunc tear_down_tc);
01023 
01024   // Adds a TestInfo to the unit test.
01025   //
01026   // Arguments:
01027   //
01028   //   set_up_tc:    pointer to the function that sets up the test case
01029   //   tear_down_tc: pointer to the function that tears down the test case
01030   //   test_info:    the TestInfo object
01031   void AddTestInfo(Test::SetUpTestCaseFunc set_up_tc,
01032                    Test::TearDownTestCaseFunc tear_down_tc,
01033                    TestInfo* test_info) {
01034     // In order to support thread-safe death tests, we need to
01035     // remember the original working directory when the test program
01036     // was first invoked.  We cannot do this in RUN_ALL_TESTS(), as
01037     // the user may have changed the current directory before calling
01038     // RUN_ALL_TESTS().  Therefore we capture the current directory in
01039     // AddTestInfo(), which is called to register a TEST or TEST_F
01040     // before main() is reached.
01041     if (original_working_dir_.IsEmpty()) {
01042       original_working_dir_.Set(FilePath::GetCurrentDir());
01043       GTEST_CHECK_(!original_working_dir_.IsEmpty())
01044           << "Failed to get the current working directory.";
01045     }
01046 
01047     GetTestCase(test_info->test_case_name(),
01048                 test_info->type_param(),
01049                 set_up_tc,
01050                 tear_down_tc)->AddTestInfo(test_info);
01051   }
01052 
01053 #if GTEST_HAS_PARAM_TEST
01054   // Returns ParameterizedTestCaseRegistry object used to keep track of
01055   // value-parameterized tests and instantiate and register them.
01056   internal::ParameterizedTestCaseRegistry& parameterized_test_registry() {
01057     return parameterized_test_registry_;
01058   }
01059 #endif  // GTEST_HAS_PARAM_TEST
01060 
01061   // Sets the TestCase object for the test that's currently running.
01062   void set_current_test_case(TestCase* a_current_test_case) {
01063     current_test_case_ = a_current_test_case;
01064   }
01065 
01066   // Sets the TestInfo object for the test that's currently running.  If
01067   // current_test_info is NULL, the assertion results will be stored in
01068   // ad_hoc_test_result_.
01069   void set_current_test_info(TestInfo* a_current_test_info) {
01070     current_test_info_ = a_current_test_info;
01071   }
01072 
01073   // Registers all parameterized tests defined using TEST_P and
01074   // INSTANTIATE_TEST_CASE_P, creating regular tests for each test/parameter
01075   // combination. This method can be called more then once; it has guards
01076   // protecting from registering the tests more then once.  If
01077   // value-parameterized tests are disabled, RegisterParameterizedTests is
01078   // present but does nothing.
01079   void RegisterParameterizedTests();
01080 
01081   // Runs all tests in this UnitTest object, prints the result, and
01082   // returns true if all tests are successful.  If any exception is
01083   // thrown during a test, this test is considered to be failed, but
01084   // the rest of the tests will still be run.
01085   bool RunAllTests();
01086 
01087   // Clears the results of all tests, except the ad hoc tests.
01088   void ClearNonAdHocTestResult() {
01089     ForEach(test_cases_, TestCase::ClearTestCaseResult);
01090   }
01091 
01092   // Clears the results of ad-hoc test assertions.
01093   void ClearAdHocTestResult() {
01094     ad_hoc_test_result_.Clear();
01095   }
01096 
01097   enum ReactionToSharding {
01098     HONOR_SHARDING_PROTOCOL,
01099     IGNORE_SHARDING_PROTOCOL
01100   };
01101 
01102   // Matches the full name of each test against the user-specified
01103   // filter to decide whether the test should run, then records the
01104   // result in each TestCase and TestInfo object.
01105   // If shard_tests == HONOR_SHARDING_PROTOCOL, further filters tests
01106   // based on sharding variables in the environment.
01107   // Returns the number of tests that should run.
01108   int FilterTests(ReactionToSharding shard_tests);
01109 
01110   // Prints the names of the tests matching the user-specified filter flag.
01111   void ListTestsMatchingFilter();
01112 
01113   const TestCase* current_test_case() const { return current_test_case_; }
01114   TestInfo* current_test_info() { return current_test_info_; }
01115   const TestInfo* current_test_info() const { return current_test_info_; }
01116 
01117   // Returns the vector of environments that need to be set-up/torn-down
01118   // before/after the tests are run.
01119   std::vector<Environment*>& environments() { return environments_; }
01120 
01121   // Getters for the per-thread Google Test trace stack.
01122   std::vector<TraceInfo>& gtest_trace_stack() {
01123     return *(gtest_trace_stack_.pointer());
01124   }
01125   const std::vector<TraceInfo>& gtest_trace_stack() const {
01126     return gtest_trace_stack_.get();
01127   }
01128 
01129 #if GTEST_HAS_DEATH_TEST
01130   void InitDeathTestSubprocessControlInfo() {
01131     internal_run_death_test_flag_.reset(ParseInternalRunDeathTestFlag());
01132   }
01133   // Returns a pointer to the parsed --gtest_internal_run_death_test
01134   // flag, or NULL if that flag was not specified.
01135   // This information is useful only in a death test child process.
01136   // Must not be called before a call to InitGoogleTest.
01137   const InternalRunDeathTestFlag* internal_run_death_test_flag() const {
01138     return internal_run_death_test_flag_.get();
01139   }
01140 
01141   // Returns a pointer to the current death test factory.
01142   internal::DeathTestFactory* death_test_factory() {
01143     return death_test_factory_.get();
01144   }
01145 
01146   void SuppressTestEventsIfInSubprocess();
01147 
01148   friend class ReplaceDeathTestFactory;
01149 #endif  // GTEST_HAS_DEATH_TEST
01150 
01151   // Initializes the event listener performing XML output as specified by
01152   // UnitTestOptions. Must not be called before InitGoogleTest.
01153   void ConfigureXmlOutput();
01154 
01155 #if GTEST_CAN_STREAM_RESULTS_
01156   // Initializes the event listener for streaming test results to a socket.
01157   // Must not be called before InitGoogleTest.
01158   void ConfigureStreamingOutput();
01159 #endif
01160 
01161   // Performs initialization dependent upon flag values obtained in
01162   // ParseGoogleTestFlagsOnly.  Is called from InitGoogleTest after the call to
01163   // ParseGoogleTestFlagsOnly.  In case a user neglects to call InitGoogleTest
01164   // this function is also called from RunAllTests.  Since this function can be
01165   // called more than once, it has to be idempotent.
01166   void PostFlagParsingInit();
01167 
01168   // Gets the random seed used at the start of the current test iteration.
01169   int random_seed() const { return random_seed_; }
01170 
01171   // Gets the random number generator.
01172   internal::Random* random() { return &random_; }
01173 
01174   // Shuffles all test cases, and the tests within each test case,
01175   // making sure that death tests are still run first.
01176   void ShuffleTests();
01177 
01178   // Restores the test cases and tests to their order before the first shuffle.
01179   void UnshuffleTests();
01180 
01181   // Returns the value of GTEST_FLAG(catch_exceptions) at the moment
01182   // UnitTest::Run() starts.
01183   bool catch_exceptions() const { return catch_exceptions_; }
01184 
01185  private:
01186   friend class ::testing::UnitTest;
01187 
01188   // Used by UnitTest::Run() to capture the state of
01189   // GTEST_FLAG(catch_exceptions) at the moment it starts.
01190   void set_catch_exceptions(bool value) { catch_exceptions_ = value; }
01191 
01192   // The UnitTest object that owns this implementation object.
01193   UnitTest* const parent_;
01194 
01195   // The working directory when the first TEST() or TEST_F() was
01196   // executed.
01197   internal::FilePath original_working_dir_;
01198 
01199   // The default test part result reporters.
01200   DefaultGlobalTestPartResultReporter default_global_test_part_result_reporter_;
01201   DefaultPerThreadTestPartResultReporter
01202       default_per_thread_test_part_result_reporter_;
01203 
01204   // Points to (but doesn't own) the global test part result reporter.
01205   TestPartResultReporterInterface* global_test_part_result_repoter_;
01206 
01207   // Protects read and write access to global_test_part_result_reporter_.
01208   internal::Mutex global_test_part_result_reporter_mutex_;
01209 
01210   // Points to (but doesn't own) the per-thread test part result reporter.
01211   internal::ThreadLocal<TestPartResultReporterInterface*>
01212       per_thread_test_part_result_reporter_;
01213 
01214   // The vector of environments that need to be set-up/torn-down
01215   // before/after the tests are run.
01216   std::vector<Environment*> environments_;
01217 
01218   // The vector of TestCases in their original order.  It owns the
01219   // elements in the vector.
01220   std::vector<TestCase*> test_cases_;
01221 
01222   // Provides a level of indirection for the test case list to allow
01223   // easy shuffling and restoring the test case order.  The i-th
01224   // element of this vector is the index of the i-th test case in the
01225   // shuffled order.
01226   std::vector<int> test_case_indices_;
01227 
01228 #if GTEST_HAS_PARAM_TEST
01229   // ParameterizedTestRegistry object used to register value-parameterized
01230   // tests.
01231   internal::ParameterizedTestCaseRegistry parameterized_test_registry_;
01232 
01233   // Indicates whether RegisterParameterizedTests() has been called already.
01234   bool parameterized_tests_registered_;
01235 #endif  // GTEST_HAS_PARAM_TEST
01236 
01237   // Index of the last death test case registered.  Initially -1.
01238   int last_death_test_case_;
01239 
01240   // This points to the TestCase for the currently running test.  It
01241   // changes as Google Test goes through one test case after another.
01242   // When no test is running, this is set to NULL and Google Test
01243   // stores assertion results in ad_hoc_test_result_.  Initially NULL.
01244   TestCase* current_test_case_;
01245 
01246   // This points to the TestInfo for the currently running test.  It
01247   // changes as Google Test goes through one test after another.  When
01248   // no test is running, this is set to NULL and Google Test stores
01249   // assertion results in ad_hoc_test_result_.  Initially NULL.
01250   TestInfo* current_test_info_;
01251 
01252   // Normally, a user only writes assertions inside a TEST or TEST_F,
01253   // or inside a function called by a TEST or TEST_F.  Since Google
01254   // Test keeps track of which test is current running, it can
01255   // associate such an assertion with the test it belongs to.
01256   //
01257   // If an assertion is encountered when no TEST or TEST_F is running,
01258   // Google Test attributes the assertion result to an imaginary "ad hoc"
01259   // test, and records the result in ad_hoc_test_result_.
01260   TestResult ad_hoc_test_result_;
01261 
01262   // The list of event listeners that can be used to track events inside
01263   // Google Test.
01264   TestEventListeners listeners_;
01265 
01266   // The OS stack trace getter.  Will be deleted when the UnitTest
01267   // object is destructed.  By default, an OsStackTraceGetter is used,
01268   // but the user can set this field to use a custom getter if that is
01269   // desired.
01270   OsStackTraceGetterInterface* os_stack_trace_getter_;
01271 
01272   // True iff PostFlagParsingInit() has been called.
01273   bool post_flag_parse_init_performed_;
01274 
01275   // The random number seed used at the beginning of the test run.
01276   int random_seed_;
01277 
01278   // Our random number generator.
01279   internal::Random random_;
01280 
01281   // How long the test took to run, in milliseconds.
01282   TimeInMillis elapsed_time_;
01283 
01284 #if GTEST_HAS_DEATH_TEST
01285   // The decomposed components of the gtest_internal_run_death_test flag,
01286   // parsed when RUN_ALL_TESTS is called.
01287   internal::scoped_ptr<InternalRunDeathTestFlag> internal_run_death_test_flag_;
01288   internal::scoped_ptr<internal::DeathTestFactory> death_test_factory_;
01289 #endif  // GTEST_HAS_DEATH_TEST
01290 
01291   // A per-thread stack of traces created by the SCOPED_TRACE() macro.
01292   internal::ThreadLocal<std::vector<TraceInfo> > gtest_trace_stack_;
01293 
01294   // The value of GTEST_FLAG(catch_exceptions) at the moment RunAllTests()
01295   // starts.
01296   bool catch_exceptions_;
01297 
01298   GTEST_DISALLOW_COPY_AND_ASSIGN_(UnitTestImpl);
01299 };  // class UnitTestImpl
01300 
01301 // Convenience function for accessing the global UnitTest
01302 // implementation object.
01303 inline UnitTestImpl* GetUnitTestImpl() {
01304   return UnitTest::GetInstance()->impl();
01305 }

01310 // expression matcher.
01311 GTEST_API_ bool IsInSet(char ch, const char* str);
01312 GTEST_API_ bool IsAsciiDigit(char ch);
01313 GTEST_API_ bool IsAsciiPunct(char ch);
01314 GTEST_API_ bool IsRepeat(char ch);
01315 GTEST_API_ bool IsAsciiWhiteSpace(char ch);
01316 GTEST_API_ bool IsAsciiWordChar(char ch);
01317 GTEST_API_ bool IsValidEscape(char ch);
01318 GTEST_API_ bool AtomMatchesChar(bool escaped, char pattern, char ch);
01319 GTEST_API_ bool ValidateRegex(const char* regex);
01320 GTEST_API_ bool MatchRegexAtHead(const char* regex, const char* str);
01321 GTEST_API_ bool MatchRepetitionAndRegexAtHead(
01322     bool escaped, char ch, char repeat, const char* regex, const char* str);
01323 GTEST_API_ bool MatchRegexAnywhere(const char* regex, const char* str);

01325 #endif  // GTEST_USES_SIMPLE_RE

01328 // other parts of Google Test.
01329 GTEST_API_ void ParseGoogleTestFlagsOnly(int* argc, char** argv);
01330 GTEST_API_ void ParseGoogleTestFlagsOnly(int* argc, wchar_t** argv);

01332 #if GTEST_HAS_DEATH_TEST
01333 
01334 // Returns the message describing the last system error, regardless of the
01335 // platform.
01336 GTEST_API_ String GetLastErrnoDescription();
01337 
01338 # if GTEST_OS_WINDOWS
01339 // Provides leak-safe Windows kernel handle ownership.
01340 class AutoHandle {
01341  public:
01342   AutoHandle() : handle_(INVALID_HANDLE_VALUE) {}
01343   explicit AutoHandle(HANDLE handle) : handle_(handle) {}
01344 
01345   ~AutoHandle() { Reset(); }
01346 
01347   HANDLE Get() const { return handle_; }
01348   void Reset() { Reset(INVALID_HANDLE_VALUE); }
01349   void Reset(HANDLE handle) {
01350     if (handle != handle_) {
01351       if (handle_ != INVALID_HANDLE_VALUE)
01352         ::CloseHandle(handle_);
01353       handle_ = handle;
01354     }
01355   }
01356 
01357  private:
01358   HANDLE handle_;
01359 
01360   GTEST_DISALLOW_COPY_AND_ASSIGN_(AutoHandle);
01361 };
01362 # endif  // GTEST_OS_WINDOWS
01363 
01364 // Attempts to parse a string into a positive integer pointed to by the
01365 // number parameter.  Returns true if that is possible.
01366 // GTEST_HAS_DEATH_TEST implies that we have ::std::string, so we can use
01367 // it here.
01368 template <typename Integer>
01369 bool ParseNaturalNumber(const ::std::string& str, Integer* number) {
01370   // Fail fast if the given string does not begin with a digit;
01371   // this bypasses strtoXXX's "optional leading whitespace and plus
01372   // or minus sign" semantics, which are undesirable here.
01373   if (str.empty() || !IsDigit(str[0])) {
01374     return false;
01375   }
01376   errno = 0;
01377 
01378   char* end;
01379   // BiggestConvertible is the largest integer type that system-provided
01380   // string-to-number conversion routines can return.
01381 
01382 # if GTEST_OS_WINDOWS && !defined(__GNUC__)
01383 
01384   // MSVC and C++ Builder define __int64 instead of the standard long long.
01385   typedef unsigned __int64 BiggestConvertible;
01386   const BiggestConvertible parsed = _strtoui64(str.c_str(), &end, 10);
01387 
01388 # else
01389 
01390   typedef unsigned long long BiggestConvertible;  // NOLINT
01391   const BiggestConvertible parsed = strtoull(str.c_str(), &end, 10);
01392 
01393 # endif  // GTEST_OS_WINDOWS && !defined(__GNUC__)
01394 
01395   const bool parse_success = *end == '\0' && errno == 0;
01396 
01397   // TODO(vladl@google.com): Convert this to compile time assertion when it is
01398   // available.
01399   GTEST_CHECK_(sizeof(Integer) <= sizeof(parsed));
01400 
01401   const Integer result = static_cast<Integer>(parsed);
01402   if (parse_success && static_cast<BiggestConvertible>(result) == parsed) {
01403     *number = result;
01404     return true;
01405   }
01406   return false;
01407 }
01408 #endif  // GTEST_HAS_DEATH_TEST
01409 
01410 // TestResult contains some private methods that should be hidden from
01411 // Google Test user but are required for testing. This class allow our tests
01412 // to access them.
01413 //
01414 // This class is supplied only for the purpose of testing Google Test's own
01415 // constructs. Do not use it in user tests, either directly or indirectly.
01416 class TestResultAccessor {
01417  public:
01418   static void RecordProperty(TestResult* test_result,
01419                              const TestProperty& property) {
01420     test_result->RecordProperty(property);
01421   }
01422 
01423   static void ClearTestPartResults(TestResult* test_result) {
01424     test_result->ClearTestPartResults();
01425   }
01426 
01427   static const std::vector<testing::TestPartResult>& test_part_results(
01428       const TestResult& test_result) {
01429     return test_result.test_part_results();
01430   }
01431 };
01432 
01433 }  // namespace internal
01434 }  // namespace testing
01435 
01436 #endif  // GTEST_SRC_GTEST_INTERNAL_INL_H_
01437 #undef GTEST_IMPLEMENTATION_
01438 
01439 #if GTEST_OS_WINDOWS
01440 # define vsnprintf _vsnprintf
01441 #endif  // GTEST_OS_WINDOWS
01442

01447 using internal::GetElementOr;
01448 using internal::Shuffle;

01450 // Constants.
01451 
01452 // A test whose test case name or test name matches this filter is
01453 // disabled and not run.
01454 static const char kDisableTestFilter[] = "DISABLED_*:*/DISABLED_*";
01455 
01456 // A test case whose name matches this filter is considered a death
01457 // test case and will be run before test cases whose name doesn't
01458 // match this filter.
01459 static const char kDeathTestCaseFilter[] = "*DeathTest:*DeathTest/*";
01460 
01461 // A test filter that matches everything.
01462 static const char kUniversalFilter[] = "*";
01463 
01464 // The default output file for XML output.
01465 static const char kDefaultOutputFile[] = "test_detail.xml";
01466 
01467 // The environment variable name for the test shard index.
01468 static const char kTestShardIndex[] = "GTEST_SHARD_INDEX";
01469 // The environment variable name for the total number of test shards.
01470 static const char kTestTotalShards[] = "GTEST_TOTAL_SHARDS";
01471 // The environment variable name for the test shard status file.
01472 static const char kTestShardStatusFile[] = "GTEST_SHARD_STATUS_FILE";

01477 // stack trace.
01478 const char kStackTraceMarker[] = "\nStack trace:\n";
01479 
01480 // g_help_flag is true iff the --help flag or an equivalent form is
01481 // specified on the command line.
01482 bool g_help_flag = false;

01494     "True iff a failed assertion should be a debugger break-point.");

01500     " should catch exceptions and treat them as test failures.");

01503     color,
01504     internal::StringFromGTestEnv("color", "auto"),
01505     "Whether to use colors in the output.  Valid values: yes, no, "
01506     "and auto.  'auto' means to use colors if the output is "
01507     "being sent to a terminal and the TERM environment variable "
01508     "is set to xterm, xterm-color, xterm-256color, linux or cygwin.");
01509

01511     filter,
01512     internal::StringFromGTestEnv("filter", kUniversalFilter),
01513     "A colon-separated list of glob (not regex) patterns "
01514     "for filtering the tests to run, optionally followed by a "
01515     "'-' and a : separated list of negative patterns (tests to "
01516     "exclude).  A test is run if it matches one of the positive "
01517     "patterns and does not match any of the negative patterns.");

01520                    "List all tests without running them.");

01525     "A format (currently must be \"xml\"), optionally followed "
01526     "by a colon and an output file name or directory. A directory "
01527     "is indicated by a trailing pathname separator. "
01528     "Examples: \"xml:filename.xml\", \"xml::directoryname/\". "
01529     "If a directory is specified, output files will be created "
01530     "within that directory, with file-names based on the test "
01531     "executable's name and, if necessary, made unique by adding "
01532     "digits.");

01573     "test results. Example: \"localhost:555\". The flag is effective only on "
01574     "Linux.");

01576 GTEST_DEFINE_bool_(
01577     throw_on_failure,
01578     internal::BoolFromGTestEnv("throw_on_failure", false),

01580     "if exceptions are enabled or exit the program with a non-zero code "
01581     "otherwise.");
01582 
01583 namespace internal {
01584 
01585 // Generates a random number from [0, range), using a Linear
01586 // Congruential Generator (LCG).  Crashes if 'range' is 0 or greater
01587 // than kMaxRange.
01588 UInt32 Random::Generate(UInt32 range) {
01589   // These constants are the same as are used in glibc's rand(3).
01590   state_ = (1103515245U*state_ + 12345U) % kMaxRange;
01591 
01592   GTEST_CHECK_(range > 0)
01593       << "Cannot generate a number in the range [0, 0).";
01594   GTEST_CHECK_(range <= kMaxRange)
01595       << "Generation of a number in [0, " << range << ") was requested, "
01596       << "but this can only generate numbers in [0, " << kMaxRange << ").";
01597 
01598   // Converting via modulus introduces a bit of downward bias, but
01599   // it's simple, and a linear congruential generator isn't too good
01600   // to begin with.
01601   return state_ % range;
01602 }
01603 
01604 // GTestIsInitialized() returns true iff the user has initialized
01605 // Google Test.  Useful for catching the user mistake of not initializing
01606 // Google Test before calling RUN_ALL_TESTS().
01607 //
01608 // A user must call testing::InitGoogleTest() to initialize Google
01609 // Test.  g_init_gtest_count is set to the number of times
01610 // InitGoogleTest() has been called.  We don't protect this variable
01611 // under a mutex as it is only accessed in the main thread.
01612 int g_init_gtest_count = 0;
01613 static bool GTestIsInitialized() { return g_init_gtest_count != 0; }
01614 
01615 // Iterates over a vector of TestCases, keeping a running sum of the
01616 // results of calling a given int-returning method on each.
01617 // Returns the sum.
01618 static int SumOverTestCaseList(const std::vector<TestCase*>& case_list,
01619                                int (TestCase::*method)() const) {
01620   int sum = 0;
01621   for (size_t i = 0; i < case_list.size(); i++) {
01622     sum += (case_list[i]->*method)();
01623   }
01624   return sum;
01625 }
01626 
01627 // Returns true iff the test case passed.
01628 static bool TestCasePassed(const TestCase* test_case) {
01629   return test_case->should_run() && test_case->Passed();
01630 }
01631 
01632 // Returns true iff the test case failed.
01633 static bool TestCaseFailed(const TestCase* test_case) {
01634   return test_case->should_run() && test_case->Failed();
01635 }
01636 
01637 // Returns true iff test_case contains at least one test that should
01638 // run.
01639 static bool ShouldRunTestCase(const TestCase* test_case) {
01640   return test_case->should_run();
01641 }
01642 
01643 // AssertHelper constructor.
01644 AssertHelper::AssertHelper(TestPartResult::Type type,
01645                            const char* file,
01646                            int line,
01647                            const char* message)
01648     : data_(new AssertHelperData(type, file, line, message)) {
01649 }
01650 
01651 AssertHelper::~AssertHelper() {
01652   delete data_;
01653 }
01654 
01655 // Message assignment, for assertion streaming support.
01656 void AssertHelper::operator=(const Message& message) const {
01657   UnitTest::GetInstance()->
01658     AddTestPartResult(data_->type, data_->file, data_->line,
01659                       AppendUserMessage(data_->message, message),
01660                       UnitTest::GetInstance()->impl()
01661                       ->CurrentOsStackTraceExceptTop(1)
01662                       // Skips the stack frame for this function itself.
01663                       );  // NOLINT
01664 }
01665 
01666 // Mutex for linked pointers.
01667 GTEST_DEFINE_STATIC_MUTEX_(g_linked_ptr_mutex);
01668 
01669 // Application pathname gotten in InitGoogleTest.
01670 String g_executable_path;
01671 
01672 // Returns the current application's name, removing directory path if that
01673 // is present.
01674 FilePath GetCurrentExecutableName() {
01675   FilePath result;
01676 
01677 #if GTEST_OS_WINDOWS
01678   result.Set(FilePath(g_executable_path).RemoveExtension("exe"));
01679 #else
01680   result.Set(FilePath(g_executable_path));
01681 #endif  // GTEST_OS_WINDOWS
01682 
01683   return result.RemoveDirectoryName();
01684 }
01685 
01686 // Functions for processing the gtest_output flag.
01687 
01688 // Returns the output format, or "" for normal printed output.
01689 String UnitTestOptions::GetOutputFormat() {
01690   const char* const gtest_output_flag = GTEST_FLAG(output).c_str();
01691   if (gtest_output_flag == NULL) return String("");
01692 
01693   const char* const colon = strchr(gtest_output_flag, ':');
01694   return (colon == NULL) ?
01695       String(gtest_output_flag) :
01696       String(gtest_output_flag, colon - gtest_output_flag);
01697 }
01698 
01699 // Returns the name of the requested output file, or the default if none
01700 // was explicitly specified.
01701 String UnitTestOptions::GetAbsolutePathToOutputFile() {
01702   const char* const gtest_output_flag = GTEST_FLAG(output).c_str();
01703   if (gtest_output_flag == NULL)
01704     return String("");
01705 
01706   const char* const colon = strchr(gtest_output_flag, ':');
01707   if (colon == NULL)
01708     return String(internal::FilePath::ConcatPaths(
01709                internal::FilePath(
01710                    UnitTest::GetInstance()->original_working_dir()),
01711                internal::FilePath(kDefaultOutputFile)).ToString() );
01712 
01713   internal::FilePath output_name(colon + 1);
01714   if (!output_name.IsAbsolutePath())
01715     // TODO(wan@google.com): on Windows \some\path is not an absolute
01716     // path (as its meaning depends on the current drive), yet the
01717     // following logic for turning it into an absolute path is wrong.
01718     // Fix it.
01719     output_name = internal::FilePath::ConcatPaths(
01720         internal::FilePath(UnitTest::GetInstance()->original_working_dir()),
01721         internal::FilePath(colon + 1));
01722 
01723   if (!output_name.IsDirectory())
01724     return output_name.ToString();
01725 
01726   internal::FilePath result(internal::FilePath::GenerateUniqueFileName(
01727       output_name, internal::GetCurrentExecutableName(),
01728       GetOutputFormat().c_str()));
01729   return result.ToString();
01730 }
01731 
01732 // Returns true iff the wildcard pattern matches the string.  The
01733 // first ':' or '\0' character in pattern marks the end of it.
01734 //
01735 // This recursive algorithm isn't very efficient, but is clear and
01736 // works well enough for matching test names, which are short.
01737 bool UnitTestOptions::PatternMatchesString(const char *pattern,
01738                                            const char *str) {
01739   switch (*pattern) {
01740     case '\0':
01741     case ':':  // Either ':' or '\0' marks the end of the pattern.
01742       return *str == '\0';
01743     case '?':  // Matches any single character.
01744       return *str != '\0' && PatternMatchesString(pattern + 1, str + 1);
01745     case '*':  // Matches any string (possibly empty) of characters.
01746       return (*str != '\0' && PatternMatchesString(pattern, str + 1)) ||
01747           PatternMatchesString(pattern + 1, str);
01748     default:  // Non-special character.  Matches itself.
01749       return *pattern == *str &&
01750           PatternMatchesString(pattern + 1, str + 1);
01751   }
01752 }
01753 
01754 bool UnitTestOptions::MatchesFilter(const String& name, const char* filter) {
01755   const char *cur_pattern = filter;
01756   for (;;) {
01757     if (PatternMatchesString(cur_pattern, name.c_str())) {
01758       return true;
01759     }
01760 
01761     // Finds the next pattern in the filter.
01762     cur_pattern = strchr(cur_pattern, ':');
01763 
01764     // Returns if no more pattern can be found.
01765     if (cur_pattern == NULL) {
01766       return false;
01767     }
01768 
01769     // Skips the pattern separater (the ':' character).
01770     cur_pattern++;
01771   }
01772 }
01773 
01774 // TODO(keithray): move String function implementations to gtest-string.cc.
01775 
01776 // Returns true iff the user-specified filter matches the test case
01777 // name and the test name.
01778 bool UnitTestOptions::FilterMatchesTest(const String &test_case_name,
01779                                         const String &test_name) {
01780   const String& full_name = String::Format("%s.%s",
01781                                            test_case_name.c_str(),
01782                                            test_name.c_str());
01783 
01784   // Split --gtest_filter at '-', if there is one, to separate into
01785   // positive filter and negative filter portions
01786   const char* const p = GTEST_FLAG(filter).c_str();
01787   const char* const dash = strchr(p, '-');
01788   String positive;
01789   String negative;
01790   if (dash == NULL) {
01791     positive = GTEST_FLAG(filter).c_str();  // Whole string is a positive filter
01792     negative = String("");
01793   } else {
01794     positive = String(p, dash - p);  // Everything up to the dash
01795     negative = String(dash+1);       // Everything after the dash
01796     if (positive.empty()) {
01797       // Treat '-test1' as the same as '*-test1'
01798       positive = kUniversalFilter;
01799     }
01800   }
01801 
01802   // A filter is a colon-separated list of patterns.  It matches a
01803   // test if any pattern in it matches the test.
01804   return (MatchesFilter(full_name, positive.c_str()) &&
01805           !MatchesFilter(full_name, negative.c_str()));
01806 }
01807 
01808 #if GTEST_HAS_SEH
01809 // Returns EXCEPTION_EXECUTE_HANDLER if Google Test should handle the
01810 // given SEH exception, or EXCEPTION_CONTINUE_SEARCH otherwise.
01811 // This function is useful as an __except condition.
01812 int UnitTestOptions::GTestShouldProcessSEH(DWORD exception_code) {
01813   // Google Test should handle a SEH exception if:
01814   //   1. the user wants it to, AND
01815   //   2. this is not a breakpoint exception, AND
01816   //   3. this is not a C++ exception (VC++ implements them via SEH,
01817   //      apparently).
01818   //
01819   // SEH exception code for C++ exceptions.
01820   // (see http://support.microsoft.com/kb/185294 for more information).
01821   const DWORD kCxxExceptionCode = 0xe06d7363;
01822 
01823   bool should_handle = true;
01824 
01825   if (!GTEST_FLAG(catch_exceptions))
01826     should_handle = false;
01827   else if (exception_code == EXCEPTION_BREAKPOINT)
01828     should_handle = false;
01829   else if (exception_code == kCxxExceptionCode)
01830     should_handle = false;
01831 
01832   return should_handle ? EXCEPTION_EXECUTE_HANDLER : EXCEPTION_CONTINUE_SEARCH;
01833 }
01834 #endif  // GTEST_HAS_SEH
01835 
01836 }  // namespace internal
01837 
01838 // The c'tor sets this object as the test part result reporter used by
01839 // Google Test.  The 'result' parameter specifies where to report the
01840 // results. Intercepts only failures from the current thread.
01841 ScopedFakeTestPartResultReporter::ScopedFakeTestPartResultReporter(
01842     TestPartResultArray* result)
01843     : intercept_mode_(INTERCEPT_ONLY_CURRENT_THREAD),
01844       result_(result) {
01845   Init();
01846 }
01847 
01848 // The c'tor sets this object as the test part result reporter used by
01849 // Google Test.  The 'result' parameter specifies where to report the
01850 // results.
01851 ScopedFakeTestPartResultReporter::ScopedFakeTestPartResultReporter(
01852     InterceptMode intercept_mode, TestPartResultArray* result)
01853     : intercept_mode_(intercept_mode),
01854       result_(result) {
01855   Init();
01856 }
01857 
01858 void ScopedFakeTestPartResultReporter::Init() {
01859   internal::UnitTestImpl* const impl = internal::GetUnitTestImpl();
01860   if (intercept_mode_ == INTERCEPT_ALL_THREADS) {
01861     old_reporter_ = impl->GetGlobalTestPartResultReporter();
01862     impl->SetGlobalTestPartResultReporter(this);
01863   } else {
01864     old_reporter_ = impl->GetTestPartResultReporterForCurrentThread();
01865     impl->SetTestPartResultReporterForCurrentThread(this);
01866   }
01867 }
01868 
01869 // The d'tor restores the test part result reporter used by Google Test
01870 // before.
01871 ScopedFakeTestPartResultReporter::~ScopedFakeTestPartResultReporter() {
01872   internal::UnitTestImpl* const impl = internal::GetUnitTestImpl();
01873   if (intercept_mode_ == INTERCEPT_ALL_THREADS) {
01874     impl->SetGlobalTestPartResultReporter(old_reporter_);
01875   } else {
01876     impl->SetTestPartResultReporterForCurrentThread(old_reporter_);
01877   }
01878 }
01879 
01880 // Increments the test part result count and remembers the result.
01881 // This method is from the TestPartResultReporterInterface interface.
01882 void ScopedFakeTestPartResultReporter::ReportTestPartResult(
01883     const TestPartResult& result) {
01884   result_->Append(result);
01885 }
01886 
01887 namespace internal {
01888 
01889 // Returns the type ID of ::testing::Test.  We should always call this
01890 // instead of GetTypeId< ::testing::Test>() to get the type ID of
01891 // testing::Test.  This is to work around a suspected linker bug when
01892 // using Google Test as a framework on Mac OS X.  The bug causes
01893 // GetTypeId< ::testing::Test>() to return different values depending
01894 // on whether the call is from the Google Test framework itself or
01895 // from user test code.  GetTestTypeId() is guaranteed to always
01896 // return the same value, as it always calls GetTypeId<>() from the
01897 // gtest.cc, which is within the Google Test framework.
01898 TypeId GetTestTypeId() {
01899   return GetTypeId<Test>();
01900 }
01901 
01902 // The value of GetTestTypeId() as seen from within the Google Test
01903 // library.  This is solely for testing GetTestTypeId().
01904 extern const TypeId kTestTypeIdInGoogleTest = GetTestTypeId();
01905 
01906 // This predicate-formatter checks that 'results' contains a test part
01907 // failure of the given type and that the failure message contains the
01908 // given substring.
01909 AssertionResult HasOneFailure(const char* /* results_expr */,
01910                               const char* /* type_expr */,
01911                               const char* /* substr_expr */,
01912                               const TestPartResultArray& results,
01913                               TestPartResult::Type type,
01914                               const string& substr) {
01915   const String expected(type == TestPartResult::kFatalFailure ?
01916                         "1 fatal failure" :
01917                         "1 non-fatal failure");
01918   Message msg;
01919   if (results.size() != 1) {
01920     msg << "Expected: " << expected << "\n"
01921         << "  Actual: " << results.size() << " failures";
01922     for (int i = 0; i < results.size(); i++) {
01923       msg << "\n" << results.GetTestPartResult(i);
01924     }
01925     return AssertionFailure() << msg;
01926   }
01927 
01928   const TestPartResult& r = results.GetTestPartResult(0);
01929   if (r.type() != type) {
01930     return AssertionFailure() << "Expected: " << expected << "\n"
01931                               << "  Actual:\n"
01932                               << r;
01933   }
01934 
01935   if (strstr(r.message(), substr.c_str()) == NULL) {
01936     return AssertionFailure() << "Expected: " << expected << " containing \""
01937                               << substr << "\"\n"
01938                               << "  Actual:\n"
01939                               << r;
01940   }
01941 
01942   return AssertionSuccess();
01943 }
01944 
01945 // The constructor of SingleFailureChecker remembers where to look up
01946 // test part results, what type of failure we expect, and what
01947 // substring the failure message should contain.
01948 SingleFailureChecker:: SingleFailureChecker(
01949     const TestPartResultArray* results,
01950     TestPartResult::Type type,
01951     const string& substr)
01952     : results_(results),
01953       type_(type),
01954       substr_(substr) {}
01955 
01956 // The destructor of SingleFailureChecker verifies that the given
01957 // TestPartResultArray contains exactly one failure that has the given
01958 // type and contains the given substring.  If that's not the case, a
01959 // non-fatal failure will be generated.
01960 SingleFailureChecker::~SingleFailureChecker() {
01961   EXPECT_PRED_FORMAT3(HasOneFailure, *results_, type_, substr_);
01962 }
01963 
01964 DefaultGlobalTestPartResultReporter::DefaultGlobalTestPartResultReporter(
01965     UnitTestImpl* unit_test) : unit_test_(unit_test) {}
01966 
01967 void DefaultGlobalTestPartResultReporter::ReportTestPartResult(
01968     const TestPartResult& result) {
01969   unit_test_->current_test_result()->AddTestPartResult(result);
01970   unit_test_->listeners()->repeater()->OnTestPartResult(result);
01971 }
01972 
01973 DefaultPerThreadTestPartResultReporter::DefaultPerThreadTestPartResultReporter(
01974     UnitTestImpl* unit_test) : unit_test_(unit_test) {}
01975 
01976 void DefaultPerThreadTestPartResultReporter::ReportTestPartResult(
01977     const TestPartResult& result) {
01978   unit_test_->GetGlobalTestPartResultReporter()->ReportTestPartResult(result);
01979 }
01980 
01981 // Returns the global test part result reporter.
01982 TestPartResultReporterInterface*
01983 UnitTestImpl::GetGlobalTestPartResultReporter() {
01984   internal::MutexLock lock(&global_test_part_result_reporter_mutex_);
01985   return global_test_part_result_repoter_;
01986 }
01987 
01988 // Sets the global test part result reporter.
01989 void UnitTestImpl::SetGlobalTestPartResultReporter(
01990     TestPartResultReporterInterface* reporter) {
01991   internal::MutexLock lock(&global_test_part_result_reporter_mutex_);
01992   global_test_part_result_repoter_ = reporter;
01993 }
01994 
01995 // Returns the test part result reporter for the current thread.
01996 TestPartResultReporterInterface*
01997 UnitTestImpl::GetTestPartResultReporterForCurrentThread() {
01998   return per_thread_test_part_result_reporter_.get();
01999 }
02000 
02001 // Sets the test part result reporter for the current thread.
02002 void UnitTestImpl::SetTestPartResultReporterForCurrentThread(
02003     TestPartResultReporterInterface* reporter) {
02004   per_thread_test_part_result_reporter_.set(reporter);
02005 }
02006 
02007 // Gets the number of successful test cases.
02008 int UnitTestImpl::successful_test_case_count() const {
02009   return CountIf(test_cases_, TestCasePassed);
02010 }
02011 
02012 // Gets the number of failed test cases.
02013 int UnitTestImpl::failed_test_case_count() const {
02014   return CountIf(test_cases_, TestCaseFailed);
02015 }
02016 
02017 // Gets the number of all test cases.
02018 int UnitTestImpl::total_test_case_count() const {
02019   return static_cast<int>(test_cases_.size());
