02020 }
02021 
02022 // Gets the number of all test cases that contain at least one test
02023 // that should run.
02024 int UnitTestImpl::test_case_to_run_count() const {
02025   return CountIf(test_cases_, ShouldRunTestCase);
02026 }
02027 
02028 // Gets the number of successful tests.
02029 int UnitTestImpl::successful_test_count() const {
02030   return SumOverTestCaseList(test_cases_, &TestCase::successful_test_count);
02031 }
02032 
02033 // Gets the number of failed tests.
02034 int UnitTestImpl::failed_test_count() const {
02035   return SumOverTestCaseList(test_cases_, &TestCase::failed_test_count);
02036 }
02037 
02038 // Gets the number of disabled tests.
02039 int UnitTestImpl::disabled_test_count() const {
02040   return SumOverTestCaseList(test_cases_, &TestCase::disabled_test_count);
02041 }
02042 
02043 // Gets the number of all tests.
02044 int UnitTestImpl::total_test_count() const {
02045   return SumOverTestCaseList(test_cases_, &TestCase::total_test_count);
02046 }
02047 
02048 // Gets the number of tests that should run.
02049 int UnitTestImpl::test_to_run_count() const {
02050   return SumOverTestCaseList(test_cases_, &TestCase::test_to_run_count);
02051 }
02052 
02053 // Returns the current OS stack trace as a String.
02054 //
02055 // The maximum number of stack frames to be included is specified by
02056 // the gtest_stack_trace_depth flag.  The skip_count parameter
02057 // specifies the number of top frames to be skipped, which doesn't
02058 // count against the number of frames to be included.
02059 //
02060 // For example, if Foo() calls Bar(), which in turn calls
02061 // CurrentOsStackTraceExceptTop(1), Foo() will be included in the
02062 // trace but Bar() and CurrentOsStackTraceExceptTop() won't.
02063 String UnitTestImpl::CurrentOsStackTraceExceptTop(int skip_count) {
02064   (void)skip_count;
02065   return String("");
02066 }
02067 
02068 // Returns the current time in milliseconds.
02069 TimeInMillis GetTimeInMillis() {
02070 #if GTEST_OS_WINDOWS_MOBILE || defined(__BORLANDC__)
02071   // Difference between 1970-01-01 and 1601-01-01 in milliseconds.
02072   // http://analogous.blogspot.com/2005/04/epoch.html
02073   const TimeInMillis kJavaEpochToWinFileTimeDelta =
02074     static_cast<TimeInMillis>(116444736UL) * 100000UL;
02075   const DWORD kTenthMicrosInMilliSecond = 10000;
02076 
02077   SYSTEMTIME now_systime;
02078   FILETIME now_filetime;
02079   ULARGE_INTEGER now_int64;
02080   // TODO(kenton@google.com): Shouldn't this just use
02081   //   GetSystemTimeAsFileTime()?
02082   GetSystemTime(&now_systime);
02083   if (SystemTimeToFileTime(&now_systime, &now_filetime)) {
02084     now_int64.LowPart = now_filetime.dwLowDateTime;
02085     now_int64.HighPart = now_filetime.dwHighDateTime;
02086     now_int64.QuadPart = (now_int64.QuadPart / kTenthMicrosInMilliSecond) -
02087       kJavaEpochToWinFileTimeDelta;
02088     return now_int64.QuadPart;
02089   }
02090   return 0;
02091 #elif GTEST_OS_WINDOWS && !GTEST_HAS_GETTIMEOFDAY_
02092   __timeb64 now;
02093 
02094 # ifdef _MSC_VER
02095 
02096   // MSVC 8 deprecates _ftime64(), so we want to suppress warning 4996
02097   // (deprecated function) there.
02098   // TODO(kenton@google.com): Use GetTickCount()?  Or use
02099   //   SystemTimeToFileTime()
02100 #  pragma warning(push)          // Saves the current warning state.
02101 #  pragma warning(disable:4996)  // Temporarily disables warning 4996.
02102   _ftime64(&now);
02103 #  pragma warning(pop)           // Restores the warning state.
02104 # else
02105 
02106   _ftime64(&now);
02107 
02108 # endif  // _MSC_VER
02109 
02110   return static_cast<TimeInMillis>(now.time) * 1000 + now.millitm;
02111 #elif GTEST_HAS_GETTIMEOFDAY_
02112   struct timeval now;
02113   gettimeofday(&now, NULL);
02114   return static_cast<TimeInMillis>(now.tv_sec) * 1000 + now.tv_usec / 1000;
02115 #else
02116 # error "Don't know how to get the current time on your system."
02117 #endif
02118 }
02119 
02120 // Utilities
02121 
02122 // class String
02123 
02124 // Returns the input enclosed in double quotes if it's not NULL;
02125 // otherwise returns "(null)".  For example, "\"Hello\"" is returned
02126 // for input "Hello".
02127 //
02128 // This is useful for printing a C string in the syntax of a literal.
02129 //
02130 // Known issue: escape sequences are not handled yet.
02131 String String::ShowCStringQuoted(const char* c_str) {
02132   return c_str ? String::Format("\"%s\"", c_str) : String("(null)");
02133 }
02134 
02135 // Copies at most length characters from str into a newly-allocated
02136 // piece of memory of size length+1.  The memory is allocated with new[].
02137 // A terminating null byte is written to the memory, and a pointer to it
02138 // is returned.  If str is NULL, NULL is returned.
02139 static char* CloneString(const char* str, size_t length) {
02140   if (str == NULL) {
02141     return NULL;
02142   } else {
02143     char* const clone = new char[length + 1];
02144     posix::StrNCpy(clone, str, length);
02145     clone[length] = '\0';
02146     return clone;
02147   }
02148 }
02149 
02150 // Clones a 0-terminated C string, allocating memory using new.  The
02151 // caller is responsible for deleting[] the return value.  Returns the
02152 // cloned string, or NULL if the input is NULL.
02153 const char * String::CloneCString(const char* c_str) {
02154   return (c_str == NULL) ?
02155                     NULL : CloneString(c_str, strlen(c_str));
02156 }
02157 
02158 #if GTEST_OS_WINDOWS_MOBILE
02159 // Creates a UTF-16 wide string from the given ANSI string, allocating
02160 // memory using new. The caller is responsible for deleting the return
02161 // value using delete[]. Returns the wide string, or NULL if the
02162 // input is NULL.
02163 LPCWSTR String::AnsiToUtf16(const char* ansi) {
02164   if (!ansi) return NULL;
02165   const int length = strlen(ansi);
02166   const int unicode_length =
02167       MultiByteToWideChar(CP_ACP, 0, ansi, length,
02168                           NULL, 0);
02169   WCHAR* unicode = new WCHAR[unicode_length + 1];
02170   MultiByteToWideChar(CP_ACP, 0, ansi, length,
02171                       unicode, unicode_length);
02172   unicode[unicode_length] = 0;
02173   return unicode;
02174 }
02175 
02176 // Creates an ANSI string from the given wide string, allocating
02177 // memory using new. The caller is responsible for deleting the return
02178 // value using delete[]. Returns the ANSI string, or NULL if the
02179 // input is NULL.
02180 const char* String::Utf16ToAnsi(LPCWSTR utf16_str)  {
02181   if (!utf16_str) return NULL;
02182   const int ansi_length =
02183       WideCharToMultiByte(CP_ACP, 0, utf16_str, -1,
02184                           NULL, 0, NULL, NULL);
02185   char* ansi = new char[ansi_length + 1];
02186   WideCharToMultiByte(CP_ACP, 0, utf16_str, -1,
02187                       ansi, ansi_length, NULL, NULL);
02188   ansi[ansi_length] = 0;
02189   return ansi;
02190 }
02191 
02192 #endif  // GTEST_OS_WINDOWS_MOBILE
02193 
02194 // Compares two C strings.  Returns true iff they have the same content.
02195 //
02196 // Unlike strcmp(), this function can handle NULL argument(s).  A NULL
02197 // C string is considered different to any non-NULL C string,
02198 // including the empty string.
02199 bool String::CStringEquals(const char * lhs, const char * rhs) {
02200   if ( lhs == NULL ) return rhs == NULL;
02201 
02202   if ( rhs == NULL ) return false;
02203 
02204   return strcmp(lhs, rhs) == 0;
02205 }
02206 
02207 #if GTEST_HAS_STD_WSTRING || GTEST_HAS_GLOBAL_WSTRING
02208 
02209 // Converts an array of wide chars to a narrow string using the UTF-8
02210 // encoding, and streams the result to the given Message object.
02211 static void StreamWideCharsToMessage(const wchar_t* wstr, size_t length,
02212                                      Message* msg) {
02213   // TODO(wan): consider allowing a testing::String object to
02214   // contain '\0'.  This will make it behave more like std::string,
02215   // and will allow ToUtf8String() to return the correct encoding
02216   // for '\0' s.t. we can get rid of the conditional here (and in
02217   // several other places).
02218   for (size_t i = 0; i != length; ) {  // NOLINT
02219     if (wstr[i] != L'\0') {
02220       *msg << WideStringToUtf8(wstr + i, static_cast<int>(length - i));
02221       while (i != length && wstr[i] != L'\0')
02222         i++;
02223     } else {
02224       *msg << '\0';
02225       i++;
02226     }
02227   }
02228 }
02229 
02230 #endif  // GTEST_HAS_STD_WSTRING || GTEST_HAS_GLOBAL_WSTRING
02231 
02232 }  // namespace internal
02233 
02234 #if GTEST_HAS_STD_WSTRING
02235 // Converts the given wide string to a narrow string using the UTF-8
02236 // encoding, and streams the result to this Message object.
02237 Message& Message::operator <<(const ::std::wstring& wstr) {
02238   internal::StreamWideCharsToMessage(wstr.c_str(), wstr.length(), this);
02239   return *this;
02240 }
02241 #endif  // GTEST_HAS_STD_WSTRING
02242 
02243 #if GTEST_HAS_GLOBAL_WSTRING
02244 // Converts the given wide string to a narrow string using the UTF-8
02245 // encoding, and streams the result to this Message object.
02246 Message& Message::operator <<(const ::wstring& wstr) {
02247   internal::StreamWideCharsToMessage(wstr.c_str(), wstr.length(), this);
02248   return *this;
02249 }
02250 #endif  // GTEST_HAS_GLOBAL_WSTRING
02251 
02252 // AssertionResult constructors.
02253 // Used in EXPECT_TRUE/FALSE(assertion_result).
02254 AssertionResult::AssertionResult(const AssertionResult& other)
02255     : success_(other.success_),
02256       message_(other.message_.get() != NULL ?
02257                new ::std::string(*other.message_) :
02258                static_cast< ::std::string*>(NULL)) {
02259 }
02260 
02261 // Returns the assertion's negation. Used with EXPECT/ASSERT_FALSE.
02262 AssertionResult AssertionResult::operator!() const {
02263   AssertionResult negation(!success_);
02264   if (message_.get() != NULL)
02265     negation << *message_;
02266   return negation;
02267 }
02268 
02269 // Makes a successful assertion result.
02270 AssertionResult AssertionSuccess() {
02271   return AssertionResult(true);
02272 }
02273 
02274 // Makes a failed assertion result.
02275 AssertionResult AssertionFailure() {
02276   return AssertionResult(false);
02277 }
02278 
02279 // Makes a failed assertion result with the given failure message.
02280 // Deprecated; use AssertionFailure() << message.
02281 AssertionResult AssertionFailure(const Message& message) {
02282   return AssertionFailure() << message;
02283 }
02284 
02285 namespace internal {
02286 
02287 // Constructs and returns the message for an equality assertion
02288 // (e.g. ASSERT_EQ, EXPECT_STREQ, etc) failure.
02289 //
02290 // The first four parameters are the expressions used in the assertion
02291 // and their values, as strings.  For example, for ASSERT_EQ(foo, bar)
02292 // where foo is 5 and bar is 6, we have:
02293 //
02294 //   expected_expression: "foo"
02295 //   actual_expression:   "bar"
02296 //   expected_value:      "5"
02297 //   actual_value:        "6"
02298 //
02299 // The ignoring_case parameter is true iff the assertion is a
02300 // *_STRCASEEQ*.  When it's true, the string " (ignoring case)" will
02301 // be inserted into the message.
02302 AssertionResult EqFailure(const char* expected_expression,
02303                           const char* actual_expression,
02304                           const String& expected_value,
02305                           const String& actual_value,
02306                           bool ignoring_case) {
02307   Message msg;
02308   msg << "Value of: " << actual_expression;
02309   if (actual_value != actual_expression) {
02310     msg << "\n  Actual: " << actual_value;
02311   }
02312 
02313   msg << "\nExpected: " << expected_expression;
02314   if (ignoring_case) {
02315     msg << " (ignoring case)";
02316   }
02317   if (expected_value != expected_expression) {
02318     msg << "\nWhich is: " << expected_value;
02319   }
02320 
02321   return AssertionFailure() << msg;
02322 }
02323 
02324 // Constructs a failure message for Boolean assertions such as EXPECT_TRUE.
02325 String GetBoolAssertionFailureMessage(const AssertionResult& assertion_result,
02326                                       const char* expression_text,
02327                                       const char* actual_predicate_value,
02328                                       const char* expected_predicate_value) {
02329   const char* actual_message = assertion_result.message();
02330   Message msg;
02331   msg << "Value of: " << expression_text
02332       << "\n  Actual: " << actual_predicate_value;
02333   if (actual_message[0] != '\0')
02334     msg << " (" << actual_message << ")";
02335   msg << "\nExpected: " << expected_predicate_value;
02336   return msg.GetString();
02337 }
02338 
02339 // Helper function for implementing ASSERT_NEAR.
02340 AssertionResult DoubleNearPredFormat(const char* expr1,
02341                                      const char* expr2,
02342                                      const char* abs_error_expr,
02343                                      double val1,
02344                                      double val2,
02345                                      double abs_error) {
02346   const double diff = fabs(val1 - val2);
02347   if (diff <= abs_error) return AssertionSuccess();
02348 
02349   // TODO(wan): do not print the value of an expression if it's
02350   // already a literal.
02351   return AssertionFailure()
02352       << "The difference between " << expr1 << " and " << expr2
02353       << " is " << diff << ", which exceeds " << abs_error_expr << ", where\n"
02354       << expr1 << " evaluates to " << val1 << ",\n"
02355       << expr2 << " evaluates to " << val2 << ", and\n"
02356       << abs_error_expr << " evaluates to " << abs_error << ".";
02357 }
02358 
02359 
02360 // Helper template for implementing FloatLE() and DoubleLE().
02361 template <typename RawType>
02362 AssertionResult FloatingPointLE(const char* expr1,
02363                                 const char* expr2,
02364                                 RawType val1,
02365                                 RawType val2) {
02366   // Returns success if val1 is less than val2,
02367   if (val1 < val2) {
02368     return AssertionSuccess();
02369   }
02370 
02371   // or if val1 is almost equal to val2.
02372   const FloatingPoint<RawType> lhs(val1), rhs(val2);
02373   if (lhs.AlmostEquals(rhs)) {
02374     return AssertionSuccess();
02375   }
02376 
02377   // Note that the above two checks will both fail if either val1 or
02378   // val2 is NaN, as the IEEE floating-point standard requires that
02379   // any predicate involving a NaN must return false.
02380 
02381   ::std::stringstream val1_ss;
02382   val1_ss << std::setprecision(std::numeric_limits<RawType>::digits10 + 2)
02383           << val1;
02384 
02385   ::std::stringstream val2_ss;
02386   val2_ss << std::setprecision(std::numeric_limits<RawType>::digits10 + 2)
02387           << val2;
02388 
02389   return AssertionFailure()
02390       << "Expected: (" << expr1 << ") <= (" << expr2 << ")\n"
02391       << "  Actual: " << StringStreamToString(&val1_ss) << " vs "
02392       << StringStreamToString(&val2_ss);
02393 }
02394 
02395 }  // namespace internal
02396 
02397 // Asserts that val1 is less than, or almost equal to, val2.  Fails
02398 // otherwise.  In particular, it fails if either val1 or val2 is NaN.
02399 AssertionResult FloatLE(const char* expr1, const char* expr2,
02400                         float val1, float val2) {
02401   return internal::FloatingPointLE<float>(expr1, expr2, val1, val2);
02402 }
02403 
02404 // Asserts that val1 is less than, or almost equal to, val2.  Fails
02405 // otherwise.  In particular, it fails if either val1 or val2 is NaN.
02406 AssertionResult DoubleLE(const char* expr1, const char* expr2,
02407                          double val1, double val2) {
02408   return internal::FloatingPointLE<double>(expr1, expr2, val1, val2);
02409 }
02410 
02411 namespace internal {
02412 
02413 // The helper function for {ASSERT|EXPECT}_EQ with int or enum
02414 // arguments.
02415 AssertionResult CmpHelperEQ(const char* expected_expression,
02416                             const char* actual_expression,
02417                             BiggestInt expected,
02418                             BiggestInt actual) {
02419   if (expected == actual) {
02420     return AssertionSuccess();
02421   }
02422 
02423   return EqFailure(expected_expression,
02424                    actual_expression,
02425                    FormatForComparisonFailureMessage(expected, actual),
02426                    FormatForComparisonFailureMessage(actual, expected),
02427                    false);
02428 }
02429 
02430 // A macro for implementing the helper functions needed to implement
02431 // ASSERT_?? and EXPECT_?? with integer or enum arguments.  It is here
02432 // just to avoid copy-and-paste of similar code.
02433 #define GTEST_IMPL_CMP_HELPER_(op_name, op)\
02434 AssertionResult CmpHelper##op_name(const char* expr1, const char* expr2, \
02435                                    BiggestInt val1, BiggestInt val2) {\
02436   if (val1 op val2) {\
02437     return AssertionSuccess();\
02438   } else {\
02439     return AssertionFailure() \
02440         << "Expected: (" << expr1 << ") " #op " (" << expr2\
02441         << "), actual: " << FormatForComparisonFailureMessage(val1, val2)\
02442         << " vs " << FormatForComparisonFailureMessage(val2, val1);\
02443   }\
02444 }
02445 
02446 // Implements the helper function for {ASSERT|EXPECT}_NE with int or
02447 // enum arguments.
02448 GTEST_IMPL_CMP_HELPER_(NE, !=)
02449 // Implements the helper function for {ASSERT|EXPECT}_LE with int or
02450 // enum arguments.
02451 GTEST_IMPL_CMP_HELPER_(LE, <=)
02452 // Implements the helper function for {ASSERT|EXPECT}_LT with int or
02453 // enum arguments.
02454 GTEST_IMPL_CMP_HELPER_(LT, < )
02455 // Implements the helper function for {ASSERT|EXPECT}_GE with int or
02456 // enum arguments.
02457 GTEST_IMPL_CMP_HELPER_(GE, >=)
02458 // Implements the helper function for {ASSERT|EXPECT}_GT with int or
02459 // enum arguments.
02460 GTEST_IMPL_CMP_HELPER_(GT, > )
02461 
02462 #undef GTEST_IMPL_CMP_HELPER_
02463 
02464 // The helper function for {ASSERT|EXPECT}_STREQ.
02465 AssertionResult CmpHelperSTREQ(const char* expected_expression,
02466                                const char* actual_expression,
02467                                const char* expected,
02468                                const char* actual) {
02469   if (String::CStringEquals(expected, actual)) {
02470     return AssertionSuccess();
02471   }
02472 
02473   return EqFailure(expected_expression,
02474                    actual_expression,
02475                    String::ShowCStringQuoted(expected),
02476                    String::ShowCStringQuoted(actual),
02477                    false);
02478 }
02479 
02480 // The helper function for {ASSERT|EXPECT}_STRCASEEQ.
02481 AssertionResult CmpHelperSTRCASEEQ(const char* expected_expression,
02482                                    const char* actual_expression,
02483                                    const char* expected,
02484                                    const char* actual) {
02485   if (String::CaseInsensitiveCStringEquals(expected, actual)) {
02486     return AssertionSuccess();
02487   }
02488 
02489   return EqFailure(expected_expression,
02490                    actual_expression,
02491                    String::ShowCStringQuoted(expected),
02492                    String::ShowCStringQuoted(actual),
02493                    true);
02494 }
02495 
02496 // The helper function for {ASSERT|EXPECT}_STRNE.
02497 AssertionResult CmpHelperSTRNE(const char* s1_expression,
02498                                const char* s2_expression,
02499                                const char* s1,
02500                                const char* s2) {
02501   if (!String::CStringEquals(s1, s2)) {
02502     return AssertionSuccess();
02503   } else {
02504     return AssertionFailure() << "Expected: (" << s1_expression << ") != ("
02505                               << s2_expression << "), actual: \""
02506                               << s1 << "\" vs \"" << s2 << "\"";
02507   }
02508 }
02509 
02510 // The helper function for {ASSERT|EXPECT}_STRCASENE.
02511 AssertionResult CmpHelperSTRCASENE(const char* s1_expression,
02512                                    const char* s2_expression,
02513                                    const char* s1,
02514                                    const char* s2) {
02515   if (!String::CaseInsensitiveCStringEquals(s1, s2)) {
02516     return AssertionSuccess();
02517   } else {
02518     return AssertionFailure()
02519         << "Expected: (" << s1_expression << ") != ("
02520         << s2_expression << ") (ignoring case), actual: \""
02521         << s1 << "\" vs \"" << s2 << "\"";
02522   }
02523 }
02524 
02525 }  // namespace internal
02526 
02527 namespace {
02528 
02529 // Helper functions for implementing IsSubString() and IsNotSubstring().
02530 
02531 // This group of overloaded functions return true iff needle is a
02532 // substring of haystack.  NULL is considered a substring of itself
02533 // only.
02534 
02535 bool IsSubstringPred(const char* needle, const char* haystack) {
02536   if (needle == NULL || haystack == NULL)
02537     return needle == haystack;
02538 
02539   return strstr(haystack, needle) != NULL;
02540 }
02541 
02542 bool IsSubstringPred(const wchar_t* needle, const wchar_t* haystack) {
02543   if (needle == NULL || haystack == NULL)
02544     return needle == haystack;
02545 
02546   return wcsstr(haystack, needle) != NULL;
02547 }
02548 
02549 // StringType here can be either ::std::string or ::std::wstring.
02550 template <typename StringType>
02551 bool IsSubstringPred(const StringType& needle,
02552                      const StringType& haystack) {
02553   return haystack.find(needle) != StringType::npos;
02554 }
02555 
02556 // This function implements either IsSubstring() or IsNotSubstring(),
02557 // depending on the value of the expected_to_be_substring parameter.
02558 // StringType here can be const char*, const wchar_t*, ::std::string,
02559 // or ::std::wstring.
02560 template <typename StringType>
02561 AssertionResult IsSubstringImpl(
02562     bool expected_to_be_substring,
02563     const char* needle_expr, const char* haystack_expr,
02564     const StringType& needle, const StringType& haystack) {
02565   if (IsSubstringPred(needle, haystack) == expected_to_be_substring)
02566     return AssertionSuccess();
02567 
02568   const bool is_wide_string = sizeof(needle[0]) > 1;
02569   const char* const begin_string_quote = is_wide_string ? "L\"" : "\"";
02570   return AssertionFailure()
02571       << "Value of: " << needle_expr << "\n"
02572       << "  Actual: " << begin_string_quote << needle << "\"\n"
02573       << "Expected: " << (expected_to_be_substring ? "" : "not ")
02574       << "a substring of " << haystack_expr << "\n"
02575       << "Which is: " << begin_string_quote << haystack << "\"";
02576 }
02577 
02578 }  // namespace
02579 
02580 // IsSubstring() and IsNotSubstring() check whether needle is a
02581 // substring of haystack (NULL is considered a substring of itself
02582 // only), and return an appropriate error message when they fail.
02583 
02584 AssertionResult IsSubstring(
02585     const char* needle_expr, const char* haystack_expr,
02586     const char* needle, const char* haystack) {
02587   return IsSubstringImpl(true, needle_expr, haystack_expr, needle, haystack);
02588 }
02589 
02590 AssertionResult IsSubstring(
02591     const char* needle_expr, const char* haystack_expr,
02592     const wchar_t* needle, const wchar_t* haystack) {
02593   return IsSubstringImpl(true, needle_expr, haystack_expr, needle, haystack);
02594 }
02595 
02596 AssertionResult IsNotSubstring(
02597     const char* needle_expr, const char* haystack_expr,
02598     const char* needle, const char* haystack) {
02599   return IsSubstringImpl(false, needle_expr, haystack_expr, needle, haystack);
02600 }
02601 
02602 AssertionResult IsNotSubstring(
02603     const char* needle_expr, const char* haystack_expr,
02604     const wchar_t* needle, const wchar_t* haystack) {
02605   return IsSubstringImpl(false, needle_expr, haystack_expr, needle, haystack);
02606 }
02607 
02608 AssertionResult IsSubstring(
02609     const char* needle_expr, const char* haystack_expr,
02610     const ::std::string& needle, const ::std::string& haystack) {
02611   return IsSubstringImpl(true, needle_expr, haystack_expr, needle, haystack);
02612 }
02613 
02614 AssertionResult IsNotSubstring(
02615     const char* needle_expr, const char* haystack_expr,
02616     const ::std::string& needle, const ::std::string& haystack) {
02617   return IsSubstringImpl(false, needle_expr, haystack_expr, needle, haystack);
02618 }
02619 
02620 #if GTEST_HAS_STD_WSTRING
02621 AssertionResult IsSubstring(
02622     const char* needle_expr, const char* haystack_expr,
02623     const ::std::wstring& needle, const ::std::wstring& haystack) {
02624   return IsSubstringImpl(true, needle_expr, haystack_expr, needle, haystack);
02625 }
02626 
02627 AssertionResult IsNotSubstring(
02628     const char* needle_expr, const char* haystack_expr,
02629     const ::std::wstring& needle, const ::std::wstring& haystack) {
02630   return IsSubstringImpl(false, needle_expr, haystack_expr, needle, haystack);
02631 }
02632 #endif  // GTEST_HAS_STD_WSTRING
02633 
02634 namespace internal {
02635 
02636 #if GTEST_OS_WINDOWS
02637 
02638 namespace {
02639 
02640 // Helper function for IsHRESULT{SuccessFailure} predicates
02641 AssertionResult HRESULTFailureHelper(const char* expr,
02642                                      const char* expected,
02643                                      long hr) {  // NOLINT
02644 # if GTEST_OS_WINDOWS_MOBILE
02645 
02646   // Windows CE doesn't support FormatMessage.
02647   const char error_text[] = "";
02648 
02649 # else
02650 
02651   // Looks up the human-readable system message for the HRESULT code
02652   // and since we're not passing any params to FormatMessage, we don't
02653   // want inserts expanded.
02654   const DWORD kFlags = FORMAT_MESSAGE_FROM_SYSTEM |
02655                        FORMAT_MESSAGE_IGNORE_INSERTS;
02656   const DWORD kBufSize = 4096;  // String::Format can't exceed this length.
02657   // Gets the system's human readable message string for this HRESULT.
02658   char error_text[kBufSize] = { '\0' };
02659   DWORD message_length = ::FormatMessageA(kFlags,
02660                                           0,  // no source, we're asking system
02661                                           hr,  // the error
02662                                           0,  // no line width restrictions
02663                                           error_text,  // output buffer
02664                                           kBufSize,  // buf size
02665                                           NULL);  // no arguments for inserts
02666   // Trims tailing white space (FormatMessage leaves a trailing cr-lf)
02667   for (; message_length && IsSpace(error_text[message_length - 1]);
02668           --message_length) {
02669     error_text[message_length - 1] = '\0';
02670   }
02671 
02672 # endif  // GTEST_OS_WINDOWS_MOBILE
02673 
02674   const String error_hex(String::Format("0x%08X ", hr));
02675   return ::testing::AssertionFailure()
02676       << "Expected: " << expr << " " << expected << ".\n"
02677       << "  Actual: " << error_hex << error_text << "\n";
02678 }
02679 
02680 }  // namespace
02681 
02682 AssertionResult IsHRESULTSuccess(const char* expr, long hr) {  // NOLINT
02683   if (SUCCEEDED(hr)) {
02684     return AssertionSuccess();
02685   }
02686   return HRESULTFailureHelper(expr, "succeeds", hr);
02687 }
02688 
02689 AssertionResult IsHRESULTFailure(const char* expr, long hr) {  // NOLINT
02690   if (FAILED(hr)) {
02691     return AssertionSuccess();
02692   }
02693   return HRESULTFailureHelper(expr, "fails", hr);
02694 }
02695 
02696 #endif  // GTEST_OS_WINDOWS
02697 
02698 // Utility functions for encoding Unicode text (wide strings) in
02699 // UTF-8.
02700 
02701 // A Unicode code-point can have upto 21 bits, and is encoded in UTF-8
02702 // like this:
02703 //
02704 // Code-point length   Encoding
02705 //   0 -  7 bits       0xxxxxxx
02706 //   8 - 11 bits       110xxxxx 10xxxxxx
02707 //  12 - 16 bits       1110xxxx 10xxxxxx 10xxxxxx
02708 //  17 - 21 bits       11110xxx 10xxxxxx 10xxxxxx 10xxxxxx
02709 
02710 // The maximum code-point a one-byte UTF-8 sequence can represent.
02711 const UInt32 kMaxCodePoint1 = (static_cast<UInt32>(1) <<  7) - 1;
02712 
02713 // The maximum code-point a two-byte UTF-8 sequence can represent.
02714 const UInt32 kMaxCodePoint2 = (static_cast<UInt32>(1) << (5 + 6)) - 1;
02715 
02716 // The maximum code-point a three-byte UTF-8 sequence can represent.
02717 const UInt32 kMaxCodePoint3 = (static_cast<UInt32>(1) << (4 + 2*6)) - 1;
02718 
02719 // The maximum code-point a four-byte UTF-8 sequence can represent.
02720 const UInt32 kMaxCodePoint4 = (static_cast<UInt32>(1) << (3 + 3*6)) - 1;
02721 
02722 // Chops off the n lowest bits from a bit pattern.  Returns the n
02723 // lowest bits.  As a side effect, the original bit pattern will be
02724 // shifted to the right by n bits.
02725 inline UInt32 ChopLowBits(UInt32* bits, int n) {
02726   const UInt32 low_bits = *bits & ((static_cast<UInt32>(1) << n) - 1);
02727   *bits >>= n;
02728   return low_bits;
02729 }
02730 
02731 // Converts a Unicode code point to a narrow string in UTF-8 encoding.
02732 // code_point parameter is of type UInt32 because wchar_t may not be
02733 // wide enough to contain a code point.
02734 // The output buffer str must containt at least 32 characters.
02735 // The function returns the address of the output buffer.
02736 // If the code_point is not a valid Unicode code point
02737 // (i.e. outside of Unicode range U+0 to U+10FFFF) it will be output
02738 // as '(Invalid Unicode 0xXXXXXXXX)'.
02739 char* CodePointToUtf8(UInt32 code_point, char* str) {
02740   if (code_point <= kMaxCodePoint1) {
02741     str[1] = '\0';
02742     str[0] = static_cast<char>(code_point);                          // 0xxxxxxx
02743   } else if (code_point <= kMaxCodePoint2) {
02744     str[2] = '\0';
02745     str[1] = static_cast<char>(0x80 | ChopLowBits(&code_point, 6));  // 10xxxxxx
02746     str[0] = static_cast<char>(0xC0 | code_point);                   // 110xxxxx
02747   } else if (code_point <= kMaxCodePoint3) {
02748     str[3] = '\0';
02749     str[2] = static_cast<char>(0x80 | ChopLowBits(&code_point, 6));  // 10xxxxxx
02750     str[1] = static_cast<char>(0x80 | ChopLowBits(&code_point, 6));  // 10xxxxxx
02751     str[0] = static_cast<char>(0xE0 | code_point);                   // 1110xxxx
02752   } else if (code_point <= kMaxCodePoint4) {
02753     str[4] = '\0';
02754     str[3] = static_cast<char>(0x80 | ChopLowBits(&code_point, 6));  // 10xxxxxx
02755     str[2] = static_cast<char>(0x80 | ChopLowBits(&code_point, 6));  // 10xxxxxx
02756     str[1] = static_cast<char>(0x80 | ChopLowBits(&code_point, 6));  // 10xxxxxx
02757     str[0] = static_cast<char>(0xF0 | code_point);                   // 11110xxx
02758   } else {
02759     // The longest string String::Format can produce when invoked
02760     // with these parameters is 28 character long (not including
02761     // the terminating nul character). We are asking for 32 character
02762     // buffer just in case. This is also enough for strncpy to
02763     // null-terminate the destination string.
02764     posix::StrNCpy(
02765         str, String::Format("(Invalid Unicode 0x%X)", code_point).c_str(), 32);
02766     str[31] = '\0';  // Makes sure no change in the format to strncpy leaves
02767                      // the result unterminated.
02768   }
02769   return str;
02770 }
02771 
02772 // The following two functions only make sense if the the system
02773 // uses UTF-16 for wide string encoding. All supported systems
02774 // with 16 bit wchar_t (Windows, Cygwin, Symbian OS) do use UTF-16.
02775 
02776 // Determines if the arguments constitute UTF-16 surrogate pair
02777 // and thus should be combined into a single Unicode code point
02778 // using CreateCodePointFromUtf16SurrogatePair.
02779 inline bool IsUtf16SurrogatePair(wchar_t first, wchar_t second) {
02780   return sizeof(wchar_t) == 2 &&
02781       (first & 0xFC00) == 0xD800 && (second & 0xFC00) == 0xDC00;
02782 }
02783 
02784 // Creates a Unicode code point from UTF16 surrogate pair.
02785 inline UInt32 CreateCodePointFromUtf16SurrogatePair(wchar_t first,
02786                                                     wchar_t second) {
02787   const UInt32 mask = (1 << 10) - 1;
02788   return (sizeof(wchar_t) == 2) ?
02789       (((first & mask) << 10) | (second & mask)) + 0x10000 :
02790       // This function should not be called when the condition is
02791       // false, but we provide a sensible default in case it is.
02792       static_cast<UInt32>(first);
02793 }
02794 
02795 // Converts a wide string to a narrow string in UTF-8 encoding.
02796 // The wide string is assumed to have the following encoding:
02797 //   UTF-16 if sizeof(wchar_t) == 2 (on Windows, Cygwin, Symbian OS)
02798 //   UTF-32 if sizeof(wchar_t) == 4 (on Linux)
02799 // Parameter str points to a null-terminated wide string.
02800 // Parameter num_chars may additionally limit the number
02801 // of wchar_t characters processed. -1 is used when the entire string
02802 // should be processed.
02803 // If the string contains code points that are not valid Unicode code points
02804 // (i.e. outside of Unicode range U+0 to U+10FFFF) they will be output
02805 // as '(Invalid Unicode 0xXXXXXXXX)'. If the string is in UTF16 encoding
02806 // and contains invalid UTF-16 surrogate pairs, values in those pairs
02807 // will be encoded as individual Unicode characters from Basic Normal Plane.
02808 String WideStringToUtf8(const wchar_t* str, int num_chars) {
02809   if (num_chars == -1)
02810     num_chars = static_cast<int>(wcslen(str));
02811 
02812   ::std::stringstream stream;
02813   for (int i = 0; i < num_chars; ++i) {
02814     UInt32 unicode_code_point;
02815 
02816     if (str[i] == L'\0') {
02817       break;
02818     } else if (i + 1 < num_chars && IsUtf16SurrogatePair(str[i], str[i + 1])) {
02819       unicode_code_point = CreateCodePointFromUtf16SurrogatePair(str[i],
02820                                                                  str[i + 1]);
02821       i++;
02822     } else {
02823       unicode_code_point = static_cast<UInt32>(str[i]);
02824     }
02825 
02826     char buffer[32];  // CodePointToUtf8 requires a buffer this big.
02827     stream << CodePointToUtf8(unicode_code_point, buffer);
02828   }
02829   return StringStreamToString(&stream);
02830 }
02831 
02832 // Converts a wide C string to a String using the UTF-8 encoding.
02833 // NULL will be converted to "(null)".
02834 String String::ShowWideCString(const wchar_t * wide_c_str) {
02835   if (wide_c_str == NULL) return String("(null)");
02836 
02837   return String(internal::WideStringToUtf8(wide_c_str, -1).c_str());
02838 }
02839 
02840 // Similar to ShowWideCString(), except that this function encloses
02841 // the converted string in double quotes.
02842 String String::ShowWideCStringQuoted(const wchar_t* wide_c_str) {
02843   if (wide_c_str == NULL) return String("(null)");
02844 
02845   return String::Format("L\"%s\"",
02846                         String::ShowWideCString(wide_c_str).c_str());
02847 }
02848 
02849 // Compares two wide C strings.  Returns true iff they have the same
02850 // content.
02851 //
02852 // Unlike wcscmp(), this function can handle NULL argument(s).  A NULL
02853 // C string is considered different to any non-NULL C string,
02854 // including the empty string.
02855 bool String::WideCStringEquals(const wchar_t * lhs, const wchar_t * rhs) {
02856   if (lhs == NULL) return rhs == NULL;
02857 
02858   if (rhs == NULL) return false;
02859 
02860   return wcscmp(lhs, rhs) == 0;
02861 }
02862 
02863 // Helper function for *_STREQ on wide strings.
02864 AssertionResult CmpHelperSTREQ(const char* expected_expression,
02865                                const char* actual_expression,
02866                                const wchar_t* expected,
02867                                const wchar_t* actual) {
02868   if (String::WideCStringEquals(expected, actual)) {
02869     return AssertionSuccess();
02870   }
02871 
02872   return EqFailure(expected_expression,
02873                    actual_expression,
02874                    String::ShowWideCStringQuoted(expected),
02875                    String::ShowWideCStringQuoted(actual),
02876                    false);
02877 }
02878 
02879 // Helper function for *_STRNE on wide strings.
02880 AssertionResult CmpHelperSTRNE(const char* s1_expression,
02881                                const char* s2_expression,
02882                                const wchar_t* s1,
02883                                const wchar_t* s2) {
02884   if (!String::WideCStringEquals(s1, s2)) {
02885     return AssertionSuccess();
02886   }
02887 
02888   return AssertionFailure() << "Expected: (" << s1_expression << ") != ("
02889                             << s2_expression << "), actual: "
02890                             << String::ShowWideCStringQuoted(s1)
02891                             << " vs " << String::ShowWideCStringQuoted(s2);
02892 }
02893 
02894 // Compares two C strings, ignoring case.  Returns true iff they have
02895 // the same content.
02896 //
02897 // Unlike strcasecmp(), this function can handle NULL argument(s).  A
02898 // NULL C string is considered different to any non-NULL C string,
02899 // including the empty string.
02900 bool String::CaseInsensitiveCStringEquals(const char * lhs, const char * rhs) {
02901   if (lhs == NULL)
02902     return rhs == NULL;
02903   if (rhs == NULL)
02904     return false;
02905   return posix::StrCaseCmp(lhs, rhs) == 0;
02906 }
02907 
02908   // Compares two wide C strings, ignoring case.  Returns true iff they
02909   // have the same content.
02910   //
02911   // Unlike wcscasecmp(), this function can handle NULL argument(s).
02912   // A NULL C string is considered different to any non-NULL wide C string,
02913   // including the empty string.
02914   // NB: The implementations on different platforms slightly differ.
02915   // On windows, this method uses _wcsicmp which compares according to LC_CTYPE
02916   // environment variable. On GNU platform this method uses wcscasecmp
02917   // which compares according to LC_CTYPE category of the current locale.
02918   // On MacOS X, it uses towlower, which also uses LC_CTYPE category of the
02919   // current locale.
02920 bool String::CaseInsensitiveWideCStringEquals(const wchar_t* lhs,
02921                                               const wchar_t* rhs) {
02922   if (lhs == NULL) return rhs == NULL;
02923 
02924   if (rhs == NULL) return false;
02925 
02926 #if GTEST_OS_WINDOWS
02927   return _wcsicmp(lhs, rhs) == 0;
02928 #elif GTEST_OS_LINUX && !GTEST_OS_LINUX_ANDROID
02929   return wcscasecmp(lhs, rhs) == 0;
02930 #else
02931   // Android, Mac OS X and Cygwin don't define wcscasecmp.
02932   // Other unknown OSes may not define it either.
02933   wint_t left, right;
02934   do {
02935     left = towlower(*lhs++);
02936     right = towlower(*rhs++);
02937   } while (left && left == right);
02938   return left == right;
02939 #endif  // OS selector
02940 }
02941 
02942 // Compares this with another String.
02943 // Returns < 0 if this is less than rhs, 0 if this is equal to rhs, or > 0
02944 // if this is greater than rhs.
02945 int String::Compare(const String & rhs) const {
02946   const char* const lhs_c_str = c_str();
02947   const char* const rhs_c_str = rhs.c_str();
02948 
02949   if (lhs_c_str == NULL) {
02950     return rhs_c_str == NULL ? 0 : -1;  // NULL < anything except NULL
02951   } else if (rhs_c_str == NULL) {
02952     return 1;
02953   }
02954 
02955   const size_t shorter_str_len =
02956       length() <= rhs.length() ? length() : rhs.length();
02957   for (size_t i = 0; i != shorter_str_len; i++) {
02958     if (lhs_c_str[i] < rhs_c_str[i]) {
02959       return -1;
02960     } else if (lhs_c_str[i] > rhs_c_str[i]) {
02961       return 1;
02962     }
02963   }
02964   return (length() < rhs.length()) ? -1 :
02965       (length() > rhs.length()) ? 1 : 0;
02966 }
02967 
02968 // Returns true iff this String ends with the given suffix.  *Any*
02969 // String is considered to end with a NULL or empty suffix.
02970 bool String::EndsWith(const char* suffix) const {
02971   if (suffix == NULL || CStringEquals(suffix, "")) return true;
02972 
02973   if (c_str() == NULL) return false;
02974 
02975   const size_t this_len = strlen(c_str());
02976   const size_t suffix_len = strlen(suffix);
02977   return (this_len >= suffix_len) &&
02978          CStringEquals(c_str() + this_len - suffix_len, suffix);
02979 }
02980 
02981 // Returns true iff this String ends with the given suffix, ignoring case.
02982 // Any String is considered to end with a NULL or empty suffix.
02983 bool String::EndsWithCaseInsensitive(const char* suffix) const {
02984   if (suffix == NULL || CStringEquals(suffix, "")) return true;
02985 
02986   if (c_str() == NULL) return false;
02987 
02988   const size_t this_len = strlen(c_str());
02989   const size_t suffix_len = strlen(suffix);
02990   return (this_len >= suffix_len) &&
02991          CaseInsensitiveCStringEquals(c_str() + this_len - suffix_len, suffix);
02992 }
02993 
02994 // Formats a list of arguments to a String, using the same format
02995 // spec string as for printf.
02996 //
02997 // We do not use the StringPrintf class as it is not universally
02998 // available.
02999 //
03000 // The result is limited to 4096 characters (including the tailing 0).
03001 // If 4096 characters are not enough to format the input, or if
03002 // there's an error, "<formatting error or buffer exceeded>" is
03003 // returned.
03004 String String::Format(const char * format, ...) {
03005   va_list args;
03006   va_start(args, format);
03007 
03008   char buffer[4096];
03009   const int kBufferSize = sizeof(buffer)/sizeof(buffer[0]);
03010 
03011   // MSVC 8 deprecates vsnprintf(), so we want to suppress warning
03012   // 4996 (deprecated function) there.
03013 #ifdef _MSC_VER  // We are using MSVC.
03014 # pragma warning(push)          // Saves the current warning state.
03015 # pragma warning(disable:4996)  // Temporarily disables warning 4996.
03016 
03017   const int size = vsnprintf(buffer, kBufferSize, format, args);
03018 
03019 # pragma warning(pop)           // Restores the warning state.
03020 #else  // We are not using MSVC.
03021   const int size = vsnprintf(buffer, kBufferSize, format, args);
03022 #endif  // _MSC_VER
03023   va_end(args);
03024 
03025   // vsnprintf()'s behavior is not portable.  When the buffer is not
03026   // big enough, it returns a negative value in MSVC, and returns the
03027   // needed buffer size on Linux.  When there is an output error, it
03028   // always returns a negative value.  For simplicity, we lump the two
03029   // error cases together.
03030   if (size < 0 || size >= kBufferSize) {
03031     return String("<formatting error or buffer exceeded>");
03032   } else {
03033     return String(buffer, size);
03034   }
03035 }
03036 
03037 // Converts the buffer in a stringstream to a String, converting NUL
03038 // bytes to "\\0" along the way.
03039 String StringStreamToString(::std::stringstream* ss) {
03040   const ::std::string& str = ss->str();
03041   const char* const start = str.c_str();
03042   const char* const end = start + str.length();
03043 
03044   // We need to use a helper stringstream to do this transformation
03045   // because String doesn't support push_back().
03046   ::std::stringstream helper;
03047   for (const char* ch = start; ch != end; ++ch) {
03048     if (*ch == '\0') {
03049       helper << "\\0";  // Replaces NUL with "\\0";
03050     } else {
03051       helper.put(*ch);
03052     }
03053   }
03054 
03055   return String(helper.str().c_str());
03056 }
03057 
03058 // Appends the user-supplied message to the Google-Test-generated message.
03059 String AppendUserMessage(const String& gtest_msg,
03060                          const Message& user_msg) {
03061   // Appends the user message if it's non-empty.
03062   const String user_msg_string = user_msg.GetString();
03063   if (user_msg_string.empty()) {
03064     return gtest_msg;
03065   }
03066 
03067   Message msg;
03068   msg << gtest_msg << "\n" << user_msg_string;
03069 
03070   return msg.GetString();
03071 }
03072 
03073 }  // namespace internal
03074 
03075 // class TestResult
03076 
03077 // Creates an empty TestResult.
03078 TestResult::TestResult()
03079     : death_test_count_(0),
03080       elapsed_time_(0) {
03081 }
03082 
03083 // D'tor.
03084 TestResult::~TestResult() {
03085 }
03086 
03087 // Returns the i-th test part result among all the results. i can
03088 // range from 0 to total_part_count() - 1. If i is not in that range,
03089 // aborts the program.
03090 const TestPartResult& TestResult::GetTestPartResult(int i) const {
03091   if (i < 0 || i >= total_part_count())
03092     internal::posix::Abort();
03093   return test_part_results_.at(i);
03094 }
03095 
03096 // Returns the i-th test property. i can range from 0 to
03097 // test_property_count() - 1. If i is not in that range, aborts the
03098 // program.
03099 const TestProperty& TestResult::GetTestProperty(int i) const {
03100   if (i < 0 || i >= test_property_count())
03101     internal::posix::Abort();
03102   return test_properties_.at(i);
03103 }
03104 
03105 // Clears the test part results.
03106 void TestResult::ClearTestPartResults() {
03107   test_part_results_.clear();
03108 }
03109 
03110 // Adds a test part result to the list.
03111 void TestResult::AddTestPartResult(const TestPartResult& test_part_result) {
03112   test_part_results_.push_back(test_part_result);
03113 }
03114 
03115 // Adds a test property to the list. If a property with the same key as the
03116 // supplied property is already represented, the value of this test_property
03117 // replaces the old value for that key.
03118 void TestResult::RecordProperty(const TestProperty& test_property) {
03119   if (!ValidateTestProperty(test_property)) {
03120     return;
03121   }
03122   internal::MutexLock lock(&test_properites_mutex_);
03123   const std::vector<TestProperty>::iterator property_with_matching_key =
03124       std::find_if(test_properties_.begin(), test_properties_.end(),
03125                    internal::TestPropertyKeyIs(test_property.key()));
03126   if (property_with_matching_key == test_properties_.end()) {
03127     test_properties_.push_back(test_property);
03128     return;
03129   }
03130   property_with_matching_key->SetValue(test_property.value());
03131 }
03132 
03133 // Adds a failure if the key is a reserved attribute of Google Test
03134 // testcase tags.  Returns true if the property is valid.
03135 bool TestResult::ValidateTestProperty(const TestProperty& test_property) {
03136   internal::String key(test_property.key());
03137   if (key == "name" || key == "status" || key == "time" || key == "classname") {
03138     ADD_FAILURE()
03139         << "Reserved key used in RecordProperty(): "
03140         << key
03141         << " ('name', 'status', 'time', and 'classname' are reserved by "
03142         << GTEST_NAME_ << ")";
03143     return false;
03144   }
03145   return true;
03146 }
03147 
03148 // Clears the object.
03149 void TestResult::Clear() {
03150   test_part_results_.clear();
03151   test_properties_.clear();
03152   death_test_count_ = 0;
03153   elapsed_time_ = 0;
03154 }
03155 
03156 // Returns true iff the test failed.
03157 bool TestResult::Failed() const {
03158   for (int i = 0; i < total_part_count(); ++i) {
03159     if (GetTestPartResult(i).failed())
03160       return true;
03161   }
03162   return false;
03163 }
03164 
03165 // Returns true iff the test part fatally failed.
03166 static bool TestPartFatallyFailed(const TestPartResult& result) {
03167   return result.fatally_failed();
03168 }
03169 
03170 // Returns true iff the test fatally failed.
03171 bool TestResult::HasFatalFailure() const {
03172   return CountIf(test_part_results_, TestPartFatallyFailed) > 0;
03173 }
03174 
03175 // Returns true iff the test part non-fatally failed.
03176 static bool TestPartNonfatallyFailed(const TestPartResult& result) {
03177   return result.nonfatally_failed();
03178 }
03179 
03180 // Returns true iff the test has a non-fatal failure.
03181 bool TestResult::HasNonfatalFailure() const {
03182   return CountIf(test_part_results_, TestPartNonfatallyFailed) > 0;
03183 }
03184 
03185 // Gets the number of all test parts.  This is the sum of the number
03186 // of successful test parts and the number of failed test parts.
03187 int TestResult::total_part_count() const {
03188   return static_cast<int>(test_part_results_.size());
03189 }
03190 
03191 // Returns the number of the test properties.
03192 int TestResult::test_property_count() const {
03193   return static_cast<int>(test_properties_.size());
03194 }
03195 
03196 // class Test
03197 
03198 // Creates a Test object.
03199 
03200 // The c'tor saves the values of all Google Test flags.
03201 Test::Test()
03202     : gtest_flag_saver_(new internal::GTestFlagSaver) {
03203 }
03204 
03205 // The d'tor restores the values of all Google Test flags.
03206 Test::~Test() {
03207   delete gtest_flag_saver_;
03208 }
03209 
03210 // Sets up the test fixture.
03211 //
03212 // A sub-class may override this.
03213 void Test::SetUp() {
03214 }
03215 
03216 // Tears down the test fixture.
03217 //
03218 // A sub-class may override this.
03219 void Test::TearDown() {
03220 }
03221 
03222 // Allows user supplied key value pairs to be recorded for later output.
03223 void Test::RecordProperty(const char* key, const char* value) {
03224   UnitTest::GetInstance()->RecordPropertyForCurrentTest(key, value);
03225 }
03226 
03227 // Allows user supplied key value pairs to be recorded for later output.
03228 void Test::RecordProperty(const char* key, int value) {
03229   Message value_message;
03230   value_message << value;
03231   RecordProperty(key, value_message.GetString().c_str());
03232 }
03233 
03234 namespace internal {
03235 
03236 void ReportFailureInUnknownLocation(TestPartResult::Type result_type,
03237                                     const String& message) {
03238   // This function is a friend of UnitTest and as such has access to
03239   // AddTestPartResult.
03240   UnitTest::GetInstance()->AddTestPartResult(
03241       result_type,
03242       NULL,  // No info about the source file where the exception occurred.
03243       -1,    // We have no info on which line caused the exception.
03244       message,
03245       String());  // No stack trace, either.
03246 }
03247 
03248 }  // namespace internal
03249 
03250 // Google Test requires all tests in the same test case to use the same test
03251 // fixture class.  This function checks if the current test has the
03252 // same fixture class as the first test in the current test case.  If
03253 // yes, it returns true; otherwise it generates a Google Test failure and
03254 // returns false.
03255 bool Test::HasSameFixtureClass() {
03256   internal::UnitTestImpl* const impl = internal::GetUnitTestImpl();
03257   const TestCase* const test_case = impl->current_test_case();
03258 
03259   // Info about the first test in the current test case.
03260   const TestInfo* const first_test_info = test_case->test_info_list()[0];
03261   const internal::TypeId first_fixture_id = first_test_info->fixture_class_id_;
03262   const char* const first_test_name = first_test_info->name();
03263 
03264   // Info about the current test.
03265   const TestInfo* const this_test_info = impl->current_test_info();
03266   const internal::TypeId this_fixture_id = this_test_info->fixture_class_id_;
03267   const char* const this_test_name = this_test_info->name();
03268 
03269   if (this_fixture_id != first_fixture_id) {
03270     // Is the first test defined using TEST?
03271     const bool first_is_TEST = first_fixture_id == internal::GetTestTypeId();
03272     // Is this test defined using TEST?
03273     const bool this_is_TEST = this_fixture_id == internal::GetTestTypeId();
03274 
03275     if (first_is_TEST || this_is_TEST) {
03276       // The user mixed TEST and TEST_F in this test case - we'll tell
03277       // him/her how to fix it.
03278 
03279       // Gets the name of the TEST and the name of the TEST_F.  Note
03280       // that first_is_TEST and this_is_TEST cannot both be true, as
03281       // the fixture IDs are different for the two tests.
03282       const char* const TEST_name =
03283           first_is_TEST ? first_test_name : this_test_name;
03284       const char* const TEST_F_name =
03285           first_is_TEST ? this_test_name : first_test_name;
03286 
03287       ADD_FAILURE()
03288           << "All tests in the same test case must use the same test fixture\n"
03289           << "class, so mixing TEST_F and TEST in the same test case is\n"
03290           << "illegal.  In test case " << this_test_info->test_case_name()
03291           << ",\n"
03292           << "test " << TEST_F_name << " is defined using TEST_F but\n"
03293           << "test " << TEST_name << " is defined using TEST.  You probably\n"
03294           << "want to change the TEST to TEST_F or move it to another test\n"
03295           << "case.";
03296     } else {
03297       // The user defined two fixture classes with the same name in
03298       // two namespaces - we'll tell him/her how to fix it.
03299       ADD_FAILURE()
03300           << "All tests in the same test case must use the same test fixture\n"
03301           << "class.  However, in test case "
03302           << this_test_info->test_case_name() << ",\n"
03303           << "you defined test " << first_test_name
03304           << " and test " << this_test_name << "\n"
03305           << "using two different test fixture classes.  This can happen if\n"
03306           << "the two classes are from different namespaces or translation\n"
03307           << "units and have the same name.  You should probably rename one\n"
03308           << "of the classes to put the tests into different test cases.";
03309     }
03310     return false;
03311   }
03312 
03313   return true;
03314 }
03315 
03316 #if GTEST_HAS_SEH
03317 
03318 // Adds an "exception thrown" fatal failure to the current test.  This
03319 // function returns its result via an output parameter pointer because VC++
03320 // prohibits creation of objects with destructors on stack in functions
03321 // using __try (see error C2712).
03322 static internal::String* FormatSehExceptionMessage(DWORD exception_code,
03323                                                    const char* location) {
03324   Message message;
03325   message << "SEH exception with code 0x" << std::setbase(16) <<
03326     exception_code << std::setbase(10) << " thrown in " << location << ".";
03327 
03328   return new internal::String(message.GetString());
03329 }
03330 
03331 #endif  // GTEST_HAS_SEH
03332 
03333 #if GTEST_HAS_EXCEPTIONS
03334 
03335 // Adds an "exception thrown" fatal failure to the current test.
03336 static internal::String FormatCxxExceptionMessage(const char* description,
03337                                                   const char* location) {
03338   Message message;
03339   if (description != NULL) {
03340     message << "C++ exception with description \"" << description << "\"";
03341   } else {
03342     message << "Unknown C++ exception";
03343   }
03344   message << " thrown in " << location << ".";
03345 
03346   return message.GetString();
03347 }
03348 
03349 static internal::String PrintTestPartResultToString(
03350     const TestPartResult& test_part_result);
03351 
03352 // A failed Google Test assertion will throw an exception of this type when
03353 // GTEST_FLAG(throw_on_failure) is true (if exceptions are enabled).  We
03354 // derive it from std::runtime_error, which is for errors presumably
03355 // detectable only at run time.  Since std::runtime_error inherits from
03356 // std::exception, many testing frameworks know how to extract and print the
03357 // message inside it.
03358 class GoogleTestFailureException : public ::std::runtime_error {
03359  public:
03360   explicit GoogleTestFailureException(const TestPartResult& failure)
03361       : ::std::runtime_error(PrintTestPartResultToString(failure).c_str()) {}
03362 };
03363 #endif  // GTEST_HAS_EXCEPTIONS
03364 
03365 namespace internal {
03366 // We put these helper functions in the internal namespace as IBM's xlC
03367 // compiler rejects the code if they were declared static.
03368 
03369 // Runs the given method and handles SEH exceptions it throws, when
03370 // SEH is supported; returns the 0-value for type Result in case of an
03371 // SEH exception.  (Microsoft compilers cannot handle SEH and C++
03372 // exceptions in the same function.  Therefore, we provide a separate
03373 // wrapper function for handling SEH exceptions.)
03374 template <class T, typename Result>
03375 Result HandleSehExceptionsInMethodIfSupported(
03376     T* object, Result (T::*method)(), const char* location) {
03377 #if GTEST_HAS_SEH
03378   __try {
03379     return (object->*method)();
03380   } __except (internal::UnitTestOptions::GTestShouldProcessSEH(  // NOLINT
03381       GetExceptionCode())) {
03382     // We create the exception message on the heap because VC++ prohibits
03383     // creation of objects with destructors on stack in functions using __try
03384     // (see error C2712).
03385     internal::String* exception_message = FormatSehExceptionMessage(
03386         GetExceptionCode(), location);
03387     internal::ReportFailureInUnknownLocation(TestPartResult::kFatalFailure,
03388                                              *exception_message);
03389     delete exception_message;
03390     return static_cast<Result>(0);
03391   }
03392 #else
03393   (void)location;
03394   return (object->*method)();
03395 #endif  // GTEST_HAS_SEH
03396 }
03397 
03398 // Runs the given method and catches and reports C++ and/or SEH-style
03399 // exceptions, if they are supported; returns the 0-value for type
03400 // Result in case of an SEH exception.
03401 template <class T, typename Result>
03402 Result HandleExceptionsInMethodIfSupported(
03403     T* object, Result (T::*method)(), const char* location) {
03404   // NOTE: The user code can affect the way in which Google Test handles
03405   // exceptions by setting GTEST_FLAG(catch_exceptions), but only before
03406   // RUN_ALL_TESTS() starts. It is technically possible to check the flag
03407   // after the exception is caught and either report or re-throw the
03408   // exception based on the flag's value:
03409   //
03410   // try {
03411   //   // Perform the test method.
03412   // } catch (...) {
03413   //   if (GTEST_FLAG(catch_exceptions))
03414   //     // Report the exception as failure.
03415   //   else
03416   //     throw;  // Re-throws the original exception.
03417   // }
03418   //
03419   // However, the purpose of this flag is to allow the program to drop into
03420   // the debugger when the exception is thrown. On most platforms, once the
03421   // control enters the catch block, the exception origin information is
03422   // lost and the debugger will stop the program at the point of the
03423   // re-throw in this function -- instead of at the point of the original
03424   // throw statement in the code under test.  For this reason, we perform
03425   // the check early, sacrificing the ability to affect Google Test's
03426   // exception handling in the method where the exception is thrown.
03427   if (internal::GetUnitTestImpl()->catch_exceptions()) {
03428 #if GTEST_HAS_EXCEPTIONS
03429     try {
03430       return HandleSehExceptionsInMethodIfSupported(object, method, location);
03431     } catch (const GoogleTestFailureException&) {  // NOLINT
03432       // This exception doesn't originate in code under test. It makes no
03433       // sense to report it as a test failure.
03434       throw;
03435     } catch (const std::exception& e) {  // NOLINT
03436       internal::ReportFailureInUnknownLocation(
03437           TestPartResult::kFatalFailure,
03438           FormatCxxExceptionMessage(e.what(), location));
03439     } catch (...) {  // NOLINT
03440       internal::ReportFailureInUnknownLocation(
03441           TestPartResult::kFatalFailure,
03442           FormatCxxExceptionMessage(NULL, location));
03443     }
03444     return static_cast<Result>(0);
03445 #else
03446     return HandleSehExceptionsInMethodIfSupported(object, method, location);
03447 #endif  // GTEST_HAS_EXCEPTIONS
03448   } else {
03449     return (object->*method)();
03450   }
03451 }
03452 
03453 }  // namespace internal
03454 
03455 // Runs the test and updates the test result.
03456 void Test::Run() {
03457   if (!HasSameFixtureClass()) return;
03458 
03459   internal::UnitTestImpl* const impl = internal::GetUnitTestImpl();
03460   impl->os_stack_trace_getter()->UponLeavingGTest();
03461   internal::HandleExceptionsInMethodIfSupported(this, &Test::SetUp, "SetUp()");
03462   // We will run the test only if SetUp() was successful.
03463   if (!HasFatalFailure()) {
03464     impl->os_stack_trace_getter()->UponLeavingGTest();
03465     internal::HandleExceptionsInMethodIfSupported(
03466         this, &Test::TestBody, "the test body");
03467   }
03468 
03469   // However, we want to clean up as much as possible.  Hence we will
03470   // always call TearDown(), even if SetUp() or the test body has
03471   // failed.
03472   impl->os_stack_trace_getter()->UponLeavingGTest();
03473   internal::HandleExceptionsInMethodIfSupported(
03474       this, &Test::TearDown, "TearDown()");
03475 }
03476 
03477 // Returns true iff the current test has a fatal failure.
03478 bool Test::HasFatalFailure() {
03479   return internal::GetUnitTestImpl()->current_test_result()->HasFatalFailure();
03480 }
03481 
03482 // Returns true iff the current test has a non-fatal failure.
03483 bool Test::HasNonfatalFailure() {
03484   return internal::GetUnitTestImpl()->current_test_result()->
03485       HasNonfatalFailure();
03486 }
03487 
03488 // class TestInfo
03489 
03490 // Constructs a TestInfo object. It assumes ownership of the test factory
03491 // object.
03492 // TODO(vladl@google.com): Make a_test_case_name and a_name const string&'s
03493 // to signify they cannot be NULLs.
03494 TestInfo::TestInfo(const char* a_test_case_name,
03495                    const char* a_name,
03496                    const char* a_type_param,
03497                    const char* a_value_param,
03498                    internal::TypeId fixture_class_id,
03499                    internal::TestFactoryBase* factory)
03500     : test_case_name_(a_test_case_name),
03501       name_(a_name),
03502       type_param_(a_type_param ? new std::string(a_type_param) : NULL),
03503       value_param_(a_value_param ? new std::string(a_value_param) : NULL),
03504       fixture_class_id_(fixture_class_id),
03505       should_run_(false),
03506       is_disabled_(false),
03507       matches_filter_(false),
03508       factory_(factory),
03509       result_() {}
03510 
03511 // Destructs a TestInfo object.
03512 TestInfo::~TestInfo() { delete factory_; }
03513 
03514 namespace internal {
03515 
03516 // Creates a new TestInfo object and registers it with Google Test;
03517 // returns the created object.
03518 //
03519 // Arguments:
03520 //
03521 //   test_case_name:   name of the test case
03522 //   name:             name of the test
03523 //   type_param:       the name of the test's type parameter, or NULL if
03524 //                     this is not a typed or a type-parameterized test.
03525 //   value_param:      text representation of the test's value parameter,
03526 //                     or NULL if this is not a value-parameterized test.
03527 //   fixture_class_id: ID of the test fixture class
03528 //   set_up_tc:        pointer to the function that sets up the test case
03529 //   tear_down_tc:     pointer to the function that tears down the test case
03530 //   factory:          pointer to the factory that creates a test object.
03531 //                     The newly created TestInfo instance will assume
03532 //                     ownership of the factory object.
03533 TestInfo* MakeAndRegisterTestInfo(
03534     const char* test_case_name, const char* name,
03535     const char* type_param,
03536     const char* value_param,
03537     TypeId fixture_class_id,
03538     SetUpTestCaseFunc set_up_tc,
03539     TearDownTestCaseFunc tear_down_tc,
03540     TestFactoryBase* factory) {
03541   TestInfo* const test_info =
03542       new TestInfo(test_case_name, name, type_param, value_param,
03543                    fixture_class_id, factory);
03544   GetUnitTestImpl()->AddTestInfo(set_up_tc, tear_down_tc, test_info);
03545   return test_info;
03546 }
03547 
03548 #if GTEST_HAS_PARAM_TEST
03549 void ReportInvalidTestCaseType(const char* test_case_name,
03550                                const char* file, int line) {
03551   Message errors;
03552   errors
03553       << "Attempted redefinition of test case " << test_case_name << ".\n"
03554       << "All tests in the same test case must use the same test fixture\n"
03555       << "class.  However, in test case " << test_case_name << ", you tried\n"
03556       << "to define a test using a fixture class different from the one\n"
03557       << "used earlier. This can happen if the two fixture classes are\n"
03558       << "from different namespaces and have the same name. You should\n"
03559       << "probably rename one of the classes to put the tests into different\n"
03560       << "test cases.";
03561 
03562   fprintf(stderr, "%s %s", FormatFileLocation(file, line).c_str(),
03563           errors.GetString().c_str());
03564 }
03565 #endif  // GTEST_HAS_PARAM_TEST
03566 
03567 }  // namespace internal
03568 
03569 namespace {
03570 
03571 // A predicate that checks the test name of a TestInfo against a known
03572 // value.
03573 //
03574 // This is used for implementation of the TestCase class only.  We put
03575 // it in the anonymous namespace to prevent polluting the outer
03576 // namespace.
03577 //
03578 // TestNameIs is copyable.
03579 class TestNameIs {
03580  public:
03581   // Constructor.
03582   //
03583   // TestNameIs has NO default constructor.
03584   explicit TestNameIs(const char* name)
03585       : name_(name) {}
03586 
03587   // Returns true iff the test name of test_info matches name_.
03588   bool operator()(const TestInfo * test_info) const {
03589     return test_info && internal::String(test_info->name()).Compare(name_) == 0;
03590   }
03591 
03592  private:
03593   internal::String name_;
03594 };
03595 
03596 }  // namespace
03597 
03598 namespace internal {
03599 
03600 // This method expands all parameterized tests registered with macros TEST_P
03601 // and INSTANTIATE_TEST_CASE_P into regular tests and registers those.
03602 // This will be done just once during the program runtime.
03603 void UnitTestImpl::RegisterParameterizedTests() {
03604 #if GTEST_HAS_PARAM_TEST
03605   if (!parameterized_tests_registered_) {
03606     parameterized_test_registry_.RegisterTests();
03607     parameterized_tests_registered_ = true;
03608   }
03609 #endif
03610 }
03611 
03612 }  // namespace internal
03613 
03614 // Creates the test object, runs it, records its result, and then
03615 // deletes it.
03616 void TestInfo::Run() {
03617   if (!should_run_) return;
03618 
03619   // Tells UnitTest where to store test result.
03620   internal::UnitTestImpl* const impl = internal::GetUnitTestImpl();
03621   impl->set_current_test_info(this);
03622 
03623   TestEventListener* repeater = UnitTest::GetInstance()->listeners().repeater();
03624 
03625   // Notifies the unit test event listeners that a test is about to start.
03626   repeater->OnTestStart(*this);
03627 
03628   const TimeInMillis start = internal::GetTimeInMillis();
03629 
03630   impl->os_stack_trace_getter()->UponLeavingGTest();
03631 
03632   // Creates the test object.
03633   Test* const test = internal::HandleExceptionsInMethodIfSupported(
03634       factory_, &internal::TestFactoryBase::CreateTest,
03635       "the test fixture's constructor");
03636 
03637   // Runs the test only if the test object was created and its
03638   // constructor didn't generate a fatal failure.
03639   if ((test != NULL) && !Test::HasFatalFailure()) {
03640     // This doesn't throw as all user code that can throw are wrapped into
03641     // exception handling code.
03642     test->Run();
03643   }
03644 
03645   // Deletes the test object.
03646   impl->os_stack_trace_getter()->UponLeavingGTest();
03647   internal::HandleExceptionsInMethodIfSupported(
03648       test, &Test::DeleteSelf_, "the test fixture's destructor");
03649 
03650   result_.set_elapsed_time(internal::GetTimeInMillis() - start);
03651 
03652   // Notifies the unit test event listener that a test has just finished.
03653   repeater->OnTestEnd(*this);
03654 
03655   // Tells UnitTest to stop associating assertion results to this
03656   // test.
03657   impl->set_current_test_info(NULL);
03658 }
03659 
03660 // class TestCase
03661 
03662 // Gets the number of successful tests in this test case.
03663 int TestCase::successful_test_count() const {
03664   return CountIf(test_info_list_, TestPassed);
03665 }
03666 
03667 // Gets the number of failed tests in this test case.
03668 int TestCase::failed_test_count() const {
03669   return CountIf(test_info_list_, TestFailed);
03670 }
03671 
03672 int TestCase::disabled_test_count() const {
03673   return CountIf(test_info_list_, TestDisabled);
03674 }
03675 
03676 // Get the number of tests in this test case that should run.
03677 int TestCase::test_to_run_count() const {
03678   return CountIf(test_info_list_, ShouldRunTest);
03679 }
03680 
03681 // Gets the number of all tests.
03682 int TestCase::total_test_count() const {
03683   return static_cast<int>(test_info_list_.size());
03684 }
03685 
03686 // Creates a TestCase with the given name.
03687 //
03688 // Arguments:
03689 //
03690 //   name:         name of the test case
03691 //   a_type_param: the name of the test case's type parameter, or NULL if
03692 //                 this is not a typed or a type-parameterized test case.
03693 //   set_up_tc:    pointer to the function that sets up the test case
03694 //   tear_down_tc: pointer to the function that tears down the test case
03695 TestCase::TestCase(const char* a_name, const char* a_type_param,
03696                    Test::SetUpTestCaseFunc set_up_tc,
03697                    Test::TearDownTestCaseFunc tear_down_tc)
03698     : name_(a_name),
03699       type_param_(a_type_param ? new std::string(a_type_param) : NULL),
03700       set_up_tc_(set_up_tc),
03701       tear_down_tc_(tear_down_tc),
03702       should_run_(false),
03703       elapsed_time_(0) {
03704 }
03705 
03706 // Destructor of TestCase.
03707 TestCase::~TestCase() {
03708   // Deletes every Test in the collection.
03709   ForEach(test_info_list_, internal::Delete<TestInfo>);
03710 }
03711 
03712 // Returns the i-th test among all the tests. i can range from 0 to
03713 // total_test_count() - 1. If i is not in that range, returns NULL.
03714 const TestInfo* TestCase::GetTestInfo(int i) const {
03715   const int index = GetElementOr(test_indices_, i, -1);
03716   return index < 0 ? NULL : test_info_list_[index];
03717 }
03718 
03719 // Returns the i-th test among all the tests. i can range from 0 to
03720 // total_test_count() - 1. If i is not in that range, returns NULL.
03721 TestInfo* TestCase::GetMutableTestInfo(int i) {
03722   const int index = GetElementOr(test_indices_, i, -1);
03723   return index < 0 ? NULL : test_info_list_[index];
03724 }
03725 
03726 // Adds a test to this test case.  Will delete the test upon
03727 // destruction of the TestCase object.
03728 void TestCase::AddTestInfo(TestInfo * test_info) {
03729   test_info_list_.push_back(test_info);
03730   test_indices_.push_back(static_cast<int>(test_indices_.size()));
03731 }
03732 
03733 // Runs every test in this TestCase.
03734 void TestCase::Run() {
03735   if (!should_run_) return;
03736 
03737   internal::UnitTestImpl* const impl = internal::GetUnitTestImpl();
03738   impl->set_current_test_case(this);
03739 
03740   TestEventListener* repeater = UnitTest::GetInstance()->listeners().repeater();
03741 
03742   repeater->OnTestCaseStart(*this);
03743   impl->os_stack_trace_getter()->UponLeavingGTest();
03744   internal::HandleExceptionsInMethodIfSupported(
03745       this, &TestCase::RunSetUpTestCase, "SetUpTestCase()");
03746 
03747   const internal::TimeInMillis start = internal::GetTimeInMillis();
03748   for (int i = 0; i < total_test_count(); i++) {
03749     GetMutableTestInfo(i)->Run();
03750   }
03751   elapsed_time_ = internal::GetTimeInMillis() - start;
03752 
03753   impl->os_stack_trace_getter()->UponLeavingGTest();
03754   internal::HandleExceptionsInMethodIfSupported(
03755       this, &TestCase::RunTearDownTestCase, "TearDownTestCase()");
03756 
03757   repeater->OnTestCaseEnd(*this);
03758   impl->set_current_test_case(NULL);
03759 }
03760 
03761 // Clears the results of all tests in this test case.
03762 void TestCase::ClearResult() {
03763   ForEach(test_info_list_, TestInfo::ClearTestResult);
03764 }
03765 
03766 // Shuffles the tests in this test case.
03767 void TestCase::ShuffleTests(internal::Random* random) {
03768   Shuffle(random, &test_indices_);
03769 }
03770 
03771 // Restores the test order to before the first shuffle.
03772 void TestCase::UnshuffleTests() {
03773   for (size_t i = 0; i < test_indices_.size(); i++) {
03774     test_indices_[i] = static_cast<int>(i);
03775   }
03776 }
03777 
03778 // Formats a countable noun.  Depending on its quantity, either the
03779 // singular form or the plural form is used. e.g.
03780 //
03781 // FormatCountableNoun(1, "formula", "formuli") returns "1 formula".
03782 // FormatCountableNoun(5, "book", "books") returns "5 books".
03783 static internal::String FormatCountableNoun(int count,
03784                                             const char * singular_form,
03785                                             const char * plural_form) {
03786   return internal::String::Format("%d %s", count,
03787                                   count == 1 ? singular_form : plural_form);
03788 }
03789 
03790 // Formats the count of tests.
03791 static internal::String FormatTestCount(int test_count) {
03792   return FormatCountableNoun(test_count, "test", "tests");
03793 }
03794 
03795 // Formats the count of test cases.
03796 static internal::String FormatTestCaseCount(int test_case_count) {
03797   return FormatCountableNoun(test_case_count, "test case", "test cases");
03798 }
03799 
03800 // Converts a TestPartResult::Type enum to human-friendly string
03801 // representation.  Both kNonFatalFailure and kFatalFailure are translated
03802 // to "Failure", as the user usually doesn't care about the difference
03803 // between the two when viewing the test result.
03804 static const char * TestPartResultTypeToString(TestPartResult::Type type) {
03805   switch (type) {
03806     case TestPartResult::kSuccess:
03807       return "Success";
03808 
03809     case TestPartResult::kNonFatalFailure:
03810     case TestPartResult::kFatalFailure:
03811 #ifdef _MSC_VER
03812       return "error: ";
03813 #else
03814       return "Failure\n";
03815 #endif
03816     default:
03817       return "Unknown result type";
03818   }
03819 }
03820 
03821 // Prints a TestPartResult to a String.
03822 static internal::String PrintTestPartResultToString(
03823     const TestPartResult& test_part_result) {
03824   return (Message()
03825           << internal::FormatFileLocation(test_part_result.file_name(),
03826                                           test_part_result.line_number())
03827           << " " << TestPartResultTypeToString(test_part_result.type())
03828           << test_part_result.message()).GetString();
03829 }
03830 
03831 // Prints a TestPartResult.
03832 static void PrintTestPartResult(const TestPartResult& test_part_result) {
03833   const internal::String& result =
03834       PrintTestPartResultToString(test_part_result);
03835   printf("%s\n", result.c_str());
03836   fflush(stdout);
03837   // If the test program runs in Visual Studio or a debugger, the
03838   // following statements add the test part result message to the Output
03839   // window such that the user can double-click on it to jump to the
03840   // corresponding source code location; otherwise they do nothing.
03841 #if GTEST_OS_WINDOWS && !GTEST_OS_WINDOWS_MOBILE
03842   // We don't call OutputDebugString*() on Windows Mobile, as printing
03843   // to stdout is done by OutputDebugString() there already - we don't
03844   // want the same message printed twice.
03845   ::OutputDebugStringA(result.c_str());
03846   ::OutputDebugStringA("\n");
03847 #endif
03848 }
03849 
03850 // class PrettyUnitTestResultPrinter
03851 
03852 namespace internal {
03853 
03854 enum GTestColor {
03855   COLOR_DEFAULT,
03856   COLOR_RED,
03857   COLOR_GREEN,
03858   COLOR_YELLOW
03859 };
03860 
03861 #if GTEST_OS_WINDOWS && !GTEST_OS_WINDOWS_MOBILE
03862 
03863 // Returns the character attribute for the given color.
03864 WORD GetColorAttribute(GTestColor color) {
03865   switch (color) {
03866     case COLOR_RED:    return FOREGROUND_RED;
03867     case COLOR_GREEN:  return FOREGROUND_GREEN;
03868     case COLOR_YELLOW: return FOREGROUND_RED | FOREGROUND_GREEN;
03869     default:           return 0;
03870   }
03871 }
03872 
03873 #else
03874 
03875 // Returns the ANSI color code for the given color.  COLOR_DEFAULT is
03876 // an invalid input.
03877 const char* GetAnsiColorCode(GTestColor color) {
03878   switch (color) {
03879     case COLOR_RED:     return "1";
03880     case COLOR_GREEN:   return "2";
03881     case COLOR_YELLOW:  return "3";
03882     default:            return NULL;
03883   };
03884 }
03885 
03886 #endif  // GTEST_OS_WINDOWS && !GTEST_OS_WINDOWS_MOBILE
03887 
03888 // Returns true iff Google Test should use colors in the output.
03889 bool ShouldUseColor(bool stdout_is_tty) {
03890   const char* const gtest_color = GTEST_FLAG(color).c_str();
03891 
03892   if (String::CaseInsensitiveCStringEquals(gtest_color, "auto")) {
03893 #if GTEST_OS_WINDOWS
03894     // On Windows the TERM variable is usually not set, but the
03895     // console there does support colors.
03896     return stdout_is_tty;
03897 #else
03898     // On non-Windows platforms, we rely on the TERM variable.
03899     const char* const term = posix::GetEnv("TERM");
03900     const bool term_supports_color =
03901         String::CStringEquals(term, "xterm") ||
03902         String::CStringEquals(term, "xterm-color") ||
03903         String::CStringEquals(term, "xterm-256color") ||
03904         String::CStringEquals(term, "screen") ||
03905         String::CStringEquals(term, "linux") ||
