05771 OsStackTraceGetterInterface* UnitTestImpl::os_stack_trace_getter() {
05772   if (os_stack_trace_getter_ == NULL) {
05773     os_stack_trace_getter_ = new OsStackTraceGetter;
05774   }
05775 
05776   return os_stack_trace_getter_;
05777 }
05778 
05779 // Returns the TestResult for the test that's currently running, or
05780 // the TestResult for the ad hoc test if no test is running.
05781 TestResult* UnitTestImpl::current_test_result() {
05782   return current_test_info_ ?
05783       &(current_test_info_->result_) : &ad_hoc_test_result_;
05784 }
05785 
05786 // Shuffles all test cases, and the tests within each test case,
05787 // making sure that death tests are still run first.
05788 void UnitTestImpl::ShuffleTests() {
05789   // Shuffles the death test cases.
05790   ShuffleRange(random(), 0, last_death_test_case_ + 1, &test_case_indices_);
05791 
05792   // Shuffles the non-death test cases.
05793   ShuffleRange(random(), last_death_test_case_ + 1,
05794                static_cast<int>(test_cases_.size()), &test_case_indices_);
05795 
05796   // Shuffles the tests inside each test case.
05797   for (size_t i = 0; i < test_cases_.size(); i++) {
05798     test_cases_[i]->ShuffleTests(random());
05799   }
05800 }
05801 
05802 // Restores the test cases and tests to their order before the first shuffle.
05803 void UnitTestImpl::UnshuffleTests() {
05804   for (size_t i = 0; i < test_cases_.size(); i++) {
05805     // Unshuffles the tests in each test case.
05806     test_cases_[i]->UnshuffleTests();
05807     // Resets the index of each test case.
05808     test_case_indices_[i] = static_cast<int>(i);
05809   }
05810 }
05811 
05812 // Returns the current OS stack trace as a String.
05813 //
05814 // The maximum number of stack frames to be included is specified by
05815 // the gtest_stack_trace_depth flag.  The skip_count parameter
05816 // specifies the number of top frames to be skipped, which doesn't
05817 // count against the number of frames to be included.
05818 //
05819 // For example, if Foo() calls Bar(), which in turn calls
05820 // GetCurrentOsStackTraceExceptTop(..., 1), Foo() will be included in
05821 // the trace but Bar() and GetCurrentOsStackTraceExceptTop() won't.
05822 String GetCurrentOsStackTraceExceptTop(UnitTest* /*unit_test*/,
05823                                        int skip_count) {
05824   // We pass skip_count + 1 to skip this wrapper function in addition
05825   // to what the user really wants to skip.
05826   return GetUnitTestImpl()->CurrentOsStackTraceExceptTop(skip_count + 1);
05827 }
05828 
05829 // Used by the GTEST_SUPPRESS_UNREACHABLE_CODE_WARNING_BELOW_ macro to
05830 // suppress unreachable code warnings.
05831 namespace {
05832 class ClassUniqueToAlwaysTrue {};
05833 }
05834 
05835 bool IsTrue(bool condition) { return condition; }
05836 
05837 bool AlwaysTrue() {
05838 #if GTEST_HAS_EXCEPTIONS
05839   // This condition is always false so AlwaysTrue() never actually throws,
05840   // but it makes the compiler think that it may throw.
05841   if (IsTrue(false))
05842     throw ClassUniqueToAlwaysTrue();
05843 #endif  // GTEST_HAS_EXCEPTIONS
05844   return true;
05845 }
05846 
05847 // If *pstr starts with the given prefix, modifies *pstr to be right
05848 // past the prefix and returns true; otherwise leaves *pstr unchanged
05849 // and returns false.  None of pstr, *pstr, and prefix can be NULL.
05850 bool SkipPrefix(const char* prefix, const char** pstr) {
05851   const size_t prefix_len = strlen(prefix);
05852   if (strncmp(*pstr, prefix, prefix_len) == 0) {
05853     *pstr += prefix_len;
05854     return true;
05855   }
05856   return false;
05857 }
05858 
05859 // Parses a string as a command line flag.  The string should have
05860 // the format "--flag=value".  When def_optional is true, the "=value"
05861 // part can be omitted.
05862 //
05863 // Returns the value of the flag, or NULL if the parsing failed.
05864 const char* ParseFlagValue(const char* str,
05865                            const char* flag,
05866                            bool def_optional) {
05867   // str and flag must not be NULL.
05868   if (str == NULL || flag == NULL) return NULL;
05869 
05870   // The flag must start with "--" followed by GTEST_FLAG_PREFIX_.
05871   const String flag_str = String::Format("--%s%s", GTEST_FLAG_PREFIX_, flag);
05872   const size_t flag_len = flag_str.length();
05873   if (strncmp(str, flag_str.c_str(), flag_len) != 0) return NULL;
05874 
05875   // Skips the flag name.
05876   const char* flag_end = str + flag_len;
05877 
05878   // When def_optional is true, it's OK to not have a "=value" part.
05879   if (def_optional && (flag_end[0] == '\0')) {
05880     return flag_end;
05881   }
05882 
05883   // If def_optional is true and there are more characters after the
05884   // flag name, or if def_optional is false, there must be a '=' after
05885   // the flag name.
05886   if (flag_end[0] != '=') return NULL;
05887 
05888   // Returns the string after "=".
05889   return flag_end + 1;
05890 }
05891 
05892 // Parses a string for a bool flag, in the form of either
05893 // "--flag=value" or "--flag".
05894 //
05895 // In the former case, the value is taken as true as long as it does
05896 // not start with '0', 'f', or 'F'.
05897 //
05898 // In the latter case, the value is taken as true.
05899 //
05900 // On success, stores the value of the flag in *value, and returns
05901 // true.  On failure, returns false without changing *value.
05902 bool ParseBoolFlag(const char* str, const char* flag, bool* value) {
05903   // Gets the value of the flag as a string.
05904   const char* const value_str = ParseFlagValue(str, flag, true);
05905 
05906   // Aborts if the parsing failed.
05907   if (value_str == NULL) return false;
05908 
05909   // Converts the string value to a bool.
05910   *value = !(*value_str == '0' || *value_str == 'f' || *value_str == 'F');
05911   return true;
05912 }
05913 
05914 // Parses a string for an Int32 flag, in the form of
05915 // "--flag=value".
05916 //
05917 // On success, stores the value of the flag in *value, and returns
05918 // true.  On failure, returns false without changing *value.
05919 bool ParseInt32Flag(const char* str, const char* flag, Int32* value) {
05920   // Gets the value of the flag as a string.
05921   const char* const value_str = ParseFlagValue(str, flag, false);
05922 
05923   // Aborts if the parsing failed.
05924   if (value_str == NULL) return false;
05925 
05926   // Sets *value to the value of the flag.
05927   return ParseInt32(Message() << "The value of flag --" << flag,
05928                     value_str, value);
05929 }
05930 
05931 // Parses a string for a string flag, in the form of
05932 // "--flag=value".
05933 //
05934 // On success, stores the value of the flag in *value, and returns
05935 // true.  On failure, returns false without changing *value.
05936 bool ParseStringFlag(const char* str, const char* flag, String* value) {
05937   // Gets the value of the flag as a string.
05938   const char* const value_str = ParseFlagValue(str, flag, false);
05939 
05940   // Aborts if the parsing failed.
05941   if (value_str == NULL) return false;
05942 
05943   // Sets *value to the value of the flag.
05944   *value = value_str;
05945   return true;
05946 }
05947 
05948 // Determines whether a string has a prefix that Google Test uses for its
05949 // flags, i.e., starts with GTEST_FLAG_PREFIX_ or GTEST_FLAG_PREFIX_DASH_.
05950 // If Google Test detects that a command line flag has its prefix but is not
05951 // recognized, it will print its help message. Flags starting with
05952 // GTEST_INTERNAL_PREFIX_ followed by "internal_" are considered Google Test
05953 // internal flags and do not trigger the help message.
05954 static bool HasGoogleTestFlagPrefix(const char* str) {
05955   return (SkipPrefix("--", &str) ||
05956           SkipPrefix("-", &str) ||
05957           SkipPrefix("/", &str)) &&
05958          !SkipPrefix(GTEST_FLAG_PREFIX_ "internal_", &str) &&
05959          (SkipPrefix(GTEST_FLAG_PREFIX_, &str) ||
05960           SkipPrefix(GTEST_FLAG_PREFIX_DASH_, &str));
05961 }
05962 
05963 // Prints a string containing code-encoded text.  The following escape
05964 // sequences can be used in the string to control the text color:
05965 //
05966 //   @@    prints a single '@' character.
05967 //   @R    changes the color to red.
05968 //   @G    changes the color to green.
05969 //   @Y    changes the color to yellow.
05970 //   @D    changes to the default terminal text color.
05971 //
05972 // TODO(wan@google.com): Write tests for this once we add stdout
05973 // capturing to Google Test.
05974 static void PrintColorEncoded(const char* str) {
05975   GTestColor color = COLOR_DEFAULT;  // The current color.
05976 
05977   // Conceptually, we split the string into segments divided by escape
05978   // sequences.  Then we print one segment at a time.  At the end of
05979   // each iteration, the str pointer advances to the beginning of the
05980   // next segment.
05981   for (;;) {
05982     const char* p = strchr(str, '@');
05983     if (p == NULL) {
05984       ColoredPrintf(color, "%s", str);
05985       return;
05986     }
05987 
05988     ColoredPrintf(color, "%s", String(str, p - str).c_str());
05989 
05990     const char ch = p[1];
05991     str = p + 2;
05992     if (ch == '@') {
05993       ColoredPrintf(color, "@");
05994     } else if (ch == 'D') {
05995       color = COLOR_DEFAULT;
05996     } else if (ch == 'R') {
05997       color = COLOR_RED;
05998     } else if (ch == 'G') {
05999       color = COLOR_GREEN;
06000     } else if (ch == 'Y') {
06001       color = COLOR_YELLOW;
06002     } else {
06003       --str;
06004     }
06005   }
06006 }
06007 
06008 static const char kColorEncodedHelpMessage[] =
06009 "This program contains tests written using " GTEST_NAME_ ". You can use the\n"
06010 "following command line flags to control its behavior:\n"
06011 "\n"
06012 "Test Selection:\n"
06013 "  @G--" GTEST_FLAG_PREFIX_ "list_tests@D\n"
06014 "      List the names of all tests instead of running them. The name of\n"
06015 "      TEST(Foo, Bar) is \"Foo.Bar\".\n"
06016 "  @G--" GTEST_FLAG_PREFIX_ "filter=@YPOSTIVE_PATTERNS"
06017     "[@G-@YNEGATIVE_PATTERNS]@D\n"
06018 "      Run only the tests whose name matches one of the positive patterns but\n"
06019 "      none of the negative patterns. '?' matches any single character; '*'\n"
06020 "      matches any substring; ':' separates two patterns.\n"
06021 "  @G--" GTEST_FLAG_PREFIX_ "also_run_disabled_tests@D\n"
06022 "      Run all disabled tests too.\n"
06023 "\n"
06024 "Test Execution:\n"
06025 "  @G--" GTEST_FLAG_PREFIX_ "repeat=@Y[COUNT]@D\n"
06026 "      Run the tests repeatedly; use a negative count to repeat forever.\n"
06027 "  @G--" GTEST_FLAG_PREFIX_ "shuffle@D\n"
06028 "      Randomize tests' orders on every iteration.\n"
06029 "  @G--" GTEST_FLAG_PREFIX_ "random_seed=@Y[NUMBER]@D\n"
06030 "      Random number seed to use for shuffling test orders (between 1 and\n"
06031 "      99999, or 0 to use a seed based on the current time).\n"
06032 "\n"
06033 "Test Output:\n"
06034 "  @G--" GTEST_FLAG_PREFIX_ "color=@Y(@Gyes@Y|@Gno@Y|@Gauto@Y)@D\n"
06035 "      Enable/disable colored output. The default is @Gauto@D.\n"
06036 "  -@G-" GTEST_FLAG_PREFIX_ "print_time=0@D\n"
06037 "      Don't print the elapsed time of each test.\n"
06038 "  @G--" GTEST_FLAG_PREFIX_ "output=xml@Y[@G:@YDIRECTORY_PATH@G"
06039     GTEST_PATH_SEP_ "@Y|@G:@YFILE_PATH]@D\n"
06040 "      Generate an XML report in the given directory or with the given file\n"
06041 "      name. @YFILE_PATH@D defaults to @Gtest_details.xml@D.\n"
06042 #if GTEST_CAN_STREAM_RESULTS_
06043 "  @G--" GTEST_FLAG_PREFIX_ "stream_result_to=@YHOST@G:@YPORT@D\n"
06044 "      Stream test results to the given server.\n"
06045 #endif  // GTEST_CAN_STREAM_RESULTS_
06046 "\n"
06047 "Assertion Behavior:\n"
06048 #if GTEST_HAS_DEATH_TEST && !GTEST_OS_WINDOWS
06049 "  @G--" GTEST_FLAG_PREFIX_ "death_test_style=@Y(@Gfast@Y|@Gthreadsafe@Y)@D\n"
06050 "      Set the default death test style.\n"
06051 #endif  // GTEST_HAS_DEATH_TEST && !GTEST_OS_WINDOWS
06052 "  @G--" GTEST_FLAG_PREFIX_ "break_on_failure@D\n"
06053 "      Turn assertion failures into debugger break-points.\n"
06054 "  @G--" GTEST_FLAG_PREFIX_ "throw_on_failure@D\n"
06055 "      Turn assertion failures into C++ exceptions.\n"
06056 "  @G--" GTEST_FLAG_PREFIX_ "catch_exceptions=0@D\n"
06057 "      Do not report exceptions as test failures. Instead, allow them\n"
06058 "      to crash the program or throw a pop-up (on Windows).\n"
06059 "\n"
06060 "Except for @G--" GTEST_FLAG_PREFIX_ "list_tests@D, you can alternatively set "
06061     "the corresponding\n"
06062 "environment variable of a flag (all letters in upper-case). For example, to\n"
06063 "disable colored text output, you can either specify @G--" GTEST_FLAG_PREFIX_
06064     "color=no@D or set\n"
06065 "the @G" GTEST_FLAG_PREFIX_UPPER_ "COLOR@D environment variable to @Gno@D.\n"
06066 "\n"
06067 "For more information, please read the " GTEST_NAME_ " documentation at\n"
06068 "@G" GTEST_PROJECT_URL_ "@D. If you find a bug in " GTEST_NAME_ "\n"
06069 "(not one in your own code or tests), please report it to\n"
06070 "@G<" GTEST_DEV_EMAIL_ ">@D.\n";
06071 
06072 // Parses the command line for Google Test flags, without initializing
06073 // other parts of Google Test.  The type parameter CharType can be
06074 // instantiated to either char or wchar_t.
06075 template <typename CharType>
06076 void ParseGoogleTestFlagsOnlyImpl(int* argc, CharType** argv) {
06077   for (int i = 1; i < *argc; i++) {
06078     const String arg_string = StreamableToString(argv[i]);
06079     const char* const arg = arg_string.c_str();
06080 
06081     using internal::ParseBoolFlag;
06082     using internal::ParseInt32Flag;
06083     using internal::ParseStringFlag;
06084 
06085     // Do we see a Google Test flag?
06086     if (ParseBoolFlag(arg, kAlsoRunDisabledTestsFlag,
06087                       &GTEST_FLAG(also_run_disabled_tests)) ||
06088         ParseBoolFlag(arg, kBreakOnFailureFlag,
06089                       &GTEST_FLAG(break_on_failure)) ||
06090         ParseBoolFlag(arg, kCatchExceptionsFlag,
06091                       &GTEST_FLAG(catch_exceptions)) ||
06092         ParseStringFlag(arg, kColorFlag, &GTEST_FLAG(color)) ||
06093         ParseStringFlag(arg, kDeathTestStyleFlag,
06094                         &GTEST_FLAG(death_test_style)) ||
06095         ParseBoolFlag(arg, kDeathTestUseFork,
06096                       &GTEST_FLAG(death_test_use_fork)) ||
06097         ParseStringFlag(arg, kFilterFlag, &GTEST_FLAG(filter)) ||
06098         ParseStringFlag(arg, kInternalRunDeathTestFlag,
06099                         &GTEST_FLAG(internal_run_death_test)) ||
06100         ParseBoolFlag(arg, kListTestsFlag, &GTEST_FLAG(list_tests)) ||
06101         ParseStringFlag(arg, kOutputFlag, &GTEST_FLAG(output)) ||
06102         ParseBoolFlag(arg, kPrintTimeFlag, &GTEST_FLAG(print_time)) ||
06103         ParseInt32Flag(arg, kRandomSeedFlag, &GTEST_FLAG(random_seed)) ||
06104         ParseInt32Flag(arg, kRepeatFlag, &GTEST_FLAG(repeat)) ||
06105         ParseBoolFlag(arg, kShuffleFlag, &GTEST_FLAG(shuffle)) ||
06106         ParseInt32Flag(arg, kStackTraceDepthFlag,
06107                        &GTEST_FLAG(stack_trace_depth)) ||
06108         ParseStringFlag(arg, kStreamResultToFlag,
06109                         &GTEST_FLAG(stream_result_to)) ||
06110         ParseBoolFlag(arg, kThrowOnFailureFlag,
06111                       &GTEST_FLAG(throw_on_failure))
06112         ) {
06113       // Yes.  Shift the remainder of the argv list left by one.  Note
06114       // that argv has (*argc + 1) elements, the last one always being
06115       // NULL.  The following loop moves the trailing NULL element as
06116       // well.
06117       for (int j = i; j != *argc; j++) {
06118         argv[j] = argv[j + 1];
06119       }
06120 
06121       // Decrements the argument count.
06122       (*argc)--;
06123 
06124       // We also need to decrement the iterator as we just removed
06125       // an element.
06126       i--;
06127     } else if (arg_string == "--help" || arg_string == "-h" ||
06128                arg_string == "-?" || arg_string == "/?" ||
06129                HasGoogleTestFlagPrefix(arg)) {
06130       // Both help flag and unrecognized Google Test flags (excluding
06131       // internal ones) trigger help display.
06132       g_help_flag = true;
06133     }
06134   }
06135 
06136   if (g_help_flag) {
06137     // We print the help here instead of in RUN_ALL_TESTS(), as the
06138     // latter may not be called at all if the user is using Google
06139     // Test with another testing framework.
06140     PrintColorEncoded(kColorEncodedHelpMessage);
06141   }
06142 }
06143 
06144 // Parses the command line for Google Test flags, without initializing
06145 // other parts of Google Test.
06146 void ParseGoogleTestFlagsOnly(int* argc, char** argv) {
06147   ParseGoogleTestFlagsOnlyImpl(argc, argv);
06148 }
06149 void ParseGoogleTestFlagsOnly(int* argc, wchar_t** argv) {
06150   ParseGoogleTestFlagsOnlyImpl(argc, argv);
06151 }
06152 
06153 // The internal implementation of InitGoogleTest().
06154 //
06155 // The type parameter CharType can be instantiated to either char or
06156 // wchar_t.
06157 template <typename CharType>
06158 void InitGoogleTestImpl(int* argc, CharType** argv) {
06159   g_init_gtest_count++;
06160 
06161   // We don't want to run the initialization code twice.
06162   if (g_init_gtest_count != 1) return;
06163 
06164   if (*argc <= 0) return;
06165 
06166   internal::g_executable_path = internal::StreamableToString(argv[0]);
06167 
06168 #if GTEST_HAS_DEATH_TEST
06169 
06170   g_argvs.clear();
06171   for (int i = 0; i != *argc; i++) {
06172     g_argvs.push_back(StreamableToString(argv[i]));
06173   }
06174 
06175 #endif  // GTEST_HAS_DEATH_TEST
06176 
06177   ParseGoogleTestFlagsOnly(argc, argv);
06178   GetUnitTestImpl()->PostFlagParsingInit();
06179 }
06180 
06181 }  // namespace internal
06182 
06183 // Initializes Google Test.  This must be called before calling
06184 // RUN_ALL_TESTS().  In particular, it parses a command line for the
06185 // flags that Google Test recognizes.  Whenever a Google Test flag is
06186 // seen, it is removed from argv, and *argc is decremented.
06187 //
06188 // No value is returned.  Instead, the Google Test flag variables are
06189 // updated.
06190 //
06191 // Calling the function for the second time has no user-visible effect.
06192 void InitGoogleTest(int* argc, char** argv) {
06193   internal::InitGoogleTestImpl(argc, argv);
06194 }
06195 
06196 // This overloaded version can be used in Windows programs compiled in
06197 // UNICODE mode.
06198 void InitGoogleTest(int* argc, wchar_t** argv) {
06199   internal::InitGoogleTestImpl(argc, argv);
06200 }
06201 
06202 }  // namespace testing

06237 #if GTEST_HAS_DEATH_TEST
06238 
06239 # if GTEST_OS_MAC
06240 #  include <crt_externs.h>
06241 # endif  // GTEST_OS_MAC
06242 
06243 # include <errno.h>
06244 # include <fcntl.h>
06245 # include <limits.h>
06246 # include <stdarg.h>
06247 
06248 # if GTEST_OS_WINDOWS
06249 #  include <windows.h>
06250 # else
06251 #  include <sys/mman.h>
06252 #  include <sys/wait.h>
06253 # endif  // GTEST_OS_WINDOWS
06254 
06255 #endif  // GTEST_HAS_DEATH_TEST
06256 
06257 
06258 // Indicates that this translation unit is part of Google Test's
06259 // implementation.  It must come before gtest-internal-inl.h is
06260 // included, or there will be a compiler error.  This trick is to
06261 // prevent a user from accidentally including gtest-internal-inl.h in
06262 // his code.
06263 #define GTEST_IMPLEMENTATION_ 1
06264 #undef GTEST_IMPLEMENTATION_
06265 
06266 namespace testing {
06267 
06268 // Constants.
06269 
06270 // The default death test style.
06271 static const char kDefaultDeathTestStyle[] = "fast";
06272 
06273 GTEST_DEFINE_string_(
06274     death_test_style,
06275     internal::StringFromGTestEnv("death_test_style", kDefaultDeathTestStyle),
06276     "Indicates how to run a death test in a forked child process: "
06277     "\"threadsafe\" (child process re-executes the test binary "
06278     "from the beginning, running only the specific death test) or "
06279     "\"fast\" (child process runs the death test immediately "
06280     "after forking).");
06281 
06282 GTEST_DEFINE_bool_(
06283     death_test_use_fork,
06284     internal::BoolFromGTestEnv("death_test_use_fork", false),
06285     "Instructs to use fork()/_exit() instead of clone() in death tests. "
06286     "Ignored and always uses fork() on POSIX systems where clone() is not "
06287     "implemented. Useful when running under valgrind or similar tools if "
06288     "those do not support clone(). Valgrind 3.3.1 will just fail if "
06289     "it sees an unsupported combination of clone() flags. "
06290     "It is not recommended to use this flag w/o valgrind though it will "
06291     "work in 99% of the cases. Once valgrind is fixed, this flag will "
06292     "most likely be removed.");
06293 
06294 namespace internal {
06295 GTEST_DEFINE_string_(
06296     internal_run_death_test, "",
06297     "Indicates the file, line number, temporal index of "
06298     "the single death test to run, and a file descriptor to "
06299     "which a success code may be sent, all separated by "
06300     "colons.  This flag is specified if and only if the current "
06301     "process is a sub-process launched for running a thread-safe "
06302     "death test.  FOR INTERNAL USE ONLY.");
06303 }  // namespace internal
06304 
06305 #if GTEST_HAS_DEATH_TEST
06306 
06307 // ExitedWithCode constructor.
06308 ExitedWithCode::ExitedWithCode(int exit_code) : exit_code_(exit_code) {
06309 }
06310 
06311 // ExitedWithCode function-call operator.
06312 bool ExitedWithCode::operator()(int exit_status) const {
06313 # if GTEST_OS_WINDOWS
06314 
06315   return exit_status == exit_code_;
06316 
06317 # else
06318 
06319   return WIFEXITED(exit_status) && WEXITSTATUS(exit_status) == exit_code_;
06320 
06321 # endif  // GTEST_OS_WINDOWS
06322 }
06323 
06324 # if !GTEST_OS_WINDOWS
06325 // KilledBySignal constructor.
06326 KilledBySignal::KilledBySignal(int signum) : signum_(signum) {
06327 }
06328 
06329 // KilledBySignal function-call operator.
06330 bool KilledBySignal::operator()(int exit_status) const {
06331   return WIFSIGNALED(exit_status) && WTERMSIG(exit_status) == signum_;
06332 }
06333 # endif  // !GTEST_OS_WINDOWS
06334 
06335 namespace internal {
06336 
06337 // Utilities needed for death tests.
06338 
06339 // Generates a textual description of a given exit code, in the format
06340 // specified by wait(2).
06341 static String ExitSummary(int exit_code) {
06342   Message m;
06343 
06344 # if GTEST_OS_WINDOWS
06345 
06346   m << "Exited with exit status " << exit_code;
06347 
06348 # else
06349 
06350   if (WIFEXITED(exit_code)) {
06351     m << "Exited with exit status " << WEXITSTATUS(exit_code);
06352   } else if (WIFSIGNALED(exit_code)) {
06353     m << "Terminated by signal " << WTERMSIG(exit_code);
06354   }
06355 #  ifdef WCOREDUMP
06356   if (WCOREDUMP(exit_code)) {
06357     m << " (core dumped)";
06358   }
06359 #  endif
06360 # endif  // GTEST_OS_WINDOWS
06361 
06362   return m.GetString();
06363 }
06364 
06365 // Returns true if exit_status describes a process that was terminated
06366 // by a signal, or exited normally with a nonzero exit code.
06367 bool ExitedUnsuccessfully(int exit_status) {
06368   return !ExitedWithCode(0)(exit_status);
06369 }
06370 
06371 # if !GTEST_OS_WINDOWS
06372 // Generates a textual failure message when a death test finds more than
06373 // one thread running, or cannot determine the number of threads, prior
06374 // to executing the given statement.  It is the responsibility of the
06375 // caller not to pass a thread_count of 1.
06376 static String DeathTestThreadWarning(size_t thread_count) {
06377   Message msg;
06378   msg << "Death tests use fork(), which is unsafe particularly"
06379       << " in a threaded context. For this test, " << GTEST_NAME_ << " ";
06380   if (thread_count == 0)
06381     msg << "couldn't detect the number of threads.";
06382   else
06383     msg << "detected " << thread_count << " threads.";
06384   return msg.GetString();
06385 }
06386 # endif  // !GTEST_OS_WINDOWS
06387 
06388 // Flag characters for reporting a death test that did not die.
06389 static const char kDeathTestLived = 'L';
06390 static const char kDeathTestReturned = 'R';
06391 static const char kDeathTestThrew = 'T';
06392 static const char kDeathTestInternalError = 'I';
06393 
06394 // An enumeration describing all of the possible ways that a death test can
06395 // conclude.  DIED means that the process died while executing the test
06396 // code; LIVED means that process lived beyond the end of the test code;
06397 // RETURNED means that the test statement attempted to execute a return
06398 // statement, which is not allowed; THREW means that the test statement
06399 // returned control by throwing an exception.  IN_PROGRESS means the test
06400 // has not yet concluded.
06401 // TODO(vladl@google.com): Unify names and possibly values for
06402 // AbortReason, DeathTestOutcome, and flag characters above.
06403 enum DeathTestOutcome { IN_PROGRESS, DIED, LIVED, RETURNED, THREW };
06404 
06405 // Routine for aborting the program which is safe to call from an
06406 // exec-style death test child process, in which case the error
06407 // message is propagated back to the parent process.  Otherwise, the
06408 // message is simply printed to stderr.  In either case, the program
06409 // then exits with status 1.
06410 void DeathTestAbort(const String& message) {
06411   // On a POSIX system, this function may be called from a threadsafe-style
06412   // death test child process, which operates on a very small stack.  Use
06413   // the heap for any additional non-minuscule memory requirements.
06414   const InternalRunDeathTestFlag* const flag =
06415       GetUnitTestImpl()->internal_run_death_test_flag();
06416   if (flag != NULL) {
06417     FILE* parent = posix::FDOpen(flag->write_fd(), "w");
06418     fputc(kDeathTestInternalError, parent);
06419     fprintf(parent, "%s", message.c_str());
06420     fflush(parent);
06421     _exit(1);
06422   } else {
06423     fprintf(stderr, "%s", message.c_str());
06424     fflush(stderr);
06425     posix::Abort();
06426   }
06427 }
06428 
06429 // A replacement for CHECK that calls DeathTestAbort if the assertion
06430 // fails.
06431 # define GTEST_DEATH_TEST_CHECK_(expression) \
06432   do { \
06433     if (!::testing::internal::IsTrue(expression)) { \
06434       DeathTestAbort(::testing::internal::String::Format( \
06435           "CHECK failed: File %s, line %d: %s", \
06436           __FILE__, __LINE__, #expression)); \
06437     } \
06438   } while (::testing::internal::AlwaysFalse())
06439 
06440 // This macro is similar to GTEST_DEATH_TEST_CHECK_, but it is meant for
06441 // evaluating any system call that fulfills two conditions: it must return
06442 // -1 on failure, and set errno to EINTR when it is interrupted and
06443 // should be tried again.  The macro expands to a loop that repeatedly
06444 // evaluates the expression as long as it evaluates to -1 and sets
06445 // errno to EINTR.  If the expression evaluates to -1 but errno is
06446 // something other than EINTR, DeathTestAbort is called.
06447 # define GTEST_DEATH_TEST_CHECK_SYSCALL_(expression) \
06448   do { \
06449     int gtest_retval; \
06450     do { \
06451       gtest_retval = (expression); \
06452     } while (gtest_retval == -1 && errno == EINTR); \
06453     if (gtest_retval == -1) { \
06454       DeathTestAbort(::testing::internal::String::Format( \
06455           "CHECK failed: File %s, line %d: %s != -1", \
06456           __FILE__, __LINE__, #expression)); \
06457     } \
06458   } while (::testing::internal::AlwaysFalse())
06459 
06460 // Returns the message describing the last system error in errno.
06461 String GetLastErrnoDescription() {
06462     return String(errno == 0 ? "" : posix::StrError(errno));
06463 }
06464 
06465 // This is called from a death test parent process to read a failure
06466 // message from the death test child process and log it with the FATAL
06467 // severity. On Windows, the message is read from a pipe handle. On other
06468 // platforms, it is read from a file descriptor.
06469 static void FailFromInternalError(int fd) {
06470   Message error;
06471   char buffer[256];
06472   int num_read;
06473 
06474   do {
06475     while ((num_read = posix::Read(fd, buffer, 255)) > 0) {
06476       buffer[num_read] = '\0';
06477       error << buffer;
06478     }
06479   } while (num_read == -1 && errno == EINTR);
06480 
06481   if (num_read == 0) {
06482     GTEST_LOG_(FATAL) << error.GetString();
06483   } else {
06484     const int last_error = errno;
06485     GTEST_LOG_(FATAL) << "Error while reading death test internal: "
06486                       << GetLastErrnoDescription() << " [" << last_error << "]";
06487   }
06488 }
06489 
06490 // Death test constructor.  Increments the running death test count
06491 // for the current test.
06492 DeathTest::DeathTest() {
06493   TestInfo* const info = GetUnitTestImpl()->current_test_info();
06494   if (info == NULL) {
06495     DeathTestAbort("Cannot run a death test outside of a TEST or "
06496                    "TEST_F construct");
06497   }
06498 }
06499 
06500 // Creates and returns a death test by dispatching to the current
06501 // death test factory.
06502 bool DeathTest::Create(const char* statement, const RE* regex,
06503                        const char* file, int line, DeathTest** test) {
06504   return GetUnitTestImpl()->death_test_factory()->Create(
06505       statement, regex, file, line, test);
06506 }
06507 
06508 const char* DeathTest::LastMessage() {
06509   return last_death_test_message_.c_str();
06510 }
06511 
06512 void DeathTest::set_last_death_test_message(const String& message) {
06513   last_death_test_message_ = message;
06514 }
06515 
06516 String DeathTest::last_death_test_message_;
06517 
06518 // Provides cross platform implementation for some death functionality.
06519 class DeathTestImpl : public DeathTest {
06520  protected:
06521   DeathTestImpl(const char* a_statement, const RE* a_regex)
06522       : statement_(a_statement),
06523         regex_(a_regex),
06524         spawned_(false),
06525         status_(-1),
06526         outcome_(IN_PROGRESS),
06527         read_fd_(-1),
06528         write_fd_(-1) {}
06529 
06530   // read_fd_ is expected to be closed and cleared by a derived class.
06531   ~DeathTestImpl() { GTEST_DEATH_TEST_CHECK_(read_fd_ == -1); }
06532 
06533   void Abort(AbortReason reason);
06534   virtual bool Passed(bool status_ok);
06535 
06536   const char* statement() const { return statement_; }
06537   const RE* regex() const { return regex_; }
06538   bool spawned() const { return spawned_; }
06539   void set_spawned(bool is_spawned) { spawned_ = is_spawned; }
06540   int status() const { return status_; }
06541   void set_status(int a_status) { status_ = a_status; }
06542   DeathTestOutcome outcome() const { return outcome_; }
06543   void set_outcome(DeathTestOutcome an_outcome) { outcome_ = an_outcome; }
06544   int read_fd() const { return read_fd_; }
06545   void set_read_fd(int fd) { read_fd_ = fd; }
06546   int write_fd() const { return write_fd_; }
06547   void set_write_fd(int fd) { write_fd_ = fd; }
06548 
06549   // Called in the parent process only. Reads the result code of the death
06550   // test child process via a pipe, interprets it to set the outcome_
06551   // member, and closes read_fd_.  Outputs diagnostics and terminates in
06552   // case of unexpected codes.
06553   void ReadAndInterpretStatusByte();
06554 
06555  private:
06556   // The textual content of the code this object is testing.  This class
06557   // doesn't own this string and should not attempt to delete it.
06558   const char* const statement_;
06559   // The regular expression which test output must match.  DeathTestImpl
06560   // doesn't own this object and should not attempt to delete it.
06561   const RE* const regex_;
06562   // True if the death test child process has been successfully spawned.
06563   bool spawned_;
06564   // The exit status of the child process.
06565   int status_;
06566   // How the death test concluded.
06567   DeathTestOutcome outcome_;
06568   // Descriptor to the read end of the pipe to the child process.  It is
06569   // always -1 in the child process.  The child keeps its write end of the
06570   // pipe in write_fd_.
06571   int read_fd_;
06572   // Descriptor to the child's write end of the pipe to the parent process.
06573   // It is always -1 in the parent process.  The parent keeps its end of the
06574   // pipe in read_fd_.
06575   int write_fd_;
06576 };
06577 
06578 // Called in the parent process only. Reads the result code of the death
06579 // test child process via a pipe, interprets it to set the outcome_
06580 // member, and closes read_fd_.  Outputs diagnostics and terminates in
06581 // case of unexpected codes.
06582 void DeathTestImpl::ReadAndInterpretStatusByte() {
06583   char flag;
06584   int bytes_read;
06585 
06586   // The read() here blocks until data is available (signifying the
06587   // failure of the death test) or until the pipe is closed (signifying
06588   // its success), so it's okay to call this in the parent before
06589   // the child process has exited.
06590   do {
06591     bytes_read = posix::Read(read_fd(), &flag, 1);
06592   } while (bytes_read == -1 && errno == EINTR);
06593 
06594   if (bytes_read == 0) {
06595     set_outcome(DIED);
06596   } else if (bytes_read == 1) {
06597     switch (flag) {
06598       case kDeathTestReturned:
06599         set_outcome(RETURNED);
06600         break;
06601       case kDeathTestThrew:
06602         set_outcome(THREW);
06603         break;
06604       case kDeathTestLived:
06605         set_outcome(LIVED);
06606         break;
06607       case kDeathTestInternalError:
06608         FailFromInternalError(read_fd());  // Does not return.
06609         break;
06610       default:
06611         GTEST_LOG_(FATAL) << "Death test child process reported "
06612                           << "unexpected status byte ("
06613                           << static_cast<unsigned int>(flag) << ")";
06614     }
06615   } else {
06616     GTEST_LOG_(FATAL) << "Read from death test child process failed: "
06617                       << GetLastErrnoDescription();
06618   }
06619   GTEST_DEATH_TEST_CHECK_SYSCALL_(posix::Close(read_fd()));
06620   set_read_fd(-1);
06621 }
06622 
06623 // Signals that the death test code which should have exited, didn't.
06624 // Should be called only in a death test child process.
06625 // Writes a status byte to the child's status file descriptor, then
06626 // calls _exit(1).
06627 void DeathTestImpl::Abort(AbortReason reason) {
06628   // The parent process considers the death test to be a failure if
06629   // it finds any data in our pipe.  So, here we write a single flag byte
06630   // to the pipe, then exit.
06631   const char status_ch =
06632       reason == TEST_DID_NOT_DIE ? kDeathTestLived :
06633       reason == TEST_THREW_EXCEPTION ? kDeathTestThrew : kDeathTestReturned;
06634 
06635   GTEST_DEATH_TEST_CHECK_SYSCALL_(posix::Write(write_fd(), &status_ch, 1));
06636   // We are leaking the descriptor here because on some platforms (i.e.,
06637   // when built as Windows DLL), destructors of global objects will still
06638   // run after calling _exit(). On such systems, write_fd_ will be
06639   // indirectly closed from the destructor of UnitTestImpl, causing double
06640   // close if it is also closed here. On debug configurations, double close
06641   // may assert. As there are no in-process buffers to flush here, we are
06642   // relying on the OS to close the descriptor after the process terminates
06643   // when the destructors are not run.
06644   _exit(1);  // Exits w/o any normal exit hooks (we were supposed to crash)
06645 }
06646 
06647 // Returns an indented copy of stderr output for a death test.
06648 // This makes distinguishing death test output lines from regular log lines
06649 // much easier.
06650 static ::std::string FormatDeathTestOutput(const ::std::string& output) {
06651   ::std::string ret;
06652   for (size_t at = 0; ; ) {
06653     const size_t line_end = output.find('\n', at);
06654     ret += "[  DEATH   ] ";
06655     if (line_end == ::std::string::npos) {
06656       ret += output.substr(at);
06657       break;
06658     }
06659     ret += output.substr(at, line_end + 1 - at);
06660     at = line_end + 1;
06661   }
06662   return ret;
06663 }
06664 
06665 // Assesses the success or failure of a death test, using both private
06666 // members which have previously been set, and one argument:
06667 //
06668 // Private data members:
06669 //   outcome:  An enumeration describing how the death test
06670 //             concluded: DIED, LIVED, THREW, or RETURNED.  The death test
06671 //             fails in the latter three cases.
06672 //   status:   The exit status of the child process. On *nix, it is in the
06673 //             in the format specified by wait(2). On Windows, this is the
06674 //             value supplied to the ExitProcess() API or a numeric code
06675 //             of the exception that terminated the program.
06676 //   regex:    A regular expression object to be applied to
06677 //             the test's captured standard error output; the death test
06678 //             fails if it does not match.
06679 //
06680 // Argument:
06681 //   status_ok: true if exit_status is acceptable in the context of
06682 //              this particular death test, which fails if it is false
06683 //
06684 // Returns true iff all of the above conditions are met.  Otherwise, the
06685 // first failing condition, in the order given above, is the one that is
06686 // reported. Also sets the last death test message string.
06687 bool DeathTestImpl::Passed(bool status_ok) {
06688   if (!spawned())
06689     return false;
06690 
06691   const String error_message = GetCapturedStderr();
06692 
06693   bool success = false;
06694   Message buffer;
06695 
06696   buffer << "Death test: " << statement() << "\n";
06697   switch (outcome()) {
06698     case LIVED:
06699       buffer << "    Result: failed to die.\n"
06700              << " Error msg:\n" << FormatDeathTestOutput(error_message);
06701       break;
06702     case THREW:
06703       buffer << "    Result: threw an exception.\n"
06704              << " Error msg:\n" << FormatDeathTestOutput(error_message);
06705       break;
06706     case RETURNED:
06707       buffer << "    Result: illegal return in test statement.\n"
06708              << " Error msg:\n" << FormatDeathTestOutput(error_message);
06709       break;
06710     case DIED:
06711       if (status_ok) {
06712         const bool matched = RE::PartialMatch(error_message.c_str(), *regex());
06713         if (matched) {
06714           success = true;
06715         } else {
06716           buffer << "    Result: died but not with expected error.\n"
06717                  << "  Expected: " << regex()->pattern() << "\n"
06718                  << "Actual msg:\n" << FormatDeathTestOutput(error_message);
06719         }
06720       } else {
06721         buffer << "    Result: died but not with expected exit code:\n"
06722                << "            " << ExitSummary(status()) << "\n"
06723                << "Actual msg:\n" << FormatDeathTestOutput(error_message);
06724       }
06725       break;
06726     case IN_PROGRESS:
06727     default:
06728       GTEST_LOG_(FATAL)
06729           << "DeathTest::Passed somehow called before conclusion of test";
06730   }
06731 
06732   DeathTest::set_last_death_test_message(buffer.GetString());
06733   return success;
06734 }
06735 
06736 # if GTEST_OS_WINDOWS
06737 // WindowsDeathTest implements death tests on Windows. Due to the
06738 // specifics of starting new processes on Windows, death tests there are
06739 // always threadsafe, and Google Test considers the
06740 // --gtest_death_test_style=fast setting to be equivalent to
06741 // --gtest_death_test_style=threadsafe there.
06742 //
06743 // A few implementation notes:  Like the Linux version, the Windows
06744 // implementation uses pipes for child-to-parent communication. But due to
06745 // the specifics of pipes on Windows, some extra steps are required:
06746 //
06747 // 1. The parent creates a communication pipe and stores handles to both
06748 //    ends of it.
06749 // 2. The parent starts the child and provides it with the information
06750 //    necessary to acquire the handle to the write end of the pipe.
06751 // 3. The child acquires the write end of the pipe and signals the parent
06752 //    using a Windows event.
06753 // 4. Now the parent can release the write end of the pipe on its side. If
06754 //    this is done before step 3, the object's reference count goes down to
06755 //    0 and it is destroyed, preventing the child from acquiring it. The
06756 //    parent now has to release it, or read operations on the read end of
06757 //    the pipe will not return when the child terminates.
06758 // 5. The parent reads child's output through the pipe (outcome code and
06759 //    any possible error messages) from the pipe, and its stderr and then
06760 //    determines whether to fail the test.
06761 //
06762 // Note: to distinguish Win32 API calls from the local method and function
06763 // calls, the former are explicitly resolved in the global namespace.
06764 //
06765 class WindowsDeathTest : public DeathTestImpl {
06766  public:
06767   WindowsDeathTest(const char* a_statement,
06768                    const RE* a_regex,
06769                    const char* file,
06770                    int line)
06771       : DeathTestImpl(a_statement, a_regex), file_(file), line_(line) {}
06772 
06773   // All of these virtual functions are inherited from DeathTest.
06774   virtual int Wait();
06775   virtual TestRole AssumeRole();
06776 
06777  private:
06778   // The name of the file in which the death test is located.
06779   const char* const file_;
06780   // The line number on which the death test is located.
06781   const int line_;
06782   // Handle to the write end of the pipe to the child process.
06783   AutoHandle write_handle_;
06784   // Child process handle.
06785   AutoHandle child_handle_;
06786   // Event the child process uses to signal the parent that it has
06787   // acquired the handle to the write end of the pipe. After seeing this
06788   // event the parent can release its own handles to make sure its
06789   // ReadFile() calls return when the child terminates.
06790   AutoHandle event_handle_;
06791 };
06792 
06793 // Waits for the child in a death test to exit, returning its exit
06794 // status, or 0 if no child process exists.  As a side effect, sets the
06795 // outcome data member.
06796 int WindowsDeathTest::Wait() {
06797   if (!spawned())
06798     return 0;
06799 
06800   // Wait until the child either signals that it has acquired the write end
06801   // of the pipe or it dies.
06802   const HANDLE wait_handles[2] = { child_handle_.Get(), event_handle_.Get() };
06803   switch (::WaitForMultipleObjects(2,
06804                                    wait_handles,
06805                                    FALSE,  // Waits for any of the handles.
06806                                    INFINITE)) {
06807     case WAIT_OBJECT_0:
06808     case WAIT_OBJECT_0 + 1:
06809       break;
06810     default:
06811       GTEST_DEATH_TEST_CHECK_(false);  // Should not get here.
06812   }
06813 
06814   // The child has acquired the write end of the pipe or exited.
06815   // We release the handle on our side and continue.
06816   write_handle_.Reset();
06817   event_handle_.Reset();
06818 
06819   ReadAndInterpretStatusByte();
06820 
06821   // Waits for the child process to exit if it haven't already. This
06822   // returns immediately if the child has already exited, regardless of
06823   // whether previous calls to WaitForMultipleObjects synchronized on this
06824   // handle or not.
06825   GTEST_DEATH_TEST_CHECK_(
06826       WAIT_OBJECT_0 == ::WaitForSingleObject(child_handle_.Get(),
06827                                              INFINITE));
06828   DWORD status_code;
06829   GTEST_DEATH_TEST_CHECK_(
06830       ::GetExitCodeProcess(child_handle_.Get(), &status_code) != FALSE);
06831   child_handle_.Reset();
06832   set_status(static_cast<int>(status_code));
06833   return status();
06834 }
06835 
06836 // The AssumeRole process for a Windows death test.  It creates a child
06837 // process with the same executable as the current process to run the
06838 // death test.  The child process is given the --gtest_filter and
06839 // --gtest_internal_run_death_test flags such that it knows to run the
06840 // current death test only.
06841 DeathTest::TestRole WindowsDeathTest::AssumeRole() {
06842   const UnitTestImpl* const impl = GetUnitTestImpl();
06843   const InternalRunDeathTestFlag* const flag =
06844       impl->internal_run_death_test_flag();
06845   const TestInfo* const info = impl->current_test_info();
06846   const int death_test_index = info->result()->death_test_count();
06847 
06848   if (flag != NULL) {
06849     // ParseInternalRunDeathTestFlag() has performed all the necessary
06850     // processing.
06851     set_write_fd(flag->write_fd());
06852     return EXECUTE_TEST;
06853   }
06854 
06855   // WindowsDeathTest uses an anonymous pipe to communicate results of
06856   // a death test.
06857   SECURITY_ATTRIBUTES handles_are_inheritable = {
06858     sizeof(SECURITY_ATTRIBUTES), NULL, TRUE };
06859   HANDLE read_handle, write_handle;
06860   GTEST_DEATH_TEST_CHECK_(
06861       ::CreatePipe(&read_handle, &write_handle, &handles_are_inheritable,
06862                    0)  // Default buffer size.
06863       != FALSE);
06864   set_read_fd(::_open_osfhandle(reinterpret_cast<intptr_t>(read_handle),
06865                                 O_RDONLY));
06866   write_handle_.Reset(write_handle);
06867   event_handle_.Reset(::CreateEvent(
06868       &handles_are_inheritable,
06869       TRUE,    // The event will automatically reset to non-signaled state.
06870       FALSE,   // The initial state is non-signalled.
06871       NULL));  // The even is unnamed.
06872   GTEST_DEATH_TEST_CHECK_(event_handle_.Get() != NULL);
06873   const String filter_flag = String::Format("--%s%s=%s.%s",
06874                                             GTEST_FLAG_PREFIX_, kFilterFlag,
06875                                             info->test_case_name(),
06876                                             info->name());
06877   const String internal_flag = String::Format(
06878     "--%s%s=%s|%d|%d|%u|%Iu|%Iu",
06879       GTEST_FLAG_PREFIX_,
06880       kInternalRunDeathTestFlag,
06881       file_, line_,
06882       death_test_index,
06883       static_cast<unsigned int>(::GetCurrentProcessId()),
06884       // size_t has the same with as pointers on both 32-bit and 64-bit
06885       // Windows platforms.
06886       // See http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/tcxf1dw6.aspx.
06887       reinterpret_cast<size_t>(write_handle),
06888       reinterpret_cast<size_t>(event_handle_.Get()));
06889 
06890   char executable_path[_MAX_PATH + 1];  // NOLINT
06891   GTEST_DEATH_TEST_CHECK_(
06892       _MAX_PATH + 1 != ::GetModuleFileNameA(NULL,
06893                                             executable_path,
06894                                             _MAX_PATH));
06895 
06896   String command_line = String::Format("%s %s \"%s\"",
06897                                        ::GetCommandLineA(),
06898                                        filter_flag.c_str(),
06899                                        internal_flag.c_str());
06900 
06901   DeathTest::set_last_death_test_message("");
06902 
06903   CaptureStderr();
06904   // Flush the log buffers since the log streams are shared with the child.
06905   FlushInfoLog();
06906 
06907   // The child process will share the standard handles with the parent.
06908   STARTUPINFOA startup_info;
06909   memset(&startup_info, 0, sizeof(STARTUPINFO));
06910   startup_info.dwFlags = STARTF_USESTDHANDLES;
06911   startup_info.hStdInput = ::GetStdHandle(STD_INPUT_HANDLE);
06912   startup_info.hStdOutput = ::GetStdHandle(STD_OUTPUT_HANDLE);
06913   startup_info.hStdError = ::GetStdHandle(STD_ERROR_HANDLE);
06914 
06915   PROCESS_INFORMATION process_info;
06916   GTEST_DEATH_TEST_CHECK_(::CreateProcessA(
06917       executable_path,
06918       const_cast<char*>(command_line.c_str()),
06919       NULL,   // Retuned process handle is not inheritable.
06920       NULL,   // Retuned thread handle is not inheritable.
06921       TRUE,   // Child inherits all inheritable handles (for write_handle_).
06922       0x0,    // Default creation flags.
06923       NULL,   // Inherit the parent's environment.
06924       UnitTest::GetInstance()->original_working_dir(),
06925       &startup_info,
06926       &process_info) != FALSE);
06927   child_handle_.Reset(process_info.hProcess);
06928   ::CloseHandle(process_info.hThread);
06929   set_spawned(true);
06930   return OVERSEE_TEST;
06931 }
06932 # else  // We are not on Windows.
06933 
06934 // ForkingDeathTest provides implementations for most of the abstract
06935 // methods of the DeathTest interface.  Only the AssumeRole method is
06936 // left undefined.
06937 class ForkingDeathTest : public DeathTestImpl {
06938  public:
06939   ForkingDeathTest(const char* statement, const RE* regex);
06940 
06941   // All of these virtual functions are inherited from DeathTest.
06942   virtual int Wait();
06943 
06944  protected:
06945   void set_child_pid(pid_t child_pid) { child_pid_ = child_pid; }
06946 
06947  private:
06948   // PID of child process during death test; 0 in the child process itself.
06949   pid_t child_pid_;
06950 };
06951 
06952 // Constructs a ForkingDeathTest.
06953 ForkingDeathTest::ForkingDeathTest(const char* a_statement, const RE* a_regex)
06954     : DeathTestImpl(a_statement, a_regex),
06955       child_pid_(-1) {}
06956 
06957 // Waits for the child in a death test to exit, returning its exit
06958 // status, or 0 if no child process exists.  As a side effect, sets the
06959 // outcome data member.
06960 int ForkingDeathTest::Wait() {
06961   if (!spawned())
06962     return 0;
06963 
06964   ReadAndInterpretStatusByte();
06965 
06966   int status_value;
06967   GTEST_DEATH_TEST_CHECK_SYSCALL_(waitpid(child_pid_, &status_value, 0));
06968   set_status(status_value);
06969   return status_value;
06970 }
06971 
06972 // A concrete death test class that forks, then immediately runs the test
06973 // in the child process.
06974 class NoExecDeathTest : public ForkingDeathTest {
06975  public:
06976   NoExecDeathTest(const char* a_statement, const RE* a_regex) :
06977       ForkingDeathTest(a_statement, a_regex) { }
06978   virtual TestRole AssumeRole();
06979 };
06980 
06981 // The AssumeRole process for a fork-and-run death test.  It implements a
06982 // straightforward fork, with a simple pipe to transmit the status byte.
06983 DeathTest::TestRole NoExecDeathTest::AssumeRole() {
06984   const size_t thread_count = GetThreadCount();
06985   if (thread_count != 1) {
06986     GTEST_LOG_(WARNING) << DeathTestThreadWarning(thread_count);
06987   }
06988 
06989   int pipe_fd[2];
06990   GTEST_DEATH_TEST_CHECK_(pipe(pipe_fd) != -1);
06991 
06992   DeathTest::set_last_death_test_message("");
06993   CaptureStderr();
06994   // When we fork the process below, the log file buffers are copied, but the
06995   // file descriptors are shared.  We flush all log files here so that closing
06996   // the file descriptors in the child process doesn't throw off the
06997   // synchronization between descriptors and buffers in the parent process.
06998   // This is as close to the fork as possible to avoid a race condition in case
06999   // there are multiple threads running before the death test, and another
07000   // thread writes to the log file.
07001   FlushInfoLog();
07002 
07003   const pid_t child_pid = fork();
07004   GTEST_DEATH_TEST_CHECK_(child_pid != -1);
07005   set_child_pid(child_pid);
07006   if (child_pid == 0) {
07007     GTEST_DEATH_TEST_CHECK_SYSCALL_(close(pipe_fd[0]));
07008     set_write_fd(pipe_fd[1]);
07009     // Redirects all logging to stderr in the child process to prevent
07010     // concurrent writes to the log files.  We capture stderr in the parent
07011     // process and append the child process' output to a log.
07012     LogToStderr();
07013     // Event forwarding to the listeners of event listener API mush be shut
07014     // down in death test subprocesses.
07015     GetUnitTestImpl()->listeners()->SuppressEventForwarding();
07016     return EXECUTE_TEST;
07017   } else {
07018     GTEST_DEATH_TEST_CHECK_SYSCALL_(close(pipe_fd[1]));
07019     set_read_fd(pipe_fd[0]);
07020     set_spawned(true);
07021     return OVERSEE_TEST;
07022   }
07023 }
07024 
07025 // A concrete death test class that forks and re-executes the main
07026 // program from the beginning, with command-line flags set that cause
07027 // only this specific death test to be run.
07028 class ExecDeathTest : public ForkingDeathTest {
07029  public:
07030   ExecDeathTest(const char* a_statement, const RE* a_regex,
07031                 const char* file, int line) :
07032       ForkingDeathTest(a_statement, a_regex), file_(file), line_(line) { }
07033   virtual TestRole AssumeRole();
07034  private:
07035   // The name of the file in which the death test is located.
07036   const char* const file_;
07037   // The line number on which the death test is located.
07038   const int line_;
07039 };
07040 
07041 // Utility class for accumulating command-line arguments.
07042 class Arguments {
07043  public:
07044   Arguments() {
07045     args_.push_back(NULL);
07046   }
07047 
07048   ~Arguments() {
07049     for (std::vector<char*>::iterator i = args_.begin(); i != args_.end();
07050          ++i) {
07051       free(*i);
07052     }
07053   }
07054   void AddArgument(const char* argument) {
07055     args_.insert(args_.end() - 1, posix::StrDup(argument));
07056   }
07057 
07058   template <typename Str>
07059   void AddArguments(const ::std::vector<Str>& arguments) {
07060     for (typename ::std::vector<Str>::const_iterator i = arguments.begin();
07061          i != arguments.end();
07062          ++i) {
07063       args_.insert(args_.end() - 1, posix::StrDup(i->c_str()));
07064     }
07065   }
07066   char* const* Argv() {
07067     return &args_[0];
07068   }
07069  private:
07070   std::vector<char*> args_;
07071 };
07072 
07073 // A struct that encompasses the arguments to the child process of a
07074 // threadsafe-style death test process.
07075 struct ExecDeathTestArgs {
07076   char* const* argv;  // Command-line arguments for the child's call to exec
07077   int close_fd;       // File descriptor to close; the read end of a pipe
07078 };
07079 
07080 #  if GTEST_OS_MAC
07081 inline char** GetEnviron() {
07082   // When Google Test is built as a framework on MacOS X, the environ variable
07083   // is unavailable. Apple's documentation (man environ) recommends using
07084   // _NSGetEnviron() instead.
07085   return *_NSGetEnviron();
07086 }
07087 #  else
07088 // Some POSIX platforms expect you to declare environ. extern "C" makes
07089 // it reside in the global namespace.
07090 extern "C" char** environ;
07091 inline char** GetEnviron() { return environ; }
07092 #  endif  // GTEST_OS_MAC
07093 
07094 // The main function for a threadsafe-style death test child process.
07095 // This function is called in a clone()-ed process and thus must avoid
07096 // any potentially unsafe operations like malloc or libc functions.
07097 static int ExecDeathTestChildMain(void* child_arg) {
07098   ExecDeathTestArgs* const args = static_cast<ExecDeathTestArgs*>(child_arg);
07099   GTEST_DEATH_TEST_CHECK_SYSCALL_(close(args->close_fd));
07100 
07101   // We need to execute the test program in the same environment where
07102   // it was originally invoked.  Therefore we change to the original
07103   // working directory first.
07104   const char* const original_dir =
07105       UnitTest::GetInstance()->original_working_dir();
07106   // We can safely call chdir() as it's a direct system call.
07107   if (chdir(original_dir) != 0) {
07108     DeathTestAbort(String::Format("chdir(\"%s\") failed: %s",
07109                                   original_dir,
07110                                   GetLastErrnoDescription().c_str()));
07111     return EXIT_FAILURE;
07112   }
07113 
07114   // We can safely call execve() as it's a direct system call.  We
07115   // cannot use execvp() as it's a libc function and thus potentially
07116   // unsafe.  Since execve() doesn't search the PATH, the user must
07117   // invoke the test program via a valid path that contains at least
07118   // one path separator.
07119   execve(args->argv[0], args->argv, GetEnviron());
07120   DeathTestAbort(String::Format("execve(%s, ...) in %s failed: %s",
07121                                 args->argv[0],
07122                                 original_dir,
07123                                 GetLastErrnoDescription().c_str()));
07124   return EXIT_FAILURE;
07125 }
07126 
07127 // Two utility routines that together determine the direction the stack
07128 // grows.
07129 // This could be accomplished more elegantly by a single recursive
07130 // function, but we want to guard against the unlikely possibility of
07131 // a smart compiler optimizing the recursion away.
07132 //
07133 // GTEST_NO_INLINE_ is required to prevent GCC 4.6 from inlining
07134 // StackLowerThanAddress into StackGrowsDown, which then doesn't give
07135 // correct answer.
07136 bool StackLowerThanAddress(const void* ptr) GTEST_NO_INLINE_;
07137 bool StackLowerThanAddress(const void* ptr) {
07138   int dummy;
07139   return &dummy < ptr;
07140 }
07141 
07142 bool StackGrowsDown() {
07143   int dummy;
07144   return StackLowerThanAddress(&dummy);
07145 }
07146 
07147 // A threadsafe implementation of fork(2) for threadsafe-style death tests
07148 // that uses clone(2).  It dies with an error message if anything goes
07149 // wrong.
07150 static pid_t ExecDeathTestFork(char* const* argv, int close_fd) {
07151   ExecDeathTestArgs args = { argv, close_fd };
07152   pid_t child_pid = -1;
07153 
07154 #  if GTEST_HAS_CLONE
07155   const bool use_fork = GTEST_FLAG(death_test_use_fork);
07156 
07157   if (!use_fork) {
07158     static const bool stack_grows_down = StackGrowsDown();
07159     const size_t stack_size = getpagesize();
07160     // MMAP_ANONYMOUS is not defined on Mac, so we use MAP_ANON instead.
07161     void* const stack = mmap(NULL, stack_size, PROT_READ | PROT_WRITE,
07162                              MAP_ANON | MAP_PRIVATE, -1, 0);
07163     GTEST_DEATH_TEST_CHECK_(stack != MAP_FAILED);
07164     void* const stack_top =
07165         static_cast<char*>(stack) + (stack_grows_down ? stack_size : 0);
07166 
07167     child_pid = clone(&ExecDeathTestChildMain, stack_top, SIGCHLD, &args);
07168 
07169     GTEST_DEATH_TEST_CHECK_(munmap(stack, stack_size) != -1);
07170   }
07171 #  else
07172   const bool use_fork = true;
07173 #  endif  // GTEST_HAS_CLONE
07174 
07175   if (use_fork && (child_pid = fork()) == 0) {
07176       ExecDeathTestChildMain(&args);
07177       _exit(0);
07178   }
07179 
07180   GTEST_DEATH_TEST_CHECK_(child_pid != -1);
07181   return child_pid;
07182 }
07183 
07184 // The AssumeRole process for a fork-and-exec death test.  It re-executes the
07185 // main program from the beginning, setting the --gtest_filter
07186 // and --gtest_internal_run_death_test flags to cause only the current
07187 // death test to be re-run.
07188 DeathTest::TestRole ExecDeathTest::AssumeRole() {
07189   const UnitTestImpl* const impl = GetUnitTestImpl();
07190   const InternalRunDeathTestFlag* const flag =
07191       impl->internal_run_death_test_flag();
07192   const TestInfo* const info = impl->current_test_info();
07193   const int death_test_index = info->result()->death_test_count();
07194 
07195   if (flag != NULL) {
07196     set_write_fd(flag->write_fd());
07197     return EXECUTE_TEST;
07198   }
07199 
07200   int pipe_fd[2];
07201   GTEST_DEATH_TEST_CHECK_(pipe(pipe_fd) != -1);
07202   // Clear the close-on-exec flag on the write end of the pipe, lest
07203   // it be closed when the child process does an exec:
07204   GTEST_DEATH_TEST_CHECK_(fcntl(pipe_fd[1], F_SETFD, 0) != -1);
07205 
07206   const String filter_flag =
07207       String::Format("--%s%s=%s.%s",
07208                      GTEST_FLAG_PREFIX_, kFilterFlag,
07209                      info->test_case_name(), info->name());
07210   const String internal_flag =
07211       String::Format("--%s%s=%s|%d|%d|%d",
07212                      GTEST_FLAG_PREFIX_, kInternalRunDeathTestFlag,
07213                      file_, line_, death_test_index, pipe_fd[1]);
07214   Arguments args;
07215   args.AddArguments(GetArgvs());
07216   args.AddArgument(filter_flag.c_str());
07217   args.AddArgument(internal_flag.c_str());
07218 
07219   DeathTest::set_last_death_test_message("");
07220 
07221   CaptureStderr();
07222   // See the comment in NoExecDeathTest::AssumeRole for why the next line
07223   // is necessary.
07224   FlushInfoLog();
07225 
07226   const pid_t child_pid = ExecDeathTestFork(args.Argv(), pipe_fd[0]);
07227   GTEST_DEATH_TEST_CHECK_SYSCALL_(close(pipe_fd[1]));
07228   set_child_pid(child_pid);
07229   set_read_fd(pipe_fd[0]);
07230   set_spawned(true);
07231   return OVERSEE_TEST;
07232 }
07233 
07234 # endif  // !GTEST_OS_WINDOWS
07235 
07236 // Creates a concrete DeathTest-derived class that depends on the
07237 // --gtest_death_test_style flag, and sets the pointer pointed to
07238 // by the "test" argument to its address.  If the test should be
07239 // skipped, sets that pointer to NULL.  Returns true, unless the
07240 // flag is set to an invalid value.
07241 bool DefaultDeathTestFactory::Create(const char* statement, const RE* regex,
07242                                      const char* file, int line,
07243                                      DeathTest** test) {
07244   UnitTestImpl* const impl = GetUnitTestImpl();
07245   const InternalRunDeathTestFlag* const flag =
07246       impl->internal_run_death_test_flag();
07247   const int death_test_index = impl->current_test_info()
07248       ->increment_death_test_count();
07249 
07250   if (flag != NULL) {
07251     if (death_test_index > flag->index()) {
07252       DeathTest::set_last_death_test_message(String::Format(
07253           "Death test count (%d) somehow exceeded expected maximum (%d)",
07254           death_test_index, flag->index()));
07255       return false;
07256     }
07257 
07258     if (!(flag->file() == file && flag->line() == line &&
07259           flag->index() == death_test_index)) {
07260       *test = NULL;
07261       return true;
07262     }
07263   }
07264 
07265 # if GTEST_OS_WINDOWS
07266 
07267   if (GTEST_FLAG(death_test_style) == "threadsafe" ||
07268       GTEST_FLAG(death_test_style) == "fast") {
07269     *test = new WindowsDeathTest(statement, regex, file, line);
07270   }
07271 
07272 # else
07273 
07274   if (GTEST_FLAG(death_test_style) == "threadsafe") {
07275     *test = new ExecDeathTest(statement, regex, file, line);
07276   } else if (GTEST_FLAG(death_test_style) == "fast") {
07277     *test = new NoExecDeathTest(statement, regex);
07278   }
07279 
07280 # endif  // GTEST_OS_WINDOWS
07281 
07282   else {  // NOLINT - this is more readable than unbalanced brackets inside #if.
07283     DeathTest::set_last_death_test_message(String::Format(
07284         "Unknown death test style \"%s\" encountered",
07285         GTEST_FLAG(death_test_style).c_str()));
07286     return false;
07287   }
07288 
07289   return true;
07290 }
07291 
07292 // Splits a given string on a given delimiter, populating a given
07293 // vector with the fields.  GTEST_HAS_DEATH_TEST implies that we have
07294 // ::std::string, so we can use it here.
07295 static void SplitString(const ::std::string& str, char delimiter,
07296                         ::std::vector< ::std::string>* dest) {
07297   ::std::vector< ::std::string> parsed;
07298   ::std::string::size_type pos = 0;
07299   while (::testing::internal::AlwaysTrue()) {
07300     const ::std::string::size_type colon = str.find(delimiter, pos);
07301     if (colon == ::std::string::npos) {
07302       parsed.push_back(str.substr(pos));
07303       break;
07304     } else {
07305       parsed.push_back(str.substr(pos, colon - pos));
07306       pos = colon + 1;
07307     }
07308   }
07309   dest->swap(parsed);
07310 }
07311 
07312 # if GTEST_OS_WINDOWS
07313 // Recreates the pipe and event handles from the provided parameters,
07314 // signals the event, and returns a file descriptor wrapped around the pipe
07315 // handle. This function is called in the child process only.
07316 int GetStatusFileDescriptor(unsigned int parent_process_id,
07317                             size_t write_handle_as_size_t,
07318                             size_t event_handle_as_size_t) {
07319   AutoHandle parent_process_handle(::OpenProcess(PROCESS_DUP_HANDLE,
07320                                                    FALSE,  // Non-inheritable.
07321                                                    parent_process_id));
07322   if (parent_process_handle.Get() == INVALID_HANDLE_VALUE) {
07323     DeathTestAbort(String::Format("Unable to open parent process %u",
07324                                   parent_process_id));
07325   }
07326 
07327   // TODO(vladl@google.com): Replace the following check with a
07328   // compile-time assertion when available.
07329   GTEST_CHECK_(sizeof(HANDLE) <= sizeof(size_t));
07330 
07331   const HANDLE write_handle =
07332       reinterpret_cast<HANDLE>(write_handle_as_size_t);
07333   HANDLE dup_write_handle;
07334 
07335   // The newly initialized handle is accessible only in in the parent
07336   // process. To obtain one accessible within the child, we need to use
07337   // DuplicateHandle.
07338   if (!::DuplicateHandle(parent_process_handle.Get(), write_handle,
07339                          ::GetCurrentProcess(), &dup_write_handle,
07340                          0x0,    // Requested privileges ignored since
07341                                  // DUPLICATE_SAME_ACCESS is used.
07342                          FALSE,  // Request non-inheritable handler.
07343                          DUPLICATE_SAME_ACCESS)) {
07344     DeathTestAbort(String::Format(
07345         "Unable to duplicate the pipe handle %Iu from the parent process %u",
07346         write_handle_as_size_t, parent_process_id));
07347   }
07348 
07349   const HANDLE event_handle = reinterpret_cast<HANDLE>(event_handle_as_size_t);
07350   HANDLE dup_event_handle;
07351 
07352   if (!::DuplicateHandle(parent_process_handle.Get(), event_handle,
07353                          ::GetCurrentProcess(), &dup_event_handle,
07354                          0x0,
07355                          FALSE,
07356                          DUPLICATE_SAME_ACCESS)) {
07357     DeathTestAbort(String::Format(
07358         "Unable to duplicate the event handle %Iu from the parent process %u",
07359         event_handle_as_size_t, parent_process_id));
07360   }
07361 
07362   const int write_fd =
07363       ::_open_osfhandle(reinterpret_cast<intptr_t>(dup_write_handle), O_APPEND);
07364   if (write_fd == -1) {
07365     DeathTestAbort(String::Format(
07366         "Unable to convert pipe handle %Iu to a file descriptor",
07367         write_handle_as_size_t));
07368   }
07369 
07370   // Signals the parent that the write end of the pipe has been acquired
07371   // so the parent can release its own write end.
07372   ::SetEvent(dup_event_handle);
07373 
07374   return write_fd;
07375 }
07376 # endif  // GTEST_OS_WINDOWS
07377 
07378 // Returns a newly created InternalRunDeathTestFlag object with fields
07379 // initialized from the GTEST_FLAG(internal_run_death_test) flag if
07380 // the flag is specified; otherwise returns NULL.
07381 InternalRunDeathTestFlag* ParseInternalRunDeathTestFlag() {
07382   if (GTEST_FLAG(internal_run_death_test) == "") return NULL;
07383 
07384   // GTEST_HAS_DEATH_TEST implies that we have ::std::string, so we
07385   // can use it here.
07386   int line = -1;
07387   int index = -1;
07388   ::std::vector< ::std::string> fields;
07389   SplitString(GTEST_FLAG(internal_run_death_test).c_str(), '|', &fields);
07390   int write_fd = -1;
07391 
07392 # if GTEST_OS_WINDOWS
07393 
07394   unsigned int parent_process_id = 0;
07395   size_t write_handle_as_size_t = 0;
07396   size_t event_handle_as_size_t = 0;
07397 
07398   if (fields.size() != 6
07399       || !ParseNaturalNumber(fields[1], &line)
07400       || !ParseNaturalNumber(fields[2], &index)
07401       || !ParseNaturalNumber(fields[3], &parent_process_id)
07402       || !ParseNaturalNumber(fields[4], &write_handle_as_size_t)
07403       || !ParseNaturalNumber(fields[5], &event_handle_as_size_t)) {
07404     DeathTestAbort(String::Format(
07405         "Bad --gtest_internal_run_death_test flag: %s",
07406         GTEST_FLAG(internal_run_death_test).c_str()));
07407   }
07408   write_fd = GetStatusFileDescriptor(parent_process_id,
07409                                      write_handle_as_size_t,
07410                                      event_handle_as_size_t);
07411 # else
07412 
07413   if (fields.size() != 4
07414       || !ParseNaturalNumber(fields[1], &line)
07415       || !ParseNaturalNumber(fields[2], &index)
07416       || !ParseNaturalNumber(fields[3], &write_fd)) {
07417     DeathTestAbort(String::Format(
07418         "Bad --gtest_internal_run_death_test flag: %s",
07419         GTEST_FLAG(internal_run_death_test).c_str()));
07420   }
07421 
07422 # endif  // GTEST_OS_WINDOWS
07423 
07424   return new InternalRunDeathTestFlag(fields[0], line, index, write_fd);
07425 }
07426 
07427 }  // namespace internal
07428 
07429 #endif  // GTEST_HAS_DEATH_TEST
07430 
07431 }  // namespace testing
