07463 
07464 #include <stdlib.h>
07465 
07466 #if GTEST_OS_WINDOWS_MOBILE
07467 # include <windows.h>
07468 #elif GTEST_OS_WINDOWS
07469 # include <direct.h>
07470 # include <io.h>
07471 #elif GTEST_OS_SYMBIAN || GTEST_OS_NACL
07472 // Symbian OpenC and NaCl have PATH_MAX in sys/syslimits.h
07473 # include <sys/syslimits.h>
07474 #else
07475 # include <limits.h>
07476 # include <climits>  // Some Linux distributions define PATH_MAX here.
07477 #endif  // GTEST_OS_WINDOWS_MOBILE
07478 
07479 #if GTEST_OS_WINDOWS
07480 # define GTEST_PATH_MAX_ _MAX_PATH
07481 #elif defined(PATH_MAX)
07482 # define GTEST_PATH_MAX_ PATH_MAX
07483 #elif defined(_XOPEN_PATH_MAX)
07484 # define GTEST_PATH_MAX_ _XOPEN_PATH_MAX
07485 #else
07486 # define GTEST_PATH_MAX_ _POSIX_PATH_MAX
07487 #endif  // GTEST_OS_WINDOWS
07488 
07489 
07490 namespace testing {
07491 namespace internal {
07492 
07493 #if GTEST_OS_WINDOWS
07494 // On Windows, '\\' is the standard path separator, but many tools and the
07495 // Windows API also accept '/' as an alternate path separator. Unless otherwise
07496 // noted, a file path can contain either kind of path separators, or a mixture
07497 // of them.
07498 const char kPathSeparator = '\\';
07499 const char kAlternatePathSeparator = '/';
07500 const char kPathSeparatorString[] = "\\";
07501 const char kAlternatePathSeparatorString[] = "/";
07502 # if GTEST_OS_WINDOWS_MOBILE
07503 // Windows CE doesn't have a current directory. You should not use
07504 // the current directory in tests on Windows CE, but this at least
07505 // provides a reasonable fallback.
07506 const char kCurrentDirectoryString[] = "\\";
07507 // Windows CE doesn't define INVALID_FILE_ATTRIBUTES
07508 const DWORD kInvalidFileAttributes = 0xffffffff;
07509 # else
07510 const char kCurrentDirectoryString[] = ".\\";
07511 # endif  // GTEST_OS_WINDOWS_MOBILE
07512 #else
07513 const char kPathSeparator = '/';
07514 const char kPathSeparatorString[] = "/";
07515 const char kCurrentDirectoryString[] = "./";
07516 #endif  // GTEST_OS_WINDOWS
07517 
07518 // Returns whether the given character is a valid path separator.
07519 static bool IsPathSeparator(char c) {
07520 #if GTEST_HAS_ALT_PATH_SEP_
07521   return (c == kPathSeparator) || (c == kAlternatePathSeparator);
07522 #else
07523   return c == kPathSeparator;
07524 #endif
07525 }
07526 
07527 // Returns the current working directory, or "" if unsuccessful.
07528 FilePath FilePath::GetCurrentDir() {
07529 #if GTEST_OS_WINDOWS_MOBILE
07530   // Windows CE doesn't have a current directory, so we just return
07531   // something reasonable.
07532   return FilePath(kCurrentDirectoryString);
07533 #elif GTEST_OS_WINDOWS
07534   char cwd[GTEST_PATH_MAX_ + 1] = { '\0' };
07535   return FilePath(_getcwd(cwd, sizeof(cwd)) == NULL ? "" : cwd);
07536 #else
07537   char cwd[GTEST_PATH_MAX_ + 1] = { '\0' };
07538   return FilePath(getcwd(cwd, sizeof(cwd)) == NULL ? "" : cwd);
07539 #endif  // GTEST_OS_WINDOWS_MOBILE
07540 }
07541 
07542 // Returns a copy of the FilePath with the case-insensitive extension removed.
07543 // Example: FilePath("dir/file.exe").RemoveExtension("EXE") returns
07544 // FilePath("dir/file"). If a case-insensitive extension is not
07545 // found, returns a copy of the original FilePath.
07546 FilePath FilePath::RemoveExtension(const char* extension) const {
07547   String dot_extension(String::Format(".%s", extension));
07548   if (pathname_.EndsWithCaseInsensitive(dot_extension.c_str())) {
07549     return FilePath(String(pathname_.c_str(), pathname_.length() - 4));
07550   }
07551   return *this;
07552 }
07553 
07554 // Returns a pointer to the last occurence of a valid path separator in
07555 // the FilePath. On Windows, for example, both '/' and '\' are valid path
07556 // separators. Returns NULL if no path separator was found.
07557 const char* FilePath::FindLastPathSeparator() const {
07558   const char* const last_sep = strrchr(c_str(), kPathSeparator);
07559 #if GTEST_HAS_ALT_PATH_SEP_
07560   const char* const last_alt_sep = strrchr(c_str(), kAlternatePathSeparator);
07561   // Comparing two pointers of which only one is NULL is undefined.
07562   if (last_alt_sep != NULL &&
07563       (last_sep == NULL || last_alt_sep > last_sep)) {
07564     return last_alt_sep;
07565   }
07566 #endif
07567   return last_sep;
07568 }
07569 
07570 // Returns a copy of the FilePath with the directory part removed.
07571 // Example: FilePath("path/to/file").RemoveDirectoryName() returns
07572 // FilePath("file"). If there is no directory part ("just_a_file"), it returns
07573 // the FilePath unmodified. If there is no file part ("just_a_dir/") it
07574 // returns an empty FilePath ("").
07575 // On Windows platform, '\' is the path separator, otherwise it is '/'.
07576 FilePath FilePath::RemoveDirectoryName() const {
07577   const char* const last_sep = FindLastPathSeparator();
07578   return last_sep ? FilePath(String(last_sep + 1)) : *this;
07579 }
07580 
07581 // RemoveFileName returns the directory path with the filename removed.
07582 // Example: FilePath("path/to/file").RemoveFileName() returns "path/to/".
07583 // If the FilePath is "a_file" or "/a_file", RemoveFileName returns
07584 // FilePath("./") or, on Windows, FilePath(".\\"). If the filepath does
07585 // not have a file, like "just/a/dir/", it returns the FilePath unmodified.
07586 // On Windows platform, '\' is the path separator, otherwise it is '/'.
07587 FilePath FilePath::RemoveFileName() const {
07588   const char* const last_sep = FindLastPathSeparator();
07589   String dir;
07590   if (last_sep) {
07591     dir = String(c_str(), last_sep + 1 - c_str());
07592   } else {
07593     dir = kCurrentDirectoryString;
07594   }
07595   return FilePath(dir);
07596 }
07597 
07598 // Helper functions for naming files in a directory for xml output.
07599 
07600 // Given directory = "dir", base_name = "test", number = 0,
07601 // extension = "xml", returns "dir/test.xml". If number is greater
07602 // than zero (e.g., 12), returns "dir/test_12.xml".
07603 // On Windows platform, uses \ as the separator rather than /.
07604 FilePath FilePath::MakeFileName(const FilePath& directory,
07605                                 const FilePath& base_name,
07606                                 int number,
07607                                 const char* extension) {
07608   String file;
07609   if (number == 0) {
07610     file = String::Format("%s.%s", base_name.c_str(), extension);
07611   } else {
07612     file = String::Format("%s_%d.%s", base_name.c_str(), number, extension);
07613   }
07614   return ConcatPaths(directory, FilePath(file));
07615 }
07616 
07617 // Given directory = "dir", relative_path = "test.xml", returns "dir/test.xml".
07618 // On Windows, uses \ as the separator rather than /.
07619 FilePath FilePath::ConcatPaths(const FilePath& directory,
07620                                const FilePath& relative_path) {
07621   if (directory.IsEmpty())
07622     return relative_path;
07623   const FilePath dir(directory.RemoveTrailingPathSeparator());
07624   return FilePath(String::Format("%s%c%s", dir.c_str(), kPathSeparator,
07625                                  relative_path.c_str()));
07626 }
07627 
07628 // Returns true if pathname describes something findable in the file-system,
07629 // either a file, directory, or whatever.
07630 bool FilePath::FileOrDirectoryExists() const {
07631 #if GTEST_OS_WINDOWS_MOBILE
07632   LPCWSTR unicode = String::AnsiToUtf16(pathname_.c_str());
07633   const DWORD attributes = GetFileAttributes(unicode);
07634   delete [] unicode;
07635   return attributes != kInvalidFileAttributes;
07636 #else
07637   posix::StatStruct file_stat;
07638   return posix::Stat(pathname_.c_str(), &file_stat) == 0;
07639 #endif  // GTEST_OS_WINDOWS_MOBILE
07640 }
07641 
07642 // Returns true if pathname describes a directory in the file-system
07643 // that exists.
07644 bool FilePath::DirectoryExists() const {
07645   bool result = false;
07646 #if GTEST_OS_WINDOWS
07647   // Don't strip off trailing separator if path is a root directory on
07648   // Windows (like "C:\\").
07649   const FilePath& path(IsRootDirectory() ? *this :
07650                                            RemoveTrailingPathSeparator());
07651 #else
07652   const FilePath& path(*this);
07653 #endif
07654 
07655 #if GTEST_OS_WINDOWS_MOBILE
07656   LPCWSTR unicode = String::AnsiToUtf16(path.c_str());
07657   const DWORD attributes = GetFileAttributes(unicode);
07658   delete [] unicode;
07659   if ((attributes != kInvalidFileAttributes) &&
07660       (attributes & FILE_ATTRIBUTE_DIRECTORY)) {
07661     result = true;
07662   }
07663 #else
07664   posix::StatStruct file_stat;
07665   result = posix::Stat(path.c_str(), &file_stat) == 0 &&
07666       posix::IsDir(file_stat);
07667 #endif  // GTEST_OS_WINDOWS_MOBILE
07668 
07669   return result;
07670 }
07671 
07672 // Returns true if pathname describes a root directory. (Windows has one
07673 // root directory per disk drive.)
07674 bool FilePath::IsRootDirectory() const {
07675 #if GTEST_OS_WINDOWS
07676   // TODO(wan@google.com): on Windows a network share like
07677   // \\server\share can be a root directory, although it cannot be the
07678   // current directory.  Handle this properly.
07679   return pathname_.length() == 3 && IsAbsolutePath();
07680 #else
07681   return pathname_.length() == 1 && IsPathSeparator(pathname_.c_str()[0]);
07682 #endif
07683 }
07684 
07685 // Returns true if pathname describes an absolute path.
07686 bool FilePath::IsAbsolutePath() const {
07687   const char* const name = pathname_.c_str();
07688 #if GTEST_OS_WINDOWS
07689   return pathname_.length() >= 3 &&
07690      ((name[0] >= 'a' && name[0] <= 'z') ||
07691       (name[0] >= 'A' && name[0] <= 'Z')) &&
07692      name[1] == ':' &&
07693      IsPathSeparator(name[2]);
07694 #else
07695   return IsPathSeparator(name[0]);
07696 #endif
07697 }
07698 
07699 // Returns a pathname for a file that does not currently exist. The pathname
07700 // will be directory/base_name.extension or
07701 // directory/base_name_<number>.extension if directory/base_name.extension
07702 // already exists. The number will be incremented until a pathname is found
07703 // that does not already exist.
07704 // Examples: 'dir/foo_test.xml' or 'dir/foo_test_1.xml'.
07705 // There could be a race condition if two or more processes are calling this
07706 // function at the same time -- they could both pick the same filename.
07707 FilePath FilePath::GenerateUniqueFileName(const FilePath& directory,
07708                                           const FilePath& base_name,
07709                                           const char* extension) {
07710   FilePath full_pathname;
07711   int number = 0;
07712   do {
07713     full_pathname.Set(MakeFileName(directory, base_name, number++, extension));
07714   } while (full_pathname.FileOrDirectoryExists());
07715   return full_pathname;
07716 }
07717 
07718 // Returns true if FilePath ends with a path separator, which indicates that
07719 // it is intended to represent a directory. Returns false otherwise.
07720 // This does NOT check that a directory (or file) actually exists.
07721 bool FilePath::IsDirectory() const {
07722   return !pathname_.empty() &&
07723          IsPathSeparator(pathname_.c_str()[pathname_.length() - 1]);
07724 }
07725 
07726 // Create directories so that path exists. Returns true if successful or if
07727 // the directories already exist; returns false if unable to create directories
07728 // for any reason.
07729 bool FilePath::CreateDirectoriesRecursively() const {
07730   if (!this->IsDirectory()) {
07731     return false;
07732   }
07733 
07734   if (pathname_.length() == 0 || this->DirectoryExists()) {
07735     return true;
07736   }
07737 
07738   const FilePath parent(this->RemoveTrailingPathSeparator().RemoveFileName());
07739   return parent.CreateDirectoriesRecursively() && this->CreateFolder();
07740 }
07741 
07742 // Create the directory so that path exists. Returns true if successful or
07743 // if the directory already exists; returns false if unable to create the
07744 // directory for any reason, including if the parent directory does not
07745 // exist. Not named "CreateDirectory" because that's a macro on Windows.
07746 bool FilePath::CreateFolder() const {
07747 #if GTEST_OS_WINDOWS_MOBILE
07748   FilePath removed_sep(this->RemoveTrailingPathSeparator());
07749   LPCWSTR unicode = String::AnsiToUtf16(removed_sep.c_str());
07750   int result = CreateDirectory(unicode, NULL) ? 0 : -1;
07751   delete [] unicode;
07752 #elif GTEST_OS_WINDOWS
07753   int result = _mkdir(pathname_.c_str());
07754 #else
07755   int result = mkdir(pathname_.c_str(), 0777);
07756 #endif  // GTEST_OS_WINDOWS_MOBILE
07757 
07758   if (result == -1) {
07759     return this->DirectoryExists();  // An error is OK if the directory exists.
07760   }
07761   return true;  // No error.
07762 }
07763 
07764 // If input name has a trailing separator character, remove it and return the
07765 // name, otherwise return the name string unmodified.
07766 // On Windows platform, uses \ as the separator, other platforms use /.
07767 FilePath FilePath::RemoveTrailingPathSeparator() const {
07768   return IsDirectory()
07769       ? FilePath(String(pathname_.c_str(), pathname_.length() - 1))
07770       : *this;
07771 }
07772 
07773 // Removes any redundant separators that might be in the pathname.
07774 // For example, "bar///foo" becomes "bar/foo". Does not eliminate other
07775 // redundancies that might be in a pathname involving "." or "..".
07776 // TODO(wan@google.com): handle Windows network shares (e.g. \\server\share).
07777 void FilePath::Normalize() {
07778   if (pathname_.c_str() == NULL) {
07779     pathname_ = "";
07780     return;
07781   }
07782   const char* src = pathname_.c_str();
07783   char* const dest = new char[pathname_.length() + 1];
07784   char* dest_ptr = dest;
07785   memset(dest_ptr, 0, pathname_.length() + 1);
07786 
07787   while (*src != '\0') {
07788     *dest_ptr = *src;
07789     if (!IsPathSeparator(*src)) {
07790       src++;
07791     } else {
07792 #if GTEST_HAS_ALT_PATH_SEP_
07793       if (*dest_ptr == kAlternatePathSeparator) {
07794         *dest_ptr = kPathSeparator;
07795       }
07796 #endif
07797       while (IsPathSeparator(*src))
07798         src++;
07799     }
07800     dest_ptr++;
07801   }
07802   *dest_ptr = '\0';
07803   pathname_ = dest;
07804   delete[] dest;
07805 }
07806 
07807 }  // namespace internal
07808 }  // namespace testing

07810 // All rights reserved.

07817 // notice, this list of conditions and the following disclaimer.
07818 //     * Redistributions in binary form must reproduce the above
07819 // copyright notice, this list of conditions and the following disclaimer
07820 // in the documentation and/or other materials provided with the
07821 // distribution.
07822 //     * Neither the name of Google Inc. nor the names of its
07823 // contributors may be used to endorse or promote products derived from
07824 // this software without specific prior written permission.
07825 //

07827 // "AS IS" AND ANY EXPRESS OR IMPLIED WARRANTIES, INCLUDING, BUT NOT
07828 // LIMITED TO, THE IMPLIED WARRANTIES OF MERCHANTABILITY AND FITNESS FOR
07829 // A PARTICULAR PURPOSE ARE DISCLAIMED. IN NO EVENT SHALL THE COPYRIGHT
07830 // OWNER OR CONTRIBUTORS BE LIABLE FOR ANY DIRECT, INDIRECT, INCIDENTAL,
07831 // SPECIAL, EXEMPLARY, OR CONSEQUENTIAL DAMAGES (INCLUDING, BUT NOT
07832 // LIMITED TO, PROCUREMENT OF SUBSTITUTE GOODS OR SERVICES; LOSS OF USE,
07833 // DATA, OR PROFITS; OR BUSINESS INTERRUPTION) HOWEVER CAUSED AND ON ANY
07834 // THEORY OF LIABILITY, WHETHER IN CONTRACT, STRICT LIABILITY, OR TORT

07840 
07841 #include <limits.h>
07842 #include <stdlib.h>
07843 #include <stdio.h>
07844 #include <string.h>
07845 
07846 #if GTEST_OS_WINDOWS_MOBILE
07847 # include <windows.h>  // For TerminateProcess()
07848 #elif GTEST_OS_WINDOWS
07849 # include <io.h>
07850 # include <sys/stat.h>
07851 #else
07852 # include <unistd.h>
07853 #endif  // GTEST_OS_WINDOWS_MOBILE
07854 
07855 #if GTEST_OS_MAC
07856 # include <mach/mach_init.h>
07857 # include <mach/task.h>
07858 # include <mach/vm_map.h>
07859 #endif  // GTEST_OS_MAC
07860 
07861 
07862 // Indicates that this translation unit is part of Google Test's
07863 // implementation.  It must come before gtest-internal-inl.h is
07864 // included, or there will be a compiler error.  This trick is to
07865 // prevent a user from accidentally including gtest-internal-inl.h in
07866 // his code.
07867 #define GTEST_IMPLEMENTATION_ 1
07868 #undef GTEST_IMPLEMENTATION_
07869 
07870 namespace testing {
07871 namespace internal {
07872 
07873 #if defined(_MSC_VER) || defined(__BORLANDC__)
07874 // MSVC and C++Builder do not provide a definition of STDERR_FILENO.
07875 const int kStdOutFileno = 1;
07876 const int kStdErrFileno = 2;
07877 #else
07878 const int kStdOutFileno = STDOUT_FILENO;
07879 const int kStdErrFileno = STDERR_FILENO;
07880 #endif  // _MSC_VER
07881 
07882 #if GTEST_OS_MAC
07883 
07884 // Returns the number of threads running in the process, or 0 to indicate that
07885 // we cannot detect it.
07886 size_t GetThreadCount() {
07887   const task_t task = mach_task_self();
07888   mach_msg_type_number_t thread_count;
07889   thread_act_array_t thread_list;
07890   const kern_return_t status = task_threads(task, &thread_list, &thread_count);
07891   if (status == KERN_SUCCESS) {
07892     // task_threads allocates resources in thread_list and we need to free them
07893     // to avoid leaks.
07894     vm_deallocate(task,
07895                   reinterpret_cast<vm_address_t>(thread_list),
07896                   sizeof(thread_t) * thread_count);
07897     return static_cast<size_t>(thread_count);
07898   } else {
07899     return 0;
07900   }
07901 }
07902 
07903 #else
07904 
07905 size_t GetThreadCount() {
07906   // There's no portable way to detect the number of threads, so we just
07907   // return 0 to indicate that we cannot detect it.
07908   return 0;
07909 }
07910 
07911 #endif  // GTEST_OS_MAC
07912 
07913 #if GTEST_USES_POSIX_RE
07914 
07915 // Implements RE.  Currently only needed for death tests.
07916 
07917 RE::~RE() {
07918   if (is_valid_) {
07919     // regfree'ing an invalid regex might crash because the content
07920     // of the regex is undefined. Since the regex's are essentially
07921     // the same, one cannot be valid (or invalid) without the other
07922     // being so too.
07923     regfree(&partial_regex_);
07924     regfree(&full_regex_);
07925   }
07926   free(const_cast<char*>(pattern_));
07927 }
07928 
07929 // Returns true iff regular expression re matches the entire str.
07930 bool RE::FullMatch(const char* str, const RE& re) {
07931   if (!re.is_valid_) return false;
07932 
07933   regmatch_t match;
07934   return regexec(&re.full_regex_, str, 1, &match, 0) == 0;
07935 }
07936 
07937 // Returns true iff regular expression re matches a substring of str
07938 // (including str itself).
07939 bool RE::PartialMatch(const char* str, const RE& re) {
07940   if (!re.is_valid_) return false;
07941 
07942   regmatch_t match;
07943   return regexec(&re.partial_regex_, str, 1, &match, 0) == 0;
07944 }
07945 
07946 // Initializes an RE from its string representation.
07947 void RE::Init(const char* regex) {
07948   pattern_ = posix::StrDup(regex);
07949 
07950   // Reserves enough bytes to hold the regular expression used for a
07951   // full match.
07952   const size_t full_regex_len = strlen(regex) + 10;
07953   char* const full_pattern = new char[full_regex_len];
07954 
07955   snprintf(full_pattern, full_regex_len, "^(%s)$", regex);
07956   is_valid_ = regcomp(&full_regex_, full_pattern, REG_EXTENDED) == 0;
07957   // We want to call regcomp(&partial_regex_, ...) even if the
07958   // previous expression returns false.  Otherwise partial_regex_ may
07959   // not be properly initialized can may cause trouble when it's
07960   // freed.
07961   //
07962   // Some implementation of POSIX regex (e.g. on at least some
07963   // versions of Cygwin) doesn't accept the empty string as a valid
07964   // regex.  We change it to an equivalent form "()" to be safe.
07965   if (is_valid_) {
07966     const char* const partial_regex = (*regex == '\0') ? "()" : regex;
07967     is_valid_ = regcomp(&partial_regex_, partial_regex, REG_EXTENDED) == 0;
07968   }
07969   EXPECT_TRUE(is_valid_)
07970       << "Regular expression \"" << regex
07971       << "\" is not a valid POSIX Extended regular expression.";
07972 
07973   delete[] full_pattern;
07974 }
07975 
07976 #elif GTEST_USES_SIMPLE_RE
07977 
07978 // Returns true iff ch appears anywhere in str (excluding the
07979 // terminating '\0' character).
07980 bool IsInSet(char ch, const char* str) {
07981   return ch != '\0' && strchr(str, ch) != NULL;
07982 }
07983 
07984 // Returns true iff ch belongs to the given classification.  Unlike
07985 // similar functions in <ctype.h>, these aren't affected by the
07986 // current locale.
07987 bool IsAsciiDigit(char ch) { return '0' <= ch && ch <= '9'; }
07988 bool IsAsciiPunct(char ch) {
07989   return IsInSet(ch, "^-!\"#$%&'()*+,./:;<=>?@[\\]_`{|}~");
07990 }
07991 bool IsRepeat(char ch) { return IsInSet(ch, "?*+"); }
07992 bool IsAsciiWhiteSpace(char ch) { return IsInSet(ch, " \f\n\r\t\v"); }
07993 bool IsAsciiWordChar(char ch) {
07994   return ('a' <= ch && ch <= 'z') || ('A' <= ch && ch <= 'Z') ||
07995       ('0' <= ch && ch <= '9') || ch == '_';
07996 }
07997 
07998 // Returns true iff "\\c" is a supported escape sequence.
07999 bool IsValidEscape(char c) {
08000   return (IsAsciiPunct(c) || IsInSet(c, "dDfnrsStvwW"));
08001 }
08002 
08003 // Returns true iff the given atom (specified by escaped and pattern)
08004 // matches ch.  The result is undefined if the atom is invalid.
08005 bool AtomMatchesChar(bool escaped, char pattern_char, char ch) {
08006   if (escaped) {  // "\\p" where p is pattern_char.
08007     switch (pattern_char) {
08008       case 'd': return IsAsciiDigit(ch);
08009       case 'D': return !IsAsciiDigit(ch);
08010       case 'f': return ch == '\f';
08011       case 'n': return ch == '\n';
08012       case 'r': return ch == '\r';
08013       case 's': return IsAsciiWhiteSpace(ch);
08014       case 'S': return !IsAsciiWhiteSpace(ch);
08015       case 't': return ch == '\t';
08016       case 'v': return ch == '\v';
08017       case 'w': return IsAsciiWordChar(ch);
08018       case 'W': return !IsAsciiWordChar(ch);
08019     }
08020     return IsAsciiPunct(pattern_char) && pattern_char == ch;
08021   }
08022 
08023   return (pattern_char == '.' && ch != '\n') || pattern_char == ch;
08024 }
08025 
08026 // Helper function used by ValidateRegex() to format error messages.
08027 String FormatRegexSyntaxError(const char* regex, int index) {
08028   return (Message() << "Syntax error at index " << index
08029           << " in simple regular expression \"" << regex << "\": ").GetString();
08030 }
08031 
08032 // Generates non-fatal failures and returns false if regex is invalid;
08033 // otherwise returns true.
08034 bool ValidateRegex(const char* regex) {
08035   if (regex == NULL) {
08036     // TODO(wan@google.com): fix the source file location in the
08037     // assertion failures to match where the regex is used in user
08038     // code.
08039     ADD_FAILURE() << "NULL is not a valid simple regular expression.";
08040     return false;
08041   }
08042 
08043   bool is_valid = true;
08044 
08045   // True iff ?, *, or + can follow the previous atom.
08046   bool prev_repeatable = false;
08047   for (int i = 0; regex[i]; i++) {
08048     if (regex[i] == '\\') {  // An escape sequence
08049       i++;
08050       if (regex[i] == '\0') {
08051         ADD_FAILURE() << FormatRegexSyntaxError(regex, i - 1)
08052                       << "'\\' cannot appear at the end.";
08053         return false;
08054       }
08055 
08056       if (!IsValidEscape(regex[i])) {
08057         ADD_FAILURE() << FormatRegexSyntaxError(regex, i - 1)
08058                       << "invalid escape sequence \"\\" << regex[i] << "\".";
08059         is_valid = false;
08060       }
08061       prev_repeatable = true;
08062     } else {  // Not an escape sequence.
08063       const char ch = regex[i];
08064 
08065       if (ch == '^' && i > 0) {
08066         ADD_FAILURE() << FormatRegexSyntaxError(regex, i)
08067                       << "'^' can only appear at the beginning.";
08068         is_valid = false;
08069       } else if (ch == '$' && regex[i + 1] != '\0') {
08070         ADD_FAILURE() << FormatRegexSyntaxError(regex, i)
08071                       << "'$' can only appear at the end.";
08072         is_valid = false;
08073       } else if (IsInSet(ch, "()[]{}|")) {
08074         ADD_FAILURE() << FormatRegexSyntaxError(regex, i)
08075                       << "'" << ch << "' is unsupported.";
08076         is_valid = false;
08077       } else if (IsRepeat(ch) && !prev_repeatable) {
08078         ADD_FAILURE() << FormatRegexSyntaxError(regex, i)
08079                       << "'" << ch << "' can only follow a repeatable token.";
08080         is_valid = false;
08081       }
08082 
08083       prev_repeatable = !IsInSet(ch, "^$?*+");
08084     }
08085   }
08086 
08087   return is_valid;
08088 }
08089 
08090 // Matches a repeated regex atom followed by a valid simple regular
08091 // expression.  The regex atom is defined as c if escaped is false,
08092 // or \c otherwise.  repeat is the repetition meta character (?, *,
08093 // or +).  The behavior is undefined if str contains too many
08094 // characters to be indexable by size_t, in which case the test will
08095 // probably time out anyway.  We are fine with this limitation as
08096 // std::string has it too.
08097 bool MatchRepetitionAndRegexAtHead(
08098     bool escaped, char c, char repeat, const char* regex,
08099     const char* str) {
08100   const size_t min_count = (repeat == '+') ? 1 : 0;
08101   const size_t max_count = (repeat == '?') ? 1 :
08102       static_cast<size_t>(-1) - 1;
08103   // We cannot call numeric_limits::max() as it conflicts with the
08104   // max() macro on Windows.
08105 
08106   for (size_t i = 0; i <= max_count; ++i) {
08107     // We know that the atom matches each of the first i characters in str.
08108     if (i >= min_count && MatchRegexAtHead(regex, str + i)) {
08109       // We have enough matches at the head, and the tail matches too.
08110       // Since we only care about *whether* the pattern matches str
08111       // (as opposed to *how* it matches), there is no need to find a
08112       // greedy match.
08113       return true;
08114     }
08115     if (str[i] == '\0' || !AtomMatchesChar(escaped, c, str[i]))
08116       return false;
08117   }
08118   return false;
08119 }
08120 
08121 // Returns true iff regex matches a prefix of str.  regex must be a
08122 // valid simple regular expression and not start with "^", or the
08123 // result is undefined.
08124 bool MatchRegexAtHead(const char* regex, const char* str) {
08125   if (*regex == '\0')  // An empty regex matches a prefix of anything.
08126     return true;
08127 
08128   // "$" only matches the end of a string.  Note that regex being
08129   // valid guarantees that there's nothing after "$" in it.
08130   if (*regex == '$')
08131     return *str == '\0';
08132 
08133   // Is the first thing in regex an escape sequence?
08134   const bool escaped = *regex == '\\';
08135   if (escaped)
08136     ++regex;
08137   if (IsRepeat(regex[1])) {
08138     // MatchRepetitionAndRegexAtHead() calls MatchRegexAtHead(), so
08139     // here's an indirect recursion.  It terminates as the regex gets
08140     // shorter in each recursion.
08141     return MatchRepetitionAndRegexAtHead(
08142         escaped, regex[0], regex[1], regex + 2, str);
08143   } else {
08144     // regex isn't empty, isn't "$", and doesn't start with a
08145     // repetition.  We match the first atom of regex with the first
08146     // character of str and recurse.
08147     return (*str != '\0') && AtomMatchesChar(escaped, *regex, *str) &&
08148         MatchRegexAtHead(regex + 1, str + 1);
08149   }
08150 }
08151 
08152 // Returns true iff regex matches any substring of str.  regex must be
08153 // a valid simple regular expression, or the result is undefined.
08154 //
08155 // The algorithm is recursive, but the recursion depth doesn't exceed
08156 // the regex length, so we won't need to worry about running out of
08157 // stack space normally.  In rare cases the time complexity can be
08158 // exponential with respect to the regex length + the string length,
08159 // but usually it's must faster (often close to linear).
08160 bool MatchRegexAnywhere(const char* regex, const char* str) {
08161   if (regex == NULL || str == NULL)
08162     return false;
08163 
08164   if (*regex == '^')
08165     return MatchRegexAtHead(regex + 1, str);
08166 
08167   // A successful match can be anywhere in str.
08168   do {
08169     if (MatchRegexAtHead(regex, str))
08170       return true;
08171   } while (*str++ != '\0');
08172   return false;
08173 }
08174 
08175 // Implements the RE class.
08176 
08177 RE::~RE() {
08178   free(const_cast<char*>(pattern_));
08179   free(const_cast<char*>(full_pattern_));
08180 }
08181 
08182 // Returns true iff regular expression re matches the entire str.
08183 bool RE::FullMatch(const char* str, const RE& re) {
08184   return re.is_valid_ && MatchRegexAnywhere(re.full_pattern_, str);
08185 }
08186 
08187 // Returns true iff regular expression re matches a substring of str
08188 // (including str itself).
08189 bool RE::PartialMatch(const char* str, const RE& re) {
08190   return re.is_valid_ && MatchRegexAnywhere(re.pattern_, str);
08191 }
08192 
08193 // Initializes an RE from its string representation.
08194 void RE::Init(const char* regex) {
08195   pattern_ = full_pattern_ = NULL;
08196   if (regex != NULL) {
08197     pattern_ = posix::StrDup(regex);
08198   }
08199 
08200   is_valid_ = ValidateRegex(regex);
08201   if (!is_valid_) {
08202     // No need to calculate the full pattern when the regex is invalid.
08203     return;
08204   }
08205 
08206   const size_t len = strlen(regex);
08207   // Reserves enough bytes to hold the regular expression used for a
08208   // full match: we need space to prepend a '^', append a '$', and
08209   // terminate the string with '\0'.
08210   char* buffer = static_cast<char*>(malloc(len + 3));
08211   full_pattern_ = buffer;
08212 
08213   if (*regex != '^')
08214     *buffer++ = '^';  // Makes sure full_pattern_ starts with '^'.
08215 
08216   // We don't use snprintf or strncpy, as they trigger a warning when
08217   // compiled with VC++ 8.0.
08218   memcpy(buffer, regex, len);
08219   buffer += len;
08220 
08221   if (len == 0 || regex[len - 1] != '$')
08222     *buffer++ = '$';  // Makes sure full_pattern_ ends with '$'.
08223 
08224   *buffer = '\0';
08225 }
08226 
08227 #endif  // GTEST_USES_POSIX_RE
08228 
08229 const char kUnknownFile[] = "unknown file";
08230 
08231 // Formats a source file path and a line number as they would appear
08232 // in an error message from the compiler used to compile this code.
08233 GTEST_API_ ::std::string FormatFileLocation(const char* file, int line) {
08234   const char* const file_name = file == NULL ? kUnknownFile : file;
08235 
08236   if (line < 0) {
08237     return String::Format("%s:", file_name).c_str();
08238   }
08239 #ifdef _MSC_VER
08240   return String::Format("%s(%d):", file_name, line).c_str();
08241 #else
08242   return String::Format("%s:%d:", file_name, line).c_str();
08243 #endif  // _MSC_VER
08244 }
08245 
08246 // Formats a file location for compiler-independent XML output.
08247 // Although this function is not platform dependent, we put it next to
08248 // FormatFileLocation in order to contrast the two functions.
08249 // Note that FormatCompilerIndependentFileLocation() does NOT append colon
08250 // to the file location it produces, unlike FormatFileLocation().
08251 GTEST_API_ ::std::string FormatCompilerIndependentFileLocation(
08252     const char* file, int line) {
08253   const char* const file_name = file == NULL ? kUnknownFile : file;
08254 
08255   if (line < 0)
08256     return file_name;
08257   else
08258     return String::Format("%s:%d", file_name, line).c_str();
08259 }
08260 
08261 
08262 GTestLog::GTestLog(GTestLogSeverity severity, const char* file, int line)
08263     : severity_(severity) {
08264   const char* const marker =
08265       severity == GTEST_INFO ?    "[  INFO ]" :
08266       severity == GTEST_WARNING ? "[WARNING]" :
08267       severity == GTEST_ERROR ?   "[ ERROR ]" : "[ FATAL ]";
08268   GetStream() << ::std::endl << marker << " "
08269               << FormatFileLocation(file, line).c_str() << ": ";
08270 }
08271 
08272 // Flushes the buffers and, if severity is GTEST_FATAL, aborts the program.
08273 GTestLog::~GTestLog() {
08274   GetStream() << ::std::endl;
08275   if (severity_ == GTEST_FATAL) {
08276     fflush(stderr);
08277     posix::Abort();
08278   }
08279 }
08280 // Disable Microsoft deprecation warnings for POSIX functions called from
08281 // this class (creat, dup, dup2, and close)
08282 #ifdef _MSC_VER
08283 # pragma warning(push)
08284 # pragma warning(disable: 4996)
08285 #endif  // _MSC_VER
08286 
08287 #if GTEST_HAS_STREAM_REDIRECTION
08288 
08289 // Object that captures an output stream (stdout/stderr).
08290 class CapturedStream {
08291  public:
08292   // The ctor redirects the stream to a temporary file.
08293   CapturedStream(int fd) : fd_(fd), uncaptured_fd_(dup(fd)) {
08294 
08295 # if GTEST_OS_WINDOWS
08296     char temp_dir_path[MAX_PATH + 1] = { '\0' };  // NOLINT
08297     char temp_file_path[MAX_PATH + 1] = { '\0' };  // NOLINT
08298 
08299     ::GetTempPathA(sizeof(temp_dir_path), temp_dir_path);
08300     const UINT success = ::GetTempFileNameA(temp_dir_path,
08301                                             "gtest_redir",
08302                                             0,  // Generate unique file name.
08303                                             temp_file_path);
08304     GTEST_CHECK_(success != 0)
08305         << "Unable to create a temporary file in " << temp_dir_path;
08306     const int captured_fd = creat(temp_file_path, _S_IREAD | _S_IWRITE);
08307     GTEST_CHECK_(captured_fd != -1) << "Unable to open temporary file "
08308                                     << temp_file_path;
08309     filename_ = temp_file_path;
08310 # else
08311     // There's no guarantee that a test has write access to the
08312     // current directory, so we create the temporary file in the /tmp
08313     // directory instead.
08314     char name_template[] = "/tmp/captured_stream.XXXXXX";
08315     const int captured_fd = mkstemp(name_template);
08316     filename_ = name_template;
08317 # endif  // GTEST_OS_WINDOWS
08318     fflush(NULL);
08319     dup2(captured_fd, fd_);
08320     close(captured_fd);
08321   }
08322 
08323   ~CapturedStream() {
08324     remove(filename_.c_str());
08325   }
08326 
08327   String GetCapturedString() {
08328     if (uncaptured_fd_ != -1) {
08329       // Restores the original stream.
08330       fflush(NULL);
08331       dup2(uncaptured_fd_, fd_);
08332       close(uncaptured_fd_);
08333       uncaptured_fd_ = -1;
08334     }
08335 
08336     FILE* const file = posix::FOpen(filename_.c_str(), "r");
08337     const String content = ReadEntireFile(file);
08338     posix::FClose(file);
08339     return content;
08340   }
08341 
08342  private:
08343   // Reads the entire content of a file as a String.
08344   static String ReadEntireFile(FILE* file);
08345 
08346   // Returns the size (in bytes) of a file.
08347   static size_t GetFileSize(FILE* file);
08348 
08349   const int fd_;  // A stream to capture.
08350   int uncaptured_fd_;
08351   // Name of the temporary file holding the stderr output.
08352   ::std::string filename_;
08353 
08354   GTEST_DISALLOW_COPY_AND_ASSIGN_(CapturedStream);
08355 };
08356 
08357 // Returns the size (in bytes) of a file.
08358 size_t CapturedStream::GetFileSize(FILE* file) {
08359   fseek(file, 0, SEEK_END);
08360   return static_cast<size_t>(ftell(file));
08361 }
08362 
08363 // Reads the entire content of a file as a string.
08364 String CapturedStream::ReadEntireFile(FILE* file) {
08365   const size_t file_size = GetFileSize(file);
08366   char* const buffer = new char[file_size];
08367 
08368   size_t bytes_last_read = 0;  // # of bytes read in the last fread()
08369   size_t bytes_read = 0;       // # of bytes read so far
08370 
08371   fseek(file, 0, SEEK_SET);
08372 
08373   // Keeps reading the file until we cannot read further or the
08374   // pre-determined file size is reached.
08375   do {
08376     bytes_last_read = fread(buffer+bytes_read, 1, file_size-bytes_read, file);
08377     bytes_read += bytes_last_read;
08378   } while (bytes_last_read > 0 && bytes_read < file_size);
08379 
08380   const String content(buffer, bytes_read);
08381   delete[] buffer;
08382 
08383   return content;
08384 }
08385 
08386 # ifdef _MSC_VER
08387 #  pragma warning(pop)
08388 # endif  // _MSC_VER
08389 
08390 static CapturedStream* g_captured_stderr = NULL;
08391 static CapturedStream* g_captured_stdout = NULL;
08392 
08393 // Starts capturing an output stream (stdout/stderr).
08394 void CaptureStream(int fd, const char* stream_name, CapturedStream** stream) {
08395   if (*stream != NULL) {
08396     GTEST_LOG_(FATAL) << "Only one " << stream_name
08397                       << " capturer can exist at a time.";
08398   }
08399   *stream = new CapturedStream(fd);
08400 }
08401 
08402 // Stops capturing the output stream and returns the captured string.
08403 String GetCapturedStream(CapturedStream** captured_stream) {
08404   const String content = (*captured_stream)->GetCapturedString();
08405 
08406   delete *captured_stream;
08407   *captured_stream = NULL;
08408 
08409   return content;
08410 }
08411 
08412 // Starts capturing stdout.
08413 void CaptureStdout() {
08414   CaptureStream(kStdOutFileno, "stdout", &g_captured_stdout);
08415 }
08416 
08417 // Starts capturing stderr.
08418 void CaptureStderr() {
08419   CaptureStream(kStdErrFileno, "stderr", &g_captured_stderr);
08420 }
08421 
08422 // Stops capturing stdout and returns the captured string.
08423 String GetCapturedStdout() { return GetCapturedStream(&g_captured_stdout); }
08424 
08425 // Stops capturing stderr and returns the captured string.
08426 String GetCapturedStderr() { return GetCapturedStream(&g_captured_stderr); }
08427 
08428 #endif  // GTEST_HAS_STREAM_REDIRECTION
08429 
08430 #if GTEST_HAS_DEATH_TEST
08431 
08432 // A copy of all command line arguments.  Set by InitGoogleTest().
08433 ::std::vector<String> g_argvs;
08434 
08435 // Returns the command line as a vector of strings.
08436 const ::std::vector<String>& GetArgvs() { return g_argvs; }
08437 
08438 #endif  // GTEST_HAS_DEATH_TEST
08439 
08440 #if GTEST_OS_WINDOWS_MOBILE
08441 namespace posix {
08442 void Abort() {
08443   DebugBreak();
08444   TerminateProcess(GetCurrentProcess(), 1);
08445 }
08446 }  // namespace posix
08447 #endif  // GTEST_OS_WINDOWS_MOBILE
08448 
08449 // Returns the name of the environment variable corresponding to the
08450 // given flag.  For example, FlagToEnvVar("foo") will return
08451 // "GTEST_FOO" in the open-source version.
08452 static String FlagToEnvVar(const char* flag) {
08453   const String full_flag =
08454       (Message() << GTEST_FLAG_PREFIX_ << flag).GetString();
08455 
08456   Message env_var;
08457   for (size_t i = 0; i != full_flag.length(); i++) {
08458     env_var << ToUpper(full_flag.c_str()[i]);
08459   }
08460 
08461   return env_var.GetString();
08462 }
08463 
08464 // Parses 'str' for a 32-bit signed integer.  If successful, writes
08465 // the result to *value and returns true; otherwise leaves *value
08466 // unchanged and returns false.
08467 bool ParseInt32(const Message& src_text, const char* str, Int32* value) {
08468   // Parses the environment variable as a decimal integer.
08469   char* end = NULL;
08470   const long long_value = strtol(str, &end, 10);  // NOLINT
08471 
08472   // Has strtol() consumed all characters in the string?
08473   if (*end != '\0') {
08474     // No - an invalid character was encountered.
08475     Message msg;
08476     msg << "WARNING: " << src_text
08477         << " is expected to be a 32-bit integer, but actually"
08478         << " has value \"" << str << "\".\n";
08479     printf("%s", msg.GetString().c_str());
08480     fflush(stdout);
08481     return false;
08482   }
08483 
08484   // Is the parsed value in the range of an Int32?
08485   const Int32 result = static_cast<Int32>(long_value);
08486   if (long_value == LONG_MAX || long_value == LONG_MIN ||
08487       // The parsed value overflows as a long.  (strtol() returns
08488       // LONG_MAX or LONG_MIN when the input overflows.)
08489       result != long_value
08490       // The parsed value overflows as an Int32.
08491       ) {
08492     Message msg;
08493     msg << "WARNING: " << src_text
08494         << " is expected to be a 32-bit integer, but actually"
08495         << " has value " << str << ", which overflows.\n";
08496     printf("%s", msg.GetString().c_str());
08497     fflush(stdout);
08498     return false;
08499   }
08500 
08501   *value = result;
08502   return true;
08503 }
08504 
08505 // Reads and returns the Boolean environment variable corresponding to
08506 // the given flag; if it's not set, returns default_value.
08507 //
08508 // The value is considered true iff it's not "0".
08509 bool BoolFromGTestEnv(const char* flag, bool default_value) {
08510   const String env_var = FlagToEnvVar(flag);
08511   const char* const string_value = posix::GetEnv(env_var.c_str());
08512   return string_value == NULL ?
08513       default_value : strcmp(string_value, "0") != 0;
08514 }
08515 
08516 // Reads and returns a 32-bit integer stored in the environment
08517 // variable corresponding to the given flag; if it isn't set or
08518 // doesn't represent a valid 32-bit integer, returns default_value.
08519 Int32 Int32FromGTestEnv(const char* flag, Int32 default_value) {
08520   const String env_var = FlagToEnvVar(flag);
08521   const char* const string_value = posix::GetEnv(env_var.c_str());
08522   if (string_value == NULL) {
08523     // The environment variable is not set.
08524     return default_value;
08525   }
08526 
08527   Int32 result = default_value;
08528   if (!ParseInt32(Message() << "Environment variable " << env_var,
08529                   string_value, &result)) {
08530     printf("The default value %s is used.\n",
08531            (Message() << default_value).GetString().c_str());
08532     fflush(stdout);
08533     return default_value;
08534   }
08535 
08536   return result;
08537 }
08538 
08539 // Reads and returns the string environment variable corresponding to
08540 // the given flag; if it's not set, returns default_value.
08541 const char* StringFromGTestEnv(const char* flag, const char* default_value) {
08542   const String env_var = FlagToEnvVar(flag);
08543   const char* const value = posix::GetEnv(env_var.c_str());
08544   return value == NULL ? default_value : value;
08545 }
08546 
08547 }  // namespace internal
08548 }  // namespace testing

08550 // All rights reserved.
08551 //
08552 // Redistribution and use in source and binary forms, with or without
08553 // modification, are permitted provided that the following conditions are
08554 // met:
08555 //
08556 //     * Redistributions of source code must retain the above copyright
08557 // notice, this list of conditions and the following disclaimer.
08558 //     * Redistributions in binary form must reproduce the above
08559 // copyright notice, this list of conditions and the following disclaimer
08560 // in the documentation and/or other materials provided with the
08561 // distribution.
08562 //     * Neither the name of Google Inc. nor the names of its
08563 // contributors may be used to endorse or promote products derived from
08564 // this software without specific prior written permission.
08565 //
08566 // THIS SOFTWARE IS PROVIDED BY THE COPYRIGHT HOLDERS AND CONTRIBUTORS
08567 // "AS IS" AND ANY EXPRESS OR IMPLIED WARRANTIES, INCLUDING, BUT NOT
08568 // LIMITED TO, THE IMPLIED WARRANTIES OF MERCHANTABILITY AND FITNESS FOR
08569 // A PARTICULAR PURPOSE ARE DISCLAIMED. IN NO EVENT SHALL THE COPYRIGHT
08570 // OWNER OR CONTRIBUTORS BE LIABLE FOR ANY DIRECT, INDIRECT, INCIDENTAL,
08571 // SPECIAL, EXEMPLARY, OR CONSEQUENTIAL DAMAGES (INCLUDING, BUT NOT
08572 // LIMITED TO, PROCUREMENT OF SUBSTITUTE GOODS OR SERVICES; LOSS OF USE,
08573 // DATA, OR PROFITS; OR BUSINESS INTERRUPTION) HOWEVER CAUSED AND ON ANY
08574 // THEORY OF LIABILITY, WHETHER IN CONTRACT, STRICT LIABILITY, OR TORT
08575 // (INCLUDING NEGLIGENCE OR OTHERWISE) ARISING IN ANY WAY OUT OF THE USE
08576 // OF THIS SOFTWARE, EVEN IF ADVISED OF THE POSSIBILITY OF SUCH DAMAGE.
08577 //
08578 // Author: wan@google.com (Zhanyong Wan)
08579 
08580 // Google Test - The Google C++ Testing Framework
08581 //
08582 // This file implements a universal value printer that can print a
08583 // value of any type T:
08584 //
08585 //   void ::testing::internal::UniversalPrinter<T>::Print(value, ostream_ptr);
08586 //
08587 // It uses the << operator when possible, and prints the bytes in the
08588 // object otherwise.  A user can override its behavior for a class
08589 // type Foo by defining either operator<<(::std::ostream&, const Foo&)
08590 // or void PrintTo(const Foo&, ::std::ostream*) in the namespace that
08591 // defines Foo.
08592 
08593 #include <ctype.h>
08594 #include <stdio.h>
08595 #include <ostream>  // NOLINT
08596 #include <string>
08597 
08598 namespace testing {
08599 
08600 namespace {
08601 
08602 using ::std::ostream;
08603 
08604 #if GTEST_OS_WINDOWS_MOBILE  // Windows CE does not define _snprintf_s.
08605 # define snprintf _snprintf
08606 #elif _MSC_VER >= 1400  // VC 8.0 and later deprecate snprintf and _snprintf.
08607 # define snprintf _snprintf_s
08608 #elif _MSC_VER
08609 # define snprintf _snprintf
08610 #endif  // GTEST_OS_WINDOWS_MOBILE
08611 
08612 // Prints a segment of bytes in the given object.
08613 void PrintByteSegmentInObjectTo(const unsigned char* obj_bytes, size_t start,
08614                                 size_t count, ostream* os) {
08615   char text[5] = "";
08616   for (size_t i = 0; i != count; i++) {
08617     const size_t j = start + i;
08618     if (i != 0) {
08619       // Organizes the bytes into groups of 2 for easy parsing by
08620       // human.
08621       if ((j % 2) == 0)
08622         *os << ' ';
08623       else
08624         *os << '-';
08625     }
08626     snprintf(text, sizeof(text), "%02X", obj_bytes[j]);
08627     *os << text;
08628   }
08629 }
08630 
08631 // Prints the bytes in the given value to the given ostream.
08632 void PrintBytesInObjectToImpl(const unsigned char* obj_bytes, size_t count,
08633                               ostream* os) {
08634   // Tells the user how big the object is.
08635   *os << count << "-byte object <";
08636 
08637   const size_t kThreshold = 132;
08638   const size_t kChunkSize = 64;
08639   // If the object size is bigger than kThreshold, we'll have to omit
08640   // some details by printing only the first and the last kChunkSize
08641   // bytes.
08642   // TODO(wan): let the user control the threshold using a flag.
08643   if (count < kThreshold) {
08644     PrintByteSegmentInObjectTo(obj_bytes, 0, count, os);
08645   } else {
08646     PrintByteSegmentInObjectTo(obj_bytes, 0, kChunkSize, os);
08647     *os << " ... ";
08648     // Rounds up to 2-byte boundary.
08649     const size_t resume_pos = (count - kChunkSize + 1)/2*2;
08650     PrintByteSegmentInObjectTo(obj_bytes, resume_pos, count - resume_pos, os);
08651   }
08652   *os << ">";
08653 }
08654 
08655 }  // namespace
08656 
08657 namespace internal2 {
08658 
08659 // Delegates to PrintBytesInObjectToImpl() to print the bytes in the
08660 // given object.  The delegation simplifies the implementation, which
08661 // uses the << operator and thus is easier done outside of the
08662 // ::testing::internal namespace, which contains a << operator that
08663 // sometimes conflicts with the one in STL.
08664 void PrintBytesInObjectTo(const unsigned char* obj_bytes, size_t count,
08665                           ostream* os) {
08666   PrintBytesInObjectToImpl(obj_bytes, count, os);
08667 }
08668 
08669 }  // namespace internal2
08670 
08671 namespace internal {
08672 
08673 // Depending on the value of a char (or wchar_t), we print it in one
08674 // of three formats:
08675 //   - as is if it's a printable ASCII (e.g. 'a', '2', ' '),
08676 //   - as a hexidecimal escape sequence (e.g. '\x7F'), or
08677 //   - as a special escape sequence (e.g. '\r', '\n').
08678 enum CharFormat {
08679   kAsIs,
08680   kHexEscape,
08681   kSpecialEscape
08682 };
08683 
08684 // Returns true if c is a printable ASCII character.  We test the
08685 // value of c directly instead of calling isprint(), which is buggy on
08686 // Windows Mobile.
08687 inline bool IsPrintableAscii(wchar_t c) {
08688   return 0x20 <= c && c <= 0x7E;
08689 }
08690 
08691 // Prints a wide or narrow char c as a character literal without the
08692 // quotes, escaping it when necessary; returns how c was formatted.
08693 // The template argument UnsignedChar is the unsigned version of Char,
08694 // which is the type of c.
08695 template <typename UnsignedChar, typename Char>
08696 static CharFormat PrintAsCharLiteralTo(Char c, ostream* os) {
08697   switch (static_cast<wchar_t>(c)) {
08698     case L'\0':
08699       *os << "\\0";
08700       break;
08701     case L'\'':
08702       *os << "\\'";
08703       break;
08704     case L'\\':
08705       *os << "\\\\";
08706       break;
08707     case L'\a':
08708       *os << "\\a";
08709       break;
08710     case L'\b':
08711       *os << "\\b";
08712       break;
08713     case L'\f':
08714       *os << "\\f";
08715       break;
08716     case L'\n':
08717       *os << "\\n";
08718       break;
08719     case L'\r':
08720       *os << "\\r";
08721       break;
08722     case L'\t':
08723       *os << "\\t";
08724       break;
08725     case L'\v':
08726       *os << "\\v";
08727       break;
08728     default:
08729       if (IsPrintableAscii(c)) {
08730         *os << static_cast<char>(c);
08731         return kAsIs;
08732       } else {
08733         *os << String::Format("\\x%X", static_cast<UnsignedChar>(c));
08734         return kHexEscape;
08735       }
08736   }
08737   return kSpecialEscape;
08738 }
08739 
08740 // Prints a char c as if it's part of a string literal, escaping it when
08741 // necessary; returns how c was formatted.
08742 static CharFormat PrintAsWideStringLiteralTo(wchar_t c, ostream* os) {
08743   switch (c) {
08744     case L'\'':
08745       *os << "'";
08746       return kAsIs;
08747     case L'"':
08748       *os << "\\\"";
08749       return kSpecialEscape;
08750     default:
08751       return PrintAsCharLiteralTo<wchar_t>(c, os);
08752   }
08753 }
08754 
08755 // Prints a char c as if it's part of a string literal, escaping it when
08756 // necessary; returns how c was formatted.
08757 static CharFormat PrintAsNarrowStringLiteralTo(char c, ostream* os) {
08758   return PrintAsWideStringLiteralTo(static_cast<unsigned char>(c), os);
08759 }
08760 
08761 // Prints a wide or narrow character c and its code.  '\0' is printed
08762 // as "'\\0'", other unprintable characters are also properly escaped
08763 // using the standard C++ escape sequence.  The template argument
08764 // UnsignedChar is the unsigned version of Char, which is the type of c.
08765 template <typename UnsignedChar, typename Char>
08766 void PrintCharAndCodeTo(Char c, ostream* os) {
08767   // First, print c as a literal in the most readable form we can find.
08768   *os << ((sizeof(c) > 1) ? "L'" : "'");
08769   const CharFormat format = PrintAsCharLiteralTo<UnsignedChar>(c, os);
08770   *os << "'";
08771 
08772   // To aid user debugging, we also print c's code in decimal, unless
08773   // it's 0 (in which case c was printed as '\\0', making the code
08774   // obvious).
08775   if (c == 0)
08776     return;
08777   *os << " (" << String::Format("%d", c).c_str();
08778 
08779   // For more convenience, we print c's code again in hexidecimal,
08780   // unless c was already printed in the form '\x##' or the code is in
08781   // [1, 9].
08782   if (format == kHexEscape || (1 <= c && c <= 9)) {
08783     // Do nothing.
08784   } else {
08785     *os << String::Format(", 0x%X",
08786                           static_cast<UnsignedChar>(c)).c_str();
08787   }
08788   *os << ")";
08789 }
08790 
08791 void PrintTo(unsigned char c, ::std::ostream* os) {
08792   PrintCharAndCodeTo<unsigned char>(c, os);
08793 }
08794 void PrintTo(signed char c, ::std::ostream* os) {
08795   PrintCharAndCodeTo<unsigned char>(c, os);
08796 }
08797 
08798 // Prints a wchar_t as a symbol if it is printable or as its internal
08799 // code otherwise and also as its code.  L'\0' is printed as "L'\\0'".
08800 void PrintTo(wchar_t wc, ostream* os) {
08801   PrintCharAndCodeTo<wchar_t>(wc, os);
08802 }
08803 
08804 // Prints the given array of characters to the ostream.
08805 // The array starts at *begin, the length is len, it may include '\0' characters
08806 // and may not be null-terminated.
08807 static void PrintCharsAsStringTo(const char* begin, size_t len, ostream* os) {
08808   *os << "\"";
08809   bool is_previous_hex = false;
08810   for (size_t index = 0; index < len; ++index) {
08811     const char cur = begin[index];
08812     if (is_previous_hex && IsXDigit(cur)) {
08813       // Previous character is of '\x..' form and this character can be
08814       // interpreted as another hexadecimal digit in its number. Break string to
08815       // disambiguate.
08816       *os << "\" \"";
08817     }
08818     is_previous_hex = PrintAsNarrowStringLiteralTo(cur, os) == kHexEscape;
08819   }
08820   *os << "\"";
08821 }
08822 
08823 // Prints a (const) char array of 'len' elements, starting at address 'begin'.
08824 void UniversalPrintArray(const char* begin, size_t len, ostream* os) {
08825   PrintCharsAsStringTo(begin, len, os);
08826 }
08827 
08828 // Prints the given array of wide characters to the ostream.
08829 // The array starts at *begin, the length is len, it may include L'\0'
08830 // characters and may not be null-terminated.
08831 static void PrintWideCharsAsStringTo(const wchar_t* begin, size_t len,
08832                                      ostream* os) {
08833   *os << "L\"";
08834   bool is_previous_hex = false;
08835   for (size_t index = 0; index < len; ++index) {
08836     const wchar_t cur = begin[index];
08837     if (is_previous_hex && isascii(cur) && IsXDigit(static_cast<char>(cur))) {
08838       // Previous character is of '\x..' form and this character can be
08839       // interpreted as another hexadecimal digit in its number. Break string to
08840       // disambiguate.
08841       *os << "\" L\"";
08842     }
08843     is_previous_hex = PrintAsWideStringLiteralTo(cur, os) == kHexEscape;
08844   }
08845   *os << "\"";
08846 }
08847 
08848 // Prints the given C string to the ostream.
08849 void PrintTo(const char* s, ostream* os) {
08850   if (s == NULL) {
08851     *os << "NULL";
08852   } else {
08853     *os << ImplicitCast_<const void*>(s) << " pointing to ";
08854     PrintCharsAsStringTo(s, strlen(s), os);
08855   }
08856 }
08857 
08858 // MSVC compiler can be configured to define whar_t as a typedef
08859 // of unsigned short. Defining an overload for const wchar_t* in that case
08860 // would cause pointers to unsigned shorts be printed as wide strings,
08861 // possibly accessing more memory than intended and causing invalid
08862 // memory accesses. MSVC defines _NATIVE_WCHAR_T_DEFINED symbol when
08863 // wchar_t is implemented as a native type.
08864 #if !defined(_MSC_VER) || defined(_NATIVE_WCHAR_T_DEFINED)
08865 // Prints the given wide C string to the ostream.
08866 void PrintTo(const wchar_t* s, ostream* os) {
08867   if (s == NULL) {
08868     *os << "NULL";
08869   } else {
08870     *os << ImplicitCast_<const void*>(s) << " pointing to ";
08871     PrintWideCharsAsStringTo(s, wcslen(s), os);
08872   }
08873 }
08874 #endif  // wchar_t is native
08875 
08876 // Prints a ::string object.
08877 #if GTEST_HAS_GLOBAL_STRING
08878 void PrintStringTo(const ::string& s, ostream* os) {
08879   PrintCharsAsStringTo(s.data(), s.size(), os);
08880 }
08881 #endif  // GTEST_HAS_GLOBAL_STRING
08882 
08883 void PrintStringTo(const ::std::string& s, ostream* os) {
08884   PrintCharsAsStringTo(s.data(), s.size(), os);
08885 }
08886 
08887 // Prints a ::wstring object.
08888 #if GTEST_HAS_GLOBAL_WSTRING
08889 void PrintWideStringTo(const ::wstring& s, ostream* os) {
08890   PrintWideCharsAsStringTo(s.data(), s.size(), os);
08891 }
08892 #endif  // GTEST_HAS_GLOBAL_WSTRING
08893 
08894 #if GTEST_HAS_STD_WSTRING
08895 void PrintWideStringTo(const ::std::wstring& s, ostream* os) {
08896   PrintWideCharsAsStringTo(s.data(), s.size(), os);
08897 }
08898 #endif  // GTEST_HAS_STD_WSTRING
08899 
08900 }  // namespace internal
08901 
08902 }  // namespace testing

08937 // Indicates that this translation unit is part of Google Test's
08938 // implementation.  It must come before gtest-internal-inl.h is
08939 // included, or there will be a compiler error.  This trick is to
08940 // prevent a user from accidentally including gtest-internal-inl.h in
08941 // his code.
08942 #define GTEST_IMPLEMENTATION_ 1
08943 #undef GTEST_IMPLEMENTATION_
08944 
08945 namespace testing {
08946 
08947 using internal::GetUnitTestImpl;
08948 
08949 // Gets the summary of the failure message by omitting the stack trace
08950 // in it.
08951 internal::String TestPartResult::ExtractSummary(const char* message) {
08952   const char* const stack_trace = strstr(message, internal::kStackTraceMarker);
08953   return stack_trace == NULL ? internal::String(message) :
08954       internal::String(message, stack_trace - message);
08955 }
08956 
08957 // Prints a TestPartResult object.
08958 std::ostream& operator<<(std::ostream& os, const TestPartResult& result) {
08959   return os
08960       << result.file_name() << ":" << result.line_number() << ": "
08961       << (result.type() == TestPartResult::kSuccess ? "Success" :
08962           result.type() == TestPartResult::kFatalFailure ? "Fatal failure" :
08963           "Non-fatal failure") << ":\n"
08964       << result.message() << std::endl;
08965 }
08966 
08967 // Appends a TestPartResult to the array.
08968 void TestPartResultArray::Append(const TestPartResult& result) {
08969   array_.push_back(result);
08970 }
08971 
08972 // Returns the TestPartResult at the given index (0-based).
08973 const TestPartResult& TestPartResultArray::GetTestPartResult(int index) const {
08974   if (index < 0 || index >= size()) {
08975     printf("\nInvalid index (%d) into TestPartResultArray.\n", index);
08976     internal::posix::Abort();
08977   }
08978 
08979   return array_[index];
08980 }
08981 
08982 // Returns the number of TestPartResult objects in the array.
08983 int TestPartResultArray::size() const {
08984   return static_cast<int>(array_.size());
08985 }
08986 
08987 namespace internal {
08988 
08989 HasNewFatalFailureHelper::HasNewFatalFailureHelper()
08990     : has_new_fatal_failure_(false),
08991       original_reporter_(GetUnitTestImpl()->
08992                          GetTestPartResultReporterForCurrentThread()) {
08993   GetUnitTestImpl()->SetTestPartResultReporterForCurrentThread(this);
08994 }
08995 
08996 HasNewFatalFailureHelper::~HasNewFatalFailureHelper() {
08997   GetUnitTestImpl()->SetTestPartResultReporterForCurrentThread(
08998       original_reporter_);
08999 }
09000 
09001 void HasNewFatalFailureHelper::ReportTestPartResult(
09002     const TestPartResult& result) {
09003   if (result.fatally_failed())
09004     has_new_fatal_failure_ = true;
09005   original_reporter_->ReportTestPartResult(result);
09006 }
09007

09043 namespace testing {
09044 namespace internal {
09045 
09046 #if GTEST_HAS_TYPED_TEST_P
09047 
09048 // Skips to the first non-space char in str. Returns an empty string if str
09049 // contains only whitespace characters.
09050 static const char* SkipSpaces(const char* str) {
09051   while (IsSpace(*str))
09052     str++;
09053   return str;
09054 }
09055 
09056 // Verifies that registered_tests match the test names in
09057 // defined_test_names_; returns registered_tests if successful, or
09058 // aborts the program otherwise.
09059 const char* TypedTestCasePState::VerifyRegisteredTestNames(
09060     const char* file, int line, const char* registered_tests) {
09061   typedef ::std::set<const char*>::const_iterator DefinedTestIter;
09062   registered_ = true;
09063 
09064   // Skip initial whitespace in registered_tests since some
09065   // preprocessors prefix stringizied literals with whitespace.
09066   registered_tests = SkipSpaces(registered_tests);
09067 
09068   Message errors;
09069   ::std::set<String> tests;
09070   for (const char* names = registered_tests; names != NULL;
09071        names = SkipComma(names)) {
09072     const String name = GetPrefixUntilComma(names);
09073     if (tests.count(name) != 0) {
09074       errors << "Test " << name << " is listed more than once.\n";
09075       continue;
09076     }
09077 
09078     bool found = false;
09079     for (DefinedTestIter it = defined_test_names_.begin();
09080          it != defined_test_names_.end();
09081          ++it) {
09082       if (name == *it) {
09083         found = true;
09084         break;
09085       }
09086     }
09087 
09088     if (found) {
09089       tests.insert(name);
09090     } else {
09091       errors << "No test named " << name
09092              << " can be found in this test case.\n";
09093     }
09094   }
09095 
09096   for (DefinedTestIter it = defined_test_names_.begin();
09097        it != defined_test_names_.end();
09098        ++it) {
09099     if (tests.count(*it) == 0) {
09100       errors << "You forgot to list test " << *it << ".\n";
09101     }
09102   }
09103 
09104   const String& errors_str = errors.GetString();
09105   if (errors_str != "") {
09106     fprintf(stderr, "%s %s", FormatFileLocation(file, line).c_str(),
09107             errors_str.c_str());
09108     fflush(stderr);
09109     posix::Abort();
09110   }
09111 
09112   return registered_tests;
09113 }
09114 
09115 #endif  // GTEST_HAS_TYPED_TEST_P
09116 
09117 }  // namespace internal
09118 }  // namespace testing
